PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Sex Discrimination Legislation
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983, in context with the U.N. Convention, especially Articles 4 and 10, is going to break down traditional family life and reduce the choice of women to be homemakers.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you do not support the Sex Discrimination Bill, or if passed, it be rescinded together with the United Nations Convention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms.
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations.
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
Should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Grimes (from 39 citizens), Jones (from 184 citizens), Lajovic (from 196 citizens), Reid (from 45 citizens) and Sibraa (from 44 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
should delay the Bill and ask:
That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine-
(a) the implications of the U. N. Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Covenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the U. N. Convention.
The terms of reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the effect of sliding scale income and fee assessment applied in subsidised child care centres causes financial hardship and emotional stress for many families in moderate to middle income brackets.

Your servants humbly request that consideration be given to reviewing the present guidelines for determining fees, in particular examining the range of allowable deductions, and the upper limit for fee relief.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Federal Government Subsidy to Residential Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned students and staff of the Armidale C.A.E. respectfully showeth that we are concerned at the consequences for residential students, at this College of the reduction by 25 per cent in the current Federal Government subsidy to Halls of Residence.
Being a regional centre, nearly all the 500 internal significant number of students (who are enrolled) at the Armidale C.A.E. are reliant upon residential accommodation, 200 live at Smith House.

The reduction in subsidy will lead to an increase in changes have the effect of forcing a number of students to terminate their studies and also restrict access to higher education in the Northern Tableland and North Coast region.
In particular we would call upon the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and all members of the Senate to take action to ensure that the full subsidy ( pre 1983-84 Budget) be reinstated.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will support the above claim. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Force Reserves
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia are concerned at the termination of the tax exemption on Defence Force Reserve pay. We are convinced that unequal relativities in pay will occur and the Reserve Force will lose a large number of dedicated trained servicemen and women which will make it impossible for the Reserve to meet it's commitments to the defence of Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will act to form a Senate Select Committee to inquire into and report on the effect of the removal of the tax exemption prior to the implementation of Government policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of Local Governments in Australia shows that
General revenue grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State Governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-selection commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the metric system and request the Government to restore the imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Grape Spirit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 1983 Budget imposition of the excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine places at risk the future of the fortified wine industry in Australia.
That the requirement to pay the excise within 7 days of the fortification occurring is inequitable.
That the excise will be reflected in increased costs to the consumers of fortified wines of up to 100 per cent and consumer choice will be restricted.
That this will cause reduced fortified wine sales which will result in reduced intake of grapes from grapegrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and either withdraw this tax or modify its method of application and collection.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the Senate of two significant developments, relating to the information systems and services for the Parliament, which have occurred during 1983. The first of these developments concerns planning for the new Parliament House. It was essential that the Parliament House Construction Authority be advised of senators' and members' possible information systems requirements so that provision could be made in the new building for the development of such facilities.

INTERJECT.PARA: It was agreed to engage a specialist consultant to assist with the preparation of a brief and the tender was awarded to Logica Pty Ltd, a firm which has had considerable experience in both the information technology area and the requirements of the Parliament. Logica began its work on 9 May 1983 and presented its report on 21 June 1983. Parliamentary staff worked with the consultants, and questionnaires were issued to senators and members. In addition a number were interviewed personally. This report formed the basis of the statement of user requirements which has now been forwarded to the Parliament House Construction Authority.

I now table the report by Logica Pty Ltd, which includes an information systems review and a user requirements statement for the information systems and services for the new Parliament House. I must add that, at this stage, there is no commitment to all or any of the systems described in the report and that senators will shortly be given the opportunity to comment on the report. Due to the size of the report, a limited number of copies have been printed and these are available to senators from the Senate Records Office.

The second development relates to a pilot study now being undertaken by the parliamentary departments into the applicability of computer-based information storage and retrieval systems to the information needs of the Parliament. Following a lengthy planning period and a tender and selection process which has extended from November 1982, a contract was signed with International Computers (Australia) Pty Ltd on 17 October 1983 for the provision of a rented service for a pilot study.

It is proposed that the pilot study continue until May 1984 and that Senate and House of Representatives Hansard, Journals of the Senate, Votes and Proceedings, Australian Senate Practice, and House of Representatives Practice will be mounted on the service to enable effective evaluation of computer-based information storage and retrieval in the Parliament. After the pilot study has been evaluated by the parliamentary departments. Mr Speaker and I will decide whether the project will proceed further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In doing so I comment briefly that I believe one of the significant aspects of the report of the National Standards Commission is the comments it makes in relation to measurements in trade and commerce. We are all only too painfully aware of the way in which standards can be misused as a form of protection, as an alternative to tariffs, to serve purposes entirely different from those which they are intended to serve. I think that Australia's record in this area is good . I believe the report supports that view. I note that further matters will be discussed in relation to this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested to receive the report of the National Standards Commission. I was interested that such effort should be devoted to trying to arrive at uniform standards. However, the line which I was particularly struck by-it is an extraordinary statement in the foreword-which I feel would benefit all honourable senators, if not amuse them, to hear reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It is of great importance that measurements made throughout Australia, and indeed throughout the world, be uniform in the sense that they can be intercompared meaningfully.

I simply suggest that a report which resorts to language such as that in its foreword probably needs to be examined somewhat seriously. I am not sure what the word 'intercompared' means when the word 'compared' would have done beautifully. I am not sure about the term 'intercompared meaningfully' either. But that is probably a flippant comment about the foreword. I think it is terribly important that we try to arrive at some kind of national standards. I also think it is quite remarkable that so many serious and earnest people sit together for so long and still seem to achieve very slowly any kind of uniformity of standards. However, I am pleased that we actually are proceeding with the task. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Australian Bicentennial Authority, which I know is supported by all members of the Senate, has presented a report which we should welcome. I think that the Authority has done an excellent job in reaching out to the community. First of all, it has found out what the community wanted in the way of the bicentennial celebrations and, having determined that, has indicated a method of progressing and of advertising the activities by the Authority and for the bicentenary. After doing that very careful ground work, the Authority has reached the stage where there have been some announcements of grants and we are moving towards looking at what shape the special activites for the bicentenary will take. There is not a great deal more to be said about the Authority. It has presented a report which gives a review of its operations and indicates what is happening in some of the States. I think it is excellent that the bicentenary committees are involving so many people. They are involving all levels of government and community organisations. That, to some extent, has been reflected in the recommendations that have been made so far for expenditure of money under the auspices of the Authority.

I just want to make a brief comment in relation to the grant that has been made to Queensland. One of the projects that has received approval is an Australian air museum which, according to a newspaper report, has been earmarked for land near the Dreamworld concept at Coomera. This project is to get $760,000 under the recommendations. An organisation in Queensland has been working for quite a number of years towards establishing an air museum in Queensland. This organisation, called the Queensland Air Museum, is run by a group of absolutely dedicated amateurs-I suppose I have to call them that because they are working for nothing-who have worked very hard to obtain aircraft for an air museum and to undertake some restoration of those aircraft. They have had no funding. They have been able to use some land only as a result of some generosity of the Commonwealth Government. However they have no security as to their future. They have had no money with which to purchase available planes. They have missed out on these planes or they have been purchased by others. Time and again they have lamented the fact that important aircraft, which they could possibly put on display in their air museum, have been lost to them.

I do not know anything about this project at Coomera. It is a new one to me. I read about it only when the bicentenary grants were announced. I do not know what resources this group has for purchasing aircraft. I am sure that it will abe able to use part of the grant for restoring aircraft. However, I want to point out that fact that the Queensland Air Museum was not supported and the alternative project, which very few people had heard about, was supported and was a matter of some public comment. One newspaper report stated:
The Queensland Australian Bicentennial Authority chairman, Mr Ian Russell, said , there was no question of political influence on the choice of selected recipients.
I accept Mr Russell's word for that-

Asked why the Queensland Air Museum's long standing campaign to establish an aviation museum had lost out to the Coomera proposal, which was within the Albert electorate of National Party member Mr Ivan Gibbs, Mr Russell said: 'I can't comment about that.
'My understanding is that Coomera is a better site and the State Government has land down there.'

That is quite a reasonable explanation. One of the problems that the Queensland Air Museum has is getting a site because it does not have the money to purchase land. Local government, State government and the Commonwealth Government have not been prepared to grant the group a site. I welcome the fact that the State Government has made a site available. I am not putting in any sort of plea for the overturning of the Bicentennial Authority's recommendations. The plea I enter is that the work that the people associated with the Queensland Air Museum have done and the items that they have acquired be taken into account in this project at Coomera. I hope that we will not have any controversy over this but that, instead, those who have the grant for the project that has been approved will take the opportunity to contact the Queensland Air Museum and if possible, will amalgamate the efforts of the two projects. Through its years of hard work, the Queensland Air Museum has attracted to it people who have some expertise on restoring aircraft and certainly a lot of expertise on Australia's aircraft. I hope that my suggestions will be taken note of and that there will be no acrimony in Queensland about this particular grant from the Bicentennial Authority.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I was privileged, and I thank the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the then Special Minister of State (Mr Young), to be granted delegate status at the National Crimes Summit Conference held in July in this chamber. I was pleased to receive this excellent discussion paper, 'A National Crimes Commission?' prepared by Senator Gareth Evans and Mr Mick Young. I am pleased to take this opportunity again of congratulating the Government on the progress it has made on the Special Prosecutor's Office and the appointment of that excellent young man, Mr Redlich, as Special Prosecutor. I congratulate him on the work that he is doing.

I still remain disturbed. As I have mentioned before, organised crime in this country is growing. In my estimate, it is now receiving profits of $750m per year. I am persuaded that the mechanisms that we have at the moment, such as State police forces, excellent though some of them are, are not capable of curing this problem. That is not just Senator Chipp giving that as an opinion. As the Attorney-General will testify, Mr Justice Moffitt, Mr Justice Woodward, Mr Justice Williams, Mr Costigan and Mr Justice Stewart, five distinguished royal commissioners, came into this chamber in July and were unanimous in their advocacy of a national crimes commission along the lines of the Fraser-Durack model, which I have publicly commended and which I think, in his heart, the present Attorney-General commends also. At that meeting we met a sickening display by State politicians which equalled, in its dimensions, the display of State politicians at the Constitutional Convention in Adelaide. It seemed that the attitude of State politicians was: 'Well, if organised crime has to flourish , so be it, but under no circumstances will we stand by and see States' rights trampled on'. That is the sort of cry I have heard from State politicians right throughout my 23 years in Parliament. In fact one person at the Conference, a Queenslander, Mr Doumany, who thankfully now is out of the ranks of parliamentarians, said that, essentially, organised crime was a figment of the imagination of the media.

The Fraser-Durack model was virtually killed at that Conference. I have great sympathy for the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, who has tried desperately to create something effective in this line. The State Attorneys- General and police Ministers have said virtually 'We will not co-operate'. Senator Gareth Evans cannot now bring in the Fraser-Durack model, as the Opposition is advocating, because his left wing has now turned against him-again I feel sorry for him for that-for probably good reasons.

I remain dissatisfied with the present state of affairs. One has got to look at the lack of progress made about allegations on the Jackson tapes to know that we need something else. In this short time I cannot do the matters justice. The Australian Democrats are seriously looking, as I understand the Liberal Party is seriously looking, at the creation of some other vehicle, even a creature of the Senate, to hear the kinds of allegations being made by people who will not testify at a State instituted inquiry but will only testify, for reasons of their own safety, at a Federal inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly to this motion. I hope that we adjourn it to next Thursday, perhaps, to have a fuller debate. It will, of course, be very relevant to the discussion of the Bill that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is about to introduce. The policy discussion paper which has now been tabled together with the record of the National Crimes Commission Conference will be particularly relevant to that debate. I understand that the motion also incorporates a noting and enabling discussion of the report of the Special Prosecutor, Mr Gyles. Unfortunately that has not been available in time to be considered at this stage. I am sure that it will be a report that will be most worthy of discussion in this chamber. We should have time to consider it before we embark upon those discussions. I do not want to say anything about that today.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say, however, that the policy discussion paper on a national crimes commission is a most worthwhile document. It provided a very useful basis , indeed, for the National Crimes Commission Conference. The paper was produced as a result of a great deal of work done by the Attorney-General's Department and particularly by Mr Menzies of that Department during the whole of last year when the development of the National Crimes Commission Act was being undertaken and, of course, followed with the new directions from the present Government.

I share the great disappointment mentioned by Senator Chipp with the Crimes Commission Conference because I do not believe that, by and large, those who participated in that conference really addressed the basic issue that was before us and will be before us; that is, how do we adequately reconcile the clear need , as exemplified by those royal commissioners mentioned by Senator Chipp, for a national initiative and an independent body which will be able to take initiatives of a worthwhile investigative kind of its own in regard to organised and sophisticated crime. That need has to be addressed as does the protection of civil liberties.

It astounded me that at the Conference a number of people got up and said that the national crimes commission proposal of the Fraser Government ignored civil liberties, was a threat to civil liberties and so on. Nothing could be further from the truth. The National Crimes Commission Act passed by this Parliament preserved the privilege about self-incrimination. There may be some strong arguments, as Mr Costigan advanced, that it should not do so. That was, in fact, recognised by the Fraser Government's legislation and it is recognised and accepted by the Opposition today. But so much legislation, such as the Sex Discrimination Bill, the national companies and securities legislation for inquiries being undertaken in the companies area and numerous other measures, comes into this chamber regularly which completely removes the right and privilege of self-incrimination. But that crimes commission proposal preserved that right and privilege and contained quite a number of other safeguards almost all of which, I understand, although we have not yet seen the legislation, will be repeated in the legislation which is going to be introduced by the Attorney- General.

So I say in general terms that I believe there was almost an obsession expressed by a number of participants in that Conference, particularly those from my own profession, the legal profession. They simply lost sight of the urgency and necessity of having what Mr Redlich has called a robust, independent authority at a national level which is going to be effective in the fight against organised and sophisticated crime. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 211th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 211th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts contains the Department of Finance minute on the Committee's 184th report which was a discussion paper on internal audit in the Australian Public Service. The Department of Finance minute is the formal documentation of the Government's response to the Committee's recommendations as contained in the 184th report which was tabled in the Parliament on 11 February 1981. The Committee regards internal audit as an essential tool through which management can monitor the effectiveness of its controls and keep informed about the reliability and suitablity of the systems and procedures it employs. The inquiry did not result from a specific reference, but rather it was a discussion paper arising from the Committee's long-standing interest in management and the quality of administration within the Public Service. The discussion paper was based on the collective experience of the Committee over many years as well as discussions with government departments, academics, professional accounting and auditing bodies and leading organisations in the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The paper looked at some of the problems of internal audit, ranging from an historical perspective to the work being undertaken to increase the effectiveness of internal audit groups. The Committee hoped that the report would stimulate further consideration of the broader dimension of the problem and suggestions for the development of a balanced approach towards achieving a solution. Previous attempts to improve internal audit in the Australian Public Service had been generally unsuccessful. It is clear that those failures resulted from insufficient interest on the part of permanent and statutory heads and a lack of support for internal audit by senior management; a situation exacerbated by the low standard of internal audit capability. The findings of the 1977 Public Service Board review of internal audit focused attention on the dismal state of internal audit in the public service and stimulated renewed efforts to bring about improvements. The Public Service Board has now initiated action designed to upgrade internal audit. Its success will depend entirely on the support given by individual departments and authorities. The Committee regards it is as essential that the heads of departments and authorities cultivate a genuine interest in internal audit and learn to use it effectively. The tendency for many permanent heads to concentrate on policy matters and ignore administrative and financial affairs cannot be condoned.

In addition, the Committee believes that officers who are motivated, qualified, experienced and capable must be encouraged to enter internal audit so that it can attain its full potential. The joint impact of the 1977 joint management review of internal audit and this Committee's report has now been observed within the public sector. This Finance minute details the main policy developments which have resulted. These are as follows: Establishment of the Joint Implementation Committee on Internal Audit (JIC) to assist the Public Service Board and departments in implementing the follow-up action arising from the joint management review; establishment of the Interdepartmental Advisory Committee on Internal Audit-IDAC; twenty departments and authorities now have internal audit committees consisting of Second Division officers and chaired by permanent heads, deputy secretaries or first assistant secretaries; progress has been made in the area of automatic data processing auditing-this has been encouraged through an IDAC paper circulated in June 1981 entitled 'The Development of Departmental Arrangements for ADP Auditing'; the Public Service Board has issued, in volume 4 of its personnel management manual, seven sets of guidelines for departments on different aspects of computer-based systems-these provide a starting point for the planning of ADP audits; classification of the chief internal auditor position has been raised in 24 organisations-in six departments this position is in the Second Division and in most others it is at the top of the Third Division; most departments have reorganised their internal audit positions so that there has been an overall trend of upward movement in their classification; in all organisations surveyed in 1982 the control of in- audit functions had been centralised.

Nevertheless, the Public Accounts Committee is concerned that considerable effort is still necessary to ensure that internal audit capability in the Public Service is established and maintained at an appropriate level. The Committee is committed to ensuring the necessary improvements in internal audit are brought about. The Committee will therefore use every opportunity to check progress within departments and test the commitment of permanent and statutory heads and management towards effective internal audit. I commend this report to honourable senators.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Department of Education and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night a number of honourable senators put questions to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) concerning behind the scenes adjustments to higher school certificate results in respect of girls in the Australian Capital Territory. It is said that an alleged bias against those girls might be corrected in this way. The Minister was not able to give a substantial explanation in relation to the questions we put. I wonder whether the Minister has received more information overnight which would help to explain the reason for this alleged bias, the facts which led her to believe that this bias exists and the justice that she thinks might be achieved through this type of correction.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind Senator Teague that I undertook last night to get from the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, which is entirely responsible for this matter, a detailed account of its response to the committee inquiring into the bias in the Australian Scholastic Aptitude Test. I am assured by officers that that paper will be available shortly after 12 o'clock. I will then have it incorporated into the proceedings of this Committee.

—Senator Peter Baume cannot be present in the chamber this morning. On his behalf I raise a matter which he referred to during the adjournment debate on 14 September. That matter concerns Mr Jim Coates, who sought promotion within the Public Service but did not receive the promotion in the way that was outlined by Senator Peter Baume in his speech during the adjournment debate on 14 September. Senator Peter Baume spoke at considerable length about this matter. In brief, it appears that Mr Coates has been blocked from gaining the promotion he was seeking because of a conscientious stance he has taken with regard to the Australian Teachers Federation and his not subscribing to that union. The details of his case have already been put to the Senate in Senator Peter Baume's speech on the adjournment a month and a half ago. We expect the Minister to respond on this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Following Senator Peter Baume's raising of this matter in the adjournment debate I asked the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority for a full inquiry and report on the concerns expressed by Senator Peter Baume. I now read for the benefit of Senator Teague the advice which has just been handed to me from the Schools Authority. First of all, the assessment in question was not an assessment for a promotion. It was an assessment for eligibility for promotion. The Chief Education Officer advises me that assessment for promotion eligibility is a peer process. The panel did not reach consensus in support of the particular officer. In line with agreed procedures this decision was reviewed by an independent panel of expert teachers. This panel confirmed the decision. There is no evidence that the officer was in any way discriminated against or that any membrs of the panel were biased against him.

—I raise a separate matter that relates to the 41 schools which have been denied the basic grant of earlier years. The formula has now been described by the Minister. It relates to an assessment of the private recurrent means, non-government recurrent means, of schools. If they are greater than 95 per cent of the average cost of a government school place, those schools will incur the 25 per cent reduction. It is clear that that assessment of whether they have independent recurrent means of 95 per cent of the cost of a government school place, is based on 1981 costs. May I be assured that the cost of a government school place was assessed in 1981 costs so that we are not applying to the formula a 1983 average government school place cost and yet, with regard to the independent schools, 1981 independent means?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I should correct an inaccuracy in the terms in which Senator Teague asked his question. The 41 schools which have had their Commonwealth recurrent grants reduced by 25 per cent have not been denied a basic right. After the reduction of 25 per cent, they are still receiving $254 per primary school pupil and $402 per secondary school pupil. It is wildly misleading to suggest that they have been denied a basic right. They have a basic right in accordance with the amounts I have just described.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator questioned the use of 1981-82 expenditure data by the Schools Commission in arriving at its formula. Senator Teague has been told by me before that this was the most recent data available to the Commission. It was indexed to take account of cost increases since 1981, but in the formulation of a needs-based method of determining funding for non-government schools in the next Budget, the community standard will, as I have said on many occasions, take into account all available data, and the Schools Commission is currently engaged in an exercise in gathering that data for that purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that these schools are receiving basic grants. I said that they have had a cut in their basic grants. I acknowledge the figures that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan) has given. I am reassured that there has been a retrospective indexing to ensure that like money amounts are being compared with like money amounts with respect to 1981. I thank the Minister for that assurance. How can the Minister put to the Senate, even if these are the most recent available figures that can be used for this assessment, that the 1981 circumstances of schools will always be relevant to an assessment for 1984? Let us suppose that amongst, say, just the 41 schools that have suffered this cut, there were particular special circumstances in 1981, such as a decline in enrolments, such that the average of the resources privately available to those schools may in 1981 have been unusually high on the test that the Minister is applying for this purpose. In 1984, three years later, that back-dated material, even if it is the most recent available, would apply.

SPEECH.PARA: Should there not be a possibility for an independent school so penalised by that 25 per cent cut in its basic grant to be able to show the inappropriateness of a 1981 set of figures that the Minister is using to make decisions in respect of 1984? Should there not be provision for a school to be able to put the comparison of figures, substantiated and authenticated, with regard to 1982, 1983, and 1984, or to give whatever context, if it claims that 1981 was an unusual and inappropriate year, and that it is unfortunate that the Minister is using that year as the basis for her test. Should there not be provision for a school to be able to claim compensation, some waiving of the cut in its basic grant, when it can show that 1981 was a special and unusual case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: — The education guidelines which I published contained a provision which enabled schools which have had a drastic change of circumstances since 1981 to make an appeal to the Schools Commission on that basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to the votes for the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Senator Ryan): In view of the fact that Koongarra and Jabiluka, as we are very well aware, are not to proceed, what is the future of the surrounding area and the lease for Jabiluka from an environmental point of view. I speak of the area known as Kakadu II which, as I understand it, is not yet committed. I am interested, as are the people of the Northern Territory, to a quite considerable degree in knowing whether the Government will declare the Kakadu II area in its entirety a national park, locking in once and for all the many minerals in this highly mineralised area, or will it accede to the Northern Territory request that a conservation of not more than 50 per cent be declared for a predetermined period of a year to allow a stocktake of resources in the area?

SPEECH.PARA: This issue has been quite controversial. The area was put aside originally so that a land claim could be heard in regard to the matter. If I remember rightly, as a result of the Aboriginal land claim some 7 per cent of the area was recognised as being Aboriginal land. This area has now been left in abeyance. A considerable number of mineral surveys have taken place. It has been acknowledged that this is a very highly mineralised area, not only in uranium, but also in copper, gold and other minerals. There has been some effort by people interested in the mining industry to have an actual stocktake of this area so that the minerals there are recognised. Of course, there has also been the move to bring about the area's incorporation in Kakadu National Park. The Northern Territory Government has requested this conservation zone, but there is the fear that the Federal Government will take precipitate action which will once and for all make Kakadu II part of the National Park, an action which would cancel out those various moves to recognise the minerals in the ground in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that case, Mr Temporary Chairman, I suppose I had better put the questions formally on the record because the Committee may wish to pass the estimates now. The Minister can provide the answers later. I will go through the questions; they are in a lot of detail but I will be as brief as I can. I have been cast somewhat in the role of an enemy of the National Library because of my campaign for a proper role for the National Film Archive. I would like to make it clear at the outset that I respect and admire what the Library does and the valuable work it has done for the Film Archive in the past. The question is, though, whether the future of the Film Archive lies with the Library or with independence, and whether the Library is in fact capable of running the Film Archive satisfactorily.
—Senator Hamer, you mentioned that you would like to put these questions on the record, and that is what you are about to do. Are they in a form in which they could be incorporated?
—I am prepared to incorporate them.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point. I have not seen this list of questions but obviously the National Film Archive will be raised in Estimates committees. I would like Senator Hamer to make a judgment as to whether it might be an idea for all of us who want to ask questions on this matter to be acquainted with the questions.
—That is quite satisfactory. Perhaps it might be better not to incorporate them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I will read out the questions and be as brief as I can. The first question is: The departmental witness at the Estimates committee informed the committee that the amount allocated to the National Film Archive for 1983-84 was $315,000, which represented a percentage increase of 31 per cent over the previous year. It was stated at the Estimates committee on 16 September that this represented a greater increase in recent years than other sections, such as the sound recording section, the pictorial section, the national film lending collection or the general book collection. Two days later, one of the witnesses said in a Press statement:

SPEECH.PARA: A disproportionate amount of recent increases in the Library's total budget is being spent on the NFA in preference to other sections of the Library.

In fact, the written answer provided on 6 October indicated that the sound recording section had received a 35 per cent increase and the manuscript section had received a 36 per cent increase-that is, they were both ahead of the Film Archive in percentage terms. So what I would like to do is ask for some elaboration on the adequacy of the budget for the National Film Archive over the last five years. How does the increase in funding for the NFA over the last five years compare with the inflationary pressures on it? For instance, has the Budget increase taken into account the increasing costs of film copying and of film stock? In short, over the last five years what has been the real increase in the purchasing power available to the National Film Archive?

The second line of questioning is about the number of requests made to the NFA and whether they were or were not met by the existing staff. At the Estimates committee hearings witnesses were asked about the capability of the National Film Archive to deal adequately with these requests. In the written response on 6 October they listed the number of requests made since 1980 but did not indicate how many of these requests were dealt with adequately. A brief addendum to the figures indicated that between May and August of 1983, 60 per cent of requests were satisfied. I remark first that the Department did not provide all the information requested at the Estimates committee. What I would like, therefore, is the exact number of requests fulfilled in each year, which was asked for at the Estimates committee. With regard to the 60 per cent of requests satisfied over that brief period, what does that actually mean? Does it mean that 40 per cent of the requests were rejected, not satisfied or are still to be dealt with? And what does the 60 per cent satisfied mean? Does it mean the customers are entirely satisfied? I would like finally to ask in that area what proportion of the Archive staff time is devoted to handling these requests.

The next line of questioning is whether the staff of the National Film Archive were consulted before the Press release of 21 October which announced the lifting of certain access restrictions to use the NFA. Were the staff informed before or after the Press release? What is the number of full time staff at the present time? The figure of 10 as at June 1983, was given to the Estimates committee. Have additional staff been provided to handle the extra work load which will result from the lifting of restrictions, bearing in mind that the restrictions were imposed in the first place because of a shortage of staff? If the Archive does not have that extra staff, how will the present number of staff deal adequately with the increased access? Will the Minister explain to the Committee why the restrictions were imposed in the first place? In what way have conditions in the National Film Archive changed to make possible now, at a very dramatic moment, the lifting of restrictions?

On 16 September the departmental witnesses indicated that recommendations from the National Film Archive Advisory Committee, an organisation set up to advise the Council of the National Library on the development of the National Film Archive and to assist in liaison with the film industry and Archive users, had not been implemented, nor had they been rejected. I would first like to ask: are the recommendations in the 6 October answer a summary or a paraphrasing of what the Committee said and, if so, do they accurately convey the Committee's point of view? Did the Advisory Committee subsequently make further recommendations to the National Library and the National Library Council, especially on the question of the autonomy of the National Film Archive? If so, can copies of any of these recommendations be supplied to the Parliament? Does the written answer of 6 October accurately report the Committee's views as known to the Library at that time? Did the Advisory Committee submit a report to the Library Council for its meeting of 7 October on the Nicholas Clark inquiry? Can the Minister give any indication of the substance of that report of the National Library Council? Is the Minister aware of the recent resignation of distinguished film maker, Mrs Pat Lovell, from the Advisory Committee? Has the Library given the Minister a report on the allegations made by Mrs Lovell that the Advisory Committee was not being heeded by the Library Council, that none of its advice relating to the National Film Archive was accepted by the Library Council and that it was useless to serve on a committee which was not able to perform its brief to give advice to the Library Council on the development of the NFA? If the Library has not passed on a report on the resignation of Mrs Lovell, will the Minister seek a report on the matter and look into her allegations? What is the cost of the National Film Archive Advisory Committee to date? Can the Minister indicate whether any recommendations of the Advisory Committee have been accepted or implemented? I have a number of other detailed questions on the National Film Archive. To save the time of the Committee, as the questions are not of as much general interest as the earlier ones, I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The questions read as follows-

1. The Departmental witnesses at the Estimates Committee informed the Committee that the amount allocated to the National Film Archive (NFA) for 1983/84 was $ 315,000 which represented a percentage increase of 31% over the previous year. It was stated on 16 September by the Departmental witness that this represented a greater increase in recent years than other sections, such as the sound recording section, the pictorial section, the national film lending collection or the general book collection. Two days later, one of the witnesses said in a Press statement: 'A disproportionate amount of recent increases in the Library's total budget is being spent on the NFA in preference to other sections of the Library'. In fact, the written answers which were provided on 6 October indicated that Sound Recording had received a 35% increase and the Manuscript Section had received a 36% increase, i.e. both ahead of the Film Archive in percentage terms.
I would now like to ask for some elaboration of the adequacy of the budget for the National Film Archive over the last five years.
How does the increase in funding for the National Film Archive over the last five years compare with inflationary pressures on it?
For instance, has the Budget increases taken into account the increasing costs of film copying?
The increasing costs of film stock?
In short, over the last five years what has been the real increase in the purchasing power available to the National Film Archive?

2. On 16 September the Departmental witnesses were asked about the number of requests by the film industry to the National Film Archive and the capacity of the Archive to deal adequately with those requests. The written response on 6 October listed the number of requests made since 1980, but did not indicate the number of requests which were dealt with adequately. A brief addendum to the figures only indicated that between May and August of 1983 60% of requests were satisfied.
I first of all remark that the Department did not supply all the information required. I would therefore request that the exact number of requests fulfilled in each year might be supplied.

Further, I would like to comment on the figure of 60% of requests satisfied. What does that mean? Does it mean that 40% of the requests were rejected, not satisfied, or still to be dealt with in the future?
Were the 60% of the requests 'satisfied' dealt with in full? How many of the 60 % of requests obtained everything they asked for or reasonably required in the request?
What proportion of the Archive's staff time is devoted to the handling of these requests?

3. The Departmental witnesses indicated on 16 September that recommendations from the National Film Archive Advisory Committee, an organisation set up to advise the Council of the National Library on the development of the National Film Archive and to assist in liaison with the film industry and the users, had not actually been implemented, nor had any of its recommendations been rejected. The written response of 6 October includes recommendations made to the National Library Council in March 1983. (This is included in 6 October answers.)
I would first like to ask: Are the recommendations in the 6 October answer a summary or paraphrasing of what the Committee said, and if so, do they accurately convey the Committee's point of view?
Were these recommendations in March submitted in document form? If so, can a copy of the document be supplied to the Senate?

Has the Advisory Committee subsequently made further recommendations to the National Library and the National Library Council-especially on the question of autonomy for the National Film Archive? If so, can any copies of these recommendations be supplied to the Parliament?
Does the written answer of 6 October accurately report the Committee's views as known to the Library at that time?
Did the Advisory Committee submit a report to the Library Council for its meeting of 7 October on the Nicholas Clark inquiry?
Can the Minister give any indiction of the substance of that report to the Library Council?
Is the Minister aware of the recent resignation of Ms Patricia Lovell from the Advisory Committee?

Has the Library given the Minister a report on the allegations made by Ms Lovell that the Advisory Committee was not being heeded by the Library Council, that none of its advice relating to the National Film Archive had been accepted by the Library Council, and that it was useless to serve on a Committee which was not able to perform its brief to give advice to the Library Council on the development of the National Film Archive?

If the Library has not passed on a report on the resignation of Ms Lovell, will the Minister seek a report on this matter and look into the allegations of Ms Lovell concerning the role of the National Advisory Committee? What is the cost of the National Advisory Committee to date? Can the Minister indicate whether any recommendations of the Advisory Committee have now been accepted or implemented, i.e. since the Library Council meeting of 7 October?

4. The Estimates Committee requested the National Library to provide a list of organisations which were able to give submissions to the Nicholas Clark inquiry and the Library undertook to do so. No list was forthcoming and no reasons were given for the failure to provide the list of organisations invited to complete the questionnaire, or the list of organisations interviewed by telephone. In the written answer of 6 October, two organisations were cited by name, the Australian Film Institute and the Australian Screen Studies Association.
Will the Minister ask his Department to provide a list of those organisations which responded to the questionnaire and a list of those organisations interviewed by telephone?
Will the Minister provide the Parliament with a copy of the questionnaire which is claimed to cover a wide range of issues relating to film archive preservation , storage and access?

Will the Minister also provide the Senate with a sample of the telephone interviews, since there has been no information provided so far on the nature of the telephone interview with the 56 organisations?
Will the Minister also provide a list of the 'persons with special expertise and experience in film archiving' which were consulted by Nicholas Clark?
Can the Minister explain why a submission from the Australian Screen Studies Association was considered to be inappropriate 'at that time'?
Was this organisation contacted at a later stage for their views or recommendations?
If not, why not, when this body is widely representative of film teachers and academics and has made its own public statements-the future of the NFA?

Will the Minister explain the following statement by the Library: 'Since the consultants were not undertaking a public inquiry the question of soliciting or rejection of submissions does not arise'. What does it mean? Did the Library consider written submissions inappropriate to the inquiry, and if so, why?

The consultants assured the National Library that they were aware of and considered fully the widely published views of many organisations with an interest in film studies. Will the Minister supply a list of these organisations and a resume of the views referred to? i.e. the widely published views.

5. I refer to a recent National Library Kit which was circulated to all Members of Parliament and Senators. The covering letter from the Director-General of the National Library makes reference to the promotion of 'sectional interests' in regard to the separation of the National Film Archive from the National Library.
First, was the Minister informed of the circulation of this kit, before it took place?
Will the Minister identify the 'sectional interests' for the Senate?
Who are the people referred to in the letter?
In what way are they seeking to promote their own interest?
What evidence exists to support this?

Can the Library provide a second information Kit which contains more concrete evidence than its own press releases and an editorial from the Canberra Times- since editorials cannot be attributed to parlicular people or identified with ' sectional interests'?

6. In this same kit is the Minister aware that the National Library claimed that its current role is defined as 'custodian of the total record of Australian culture and development as expressed not only through books but through diverse collections of manuscripts, pictures, maps, sound recordings and films'?
Does the Minister agree that this is the current role of the National Library of Australia?

If so, why does the Library not control the National Gallery of Australia, the Australian War Memorial, the Australian Archives, the Parliamentary Library, the Museum of Australia, the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies, and other similar organisations which house the records of Australian culture and development?
7. Were the staff in the National Film Archive consulted before the press release of 21 October which announced the lifting of certain access restrictions to users of the National Film Archive?
Were the staff informed after the press release? If so, when were they informed ?

What is the number of full-time staff at the present time? The figure of 10 given to the Estimates Committee was for June 1983. Has additional staff been provided to handle the extra workload that will result from the lifting of restrictions?
If not, how will the present number of staff deal adequately with the increased access?
Will the Minister inform the Senate why the restrictions were imposed in the first place? In what way have conditions in the National Film Archive changed to allow this relaxation now?

8. The same press release of 21 October also indicates that access restrictions to television companies were claimed to have been lifted in September 1982. According to the Library's own Information Leaflet issued on 13 September 1982, television producers were informed that viewing prints in the Film Archive were accessible for all television programmes.
Will the Minister inform the Senate if other restrictions have been subsequently lifted also for television clients?
If so, what other restrictions have been lifted and what restrictions still apply to television clients?
9. What was the cost to the National Library of the Nicholas Clark Enquiry?
Was the Enquiry paid for before or after assessment of the Report by the National Film Archive, the National Advisory Committee and the National Library Council?
I note that the Report on the Enquiry by Nicholas Clark has been made available to the public, will the Minister inform the Senate of the response from the National Library to the Report?

10. I note with interest a recent National Library statement that over 2 million feet of film has been found by the National Film Archive in the course of The Last Film Search. This important project-regrettably of great urgency and even desperation because so much of our important early film production has been lost-deserves the support of all Australians and its success so far is very gratifying. The Search was conceived by staff members of the National Film Archive and has been made possible by the support of an impressive list of sponsors, most from within the film industry.
I would like to ask the Minister:
How much of the footage discovered in the Search has been copied and is accessible to Film Archive users?
How much of the footage is still to be copied?
How much of the remaining footage can be copied under the present budget limitations before the nitrate stock decomposes and the film is lost?
Is The Last Film Search operating on a large enough scale to ensure recovery of what is left of Australia's nitrate film?
What is the present state of progress with the preservation and copying of the Corrick collection from Tasmania?

The Library's statement of accounts in its 1981/82 annual report indicates that $58,000 was placed into The Last Film Search trust account during that year comprising sponsors' donations and instalments. Unlike the other trust accounts shown in the same report The Last Film Search funds appear to have earned no interest. Can this anomaly be explained?
Has the Library or the Government made any specific financial contribution to the Search over and above the money from sponsors?

11. Mr Hawke said on 26 September that the Government would give the National Film Archive 'some autonomy so that it can concentrate on what is a distinctly important task'. He also said that he did not think that a lot of money was involved because there is a certain allocation there now which has been operated through the Library and perhaps not as efficiently as it might be . . . We'll build more effectively on what is there'.
Will the Minister inform the Senate what Mr Hawke meant by 'some autonomy'?
Will the Minister also indicate what is meant by building more effectively on what is there?
Does that mean more money and more staff for the National Film Archive?
Is the Government in a position to allocate more money to the National Library and indicate specific areas in which that money is to be spent?

12. The National Library witnesses at the Senate Estimates Committee informed the Committee that they were aware of the resolutions concerning the National Film Archive passed at the Australian Film Institute's 'summit' on the Archive on 12 September. As Senators may know, these resolutions-which call for the separation of the National Film Archive from the National Library and make recommendations about the future structure, nature and funding of the Archive- have the support of a wide spectrum of film and television bodies and are at the centre of present public debate on the future of the Archive. At the Estimates Committee on 16 September, Senator Baume stressed the importance of Parliament receiving the Library's response to these recommendations. 'The resolutions are an important input into the public debate . . . and the response of the Library will be an equally important response'. Acting Director General, Mr Yates, confirmed acceptance of the need for the Library to make a public response.
I ask the Minister:
Has the Library responded to this request and made its views on the Australian Film Institute recommendations known to Parliament?
Has the Library made any public response to these recommendations?

13. The National Library announced on 7 October, following a meeting of the National Library Council, that the Nicholas Clark Report was now a public document. As such it joins the several earlier reports which have been done on the National Film Archive: I am thinking specifically of the Roger Easton report on video developments for the National Film Archive (last year), the Clyde Jeavons report (also last year), and earlier the Australian Film Commission Working Party report of 1980 and the Edmondson report of 1974.
I understand that the Easton report is still not a public document although the others are.
I ask the Minister:
Will the Library make the Easton report public?
What is the Library's public position on the recommendations of the other three earlier reports?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the subject of the National Film Archive I pay very particular tribute to the dogged work that Senator Hamer has been doing on this subject over a number of years. In recent years quite a number of questions have been raised at Estimates committee hearings in relation to it. This occurred well prior to the prominence that the National Film Archive now receives in the Press. I raise the matter of the resignation of Mrs Pat Lovell from the National Film Archive Advisory Committee. The issue that concerned me greatly was that in the statement on her resignation she said that the 18 months she had spent on the Committee had been a waste of her time as the National Library of Australia had ignored the Committee's advice and the Library 's governing Council never once met with members of the Committee. I have not met with the members of the governing Council of the National Library and, whilst I may have met with members of the Advisory Committee, I have not met them in that capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: Very clearly, the subject of the National Film Archive cannot be pushed aside much longer. I freely admit to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan) that one of the problems over a number of years has been one of financial neglect. However, what has never been clear to me in the inquiries I have made is just who shares in the responsibility for this financial neglect. For example, I have never been clear on what responsibility the National Library shares in that. It has been suggested that the Library did not see the Archive as a priority, did not push very hard for it and did not treat it as a priority. I think that some of the material Senator Hamer has covered this morning indicates that and I will not recanvass it.

I will say only this: In the interest that I have taken in the Archive in the last three or four years I have not had any communication from the National Library on the subject, apart from as a result of questions that have been asked at Estimates committee hearings. Now that the pressure has really built up on the subject of the National Film Archive-there is a suggestion that some alternative arrangement may be reached other than the Archive being administered by the National Library-all of a sudden there is a flurry of activity. The National Library has embarked on a campaign of persuading members of parliament that the Film Archive ought to be left with the National Library. Again, I do not want to recanvass or reiterate many of the points which were covered by Senator Hamer this morning. I merely say that I agree with him.

There have been a number of suggestions of alternatives as to what might happen with the Film Archive. One is that it should become an independent statutory authority. Another is that it remain part of the National Library, that it be relocated in another city and separately administered but that it come under the overall administration of the National Library. Another suggestion is that it might become part of the Australian Archives. It has also been suggested that the Archive be transferred to the Australian Film Commission. One suggestion that seems very popular with a number of people is that it be set up as an independent statutory authority.

From my discussions with people in the industry-a variety of views have been put to me-I discern that the issue of the shift from Canberra is not a major issue, although some people would like to make it one. They claim that most activity in the film industry takes place in Sydney and Melbourne and that there are problems, for example, in producers continually having to come to Canberra to get access to the film archives in support of their filming projects. But I gather that that is not a major issue. I would prefer not to get into the argument about whether the Archive should go to Sydney or Melbourne, as I am sure the Government would prefer not to get into the argument, if there is general satisfaction with its staying in Canberra. However, the matter of relocation, if that is the decision-I think it is propably a decision which the Government will have to come to-is another question.

There has been some opposition, on the basis of cost, to the Archives being a separate statutory authority. I am sure that in the options that are available that matter of cost will be investigated. There is some opposition also to the Film Archive being relocated with the Australian Film Commission. Some people see that the Film Commission's objectives are not the same as those other members of the film industry. There is some rivalry and jealousy there. However, what I think is very clear is that the Archive does have to come out of the National Library. In saying that I do not sweep the Library aside. Along with Senator Hamer, I agree that the National Library is an excellent institution. However, its record on the subject of film archives is not good. I do not see the logic of the case that the National Film Archive must remain with the National Library. There is a case for the Archives to be with the National Library, but that case is not overwhelming.

In conclusion, I say to the Minister that I understand advice on this matter has now gone to Cabinet. Over the last couple of months the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have made a number of statements holding out hope to the film industry that there will be some action on the subject of the National Film Archive. There have been promises that by this month those who have an interest in the subject will be told the outcome. Can the Minister confirm whether this matter is currently under Cabinet consideration? If so, when can we expect an announcement of the Cabinet's decision?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments concerning the subject that was raised, I think initially by Senator Hamer, and supported by Senator Martin. As a member of the National Library of Australia Council I certainly endorse the need for more finance to be provided to ensure that the National Film Archive is kept in a proper and appropriate state at all times. However, I disagree entirely with the concept of establishing another statutory authority. In Australia now we have too many statutory authorities requiring too much finance and too many people to man them efficiently and effectively. I endorse the need for more money to be provided to the National Library so that it can do the job more effectively. The National Library Council believes it is important that collections of films and other collections be under the umbrella of the National Library. There are very good reasons why those collections should come under that umbrella. I am certainly not disparaging the interest displayed by Senator Hamer and Senator Martin in this matter. However, I think the National Library needs a greater financial capacity if it is to do its job more effectively than perhaps it has been able to do because of economic difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that we should seek to proliferate the number of statutory authorities in Australia. I think the National Film Archive ought to be in the national capital. It is most important that it remain here because of its national interest to the people of Australia. With those words, I support the concern expressed by my colleagues. However, I certainly do not support the way in which they would like to give effect to their concern so that appropriate care can be taken of this important matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment very briefly on this subject. Senator Jessop came into the chamber during the debate. He may well have heard most of it but he may not have heard the comments that I made about cost. Perhaps Senator Jessop one of these days can indicate to us how he feels about the independent administration of the National Library and its governing council, of which he is a member and whether there might be a better administrative arrangement for the Library, other than an independent authority, which might save money. I am not an advocate, right, left and centre, of other authorities. What I said was that undoubtedly the Minister will get advice on what the additional cost would be and that will be a consideration in any decision that is made. I am not seriously suggesting that the National Library ought to be administered by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. I accept that there is a good reason for it being administered the way it is. There are occasions on which there are good reasons for such an arrangement. Therefore, I would not want the measured consideration of whether an independent authority might administer the Film Archive to be swept aside on the grounds that we have too many authorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer again briefly to the environmental aspect of Kakadu and to make a brief statement. As I was saying a few minutes ago, the future ownership of Kakadu II and the various mining leases is a vexed question. There is concern that, now that Jabiluka and Koongarra are not to go ahead, there will be moves by the Federal Government to ensure that once and for all these areas will never come into production. As I understand it, some of the Jabiluka land is owned by the Northern Territory. Therefore, it would be difficult for the Government to proclaim it as a national park. The lease would still exist even if the site were proclaimed. It would be easier to incorporate Koongarra into Kakadu I as there is no Northern Territory land involved. However a proclamation would be needed to change the original park boundaries and have that area included. Mining of the area would not be negated if both projects were incorporated in the park. When the plans for the park were first drawn up it was agreed that mining would be allowed within the park.

SPEECH.PARA: We must take into consideration the views of the owners of the land. The traditional Aboriginal people would not react favourably to a government which negated their wishes. This view has been stated very plainly over the last few months and has been re-stated by the Chairman of the Northern Land Council, Mr Gularrwuy Yunupingu, who has just been elected, and the previous Chairman, Gerry Blitner. It appears that the Federal Government hopes that by including Jabiluka and Koongarra in the proclamation of a national park it will be more difficult for mining to be undertaken. I would not think that this would be necessarily so . I am merely pointing out once again that the claims of the Aboriginal people in respect of Jabiluka and Koongarra must be recognised. I hope that this point of view is taken into consideration in the action that obviously the Federal Government is now considering.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I ask Senator Kilgariff to comment on what area of the national park--

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I do not wish to interfere with the rights of honourable senators to question items before the Committee. However, debates between members of the Opposition seem to me a little inappropriate at this stage.

—They are generally more intelligent, Mr Temporary Chairman. However, I ask the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) a question which arises out of what was said by Senator Kilgariff. What area of the total Kakadu National Park is represented by the lease areas that have been granted to the various mining companies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jessop was not here earlier when Senator Kilgariff asked a number of detailed questions in respect of which I have undertaken to get answers. I can amplify a little what I told Senator Kilgariff earlier in regard to the Government's intentions for declaring stage II of Kakadu National Park. The Cabinet submission relating to this matter is lodged and awaiting consideration. Obviously, until it has been considered by Cabinet and a decision taken, a detailed response will not be forthcoming.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Martin's comments about the National Film Archive have been taken on board. She will be aware that the matter will involve a policy decision by the Government and, again, that is expected shortly. The Minister responsible, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen), will visit the National Library tomorrow specifically to see the National Film Archive for himself and to inform himself on the pros and cons of the case. So I think we can expect a government decision on the future of the National Film Archive, which has been guaranteed by the Government in one place or another, in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) for agreeing to provide at some future time information in regard to the area involved in mining leases in the park area. I think she will find it is probably less than 2 per cent-probably a little bit more than 1 per cent-of the total area. This will give the Committee an idea that the area is not very great. However, I look forward to confirmation of that. While I am on my feet I would like to comment on the statement made by Senator Martin in respect of the National Film Archive. I suggest that there is some lack of communication between the National Library Council and people interested in this important subject.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I would really like your clarification as to whether this debate between two members of the Opposition is an appropriate way to pursue the Committee consideration at this stage.
—The Chair gives some latitude in appropriation debates, which range far and wide. There is no point of order.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. Will you rule whether it is appropriate for members of the Opposition to direct questions to each other rather than to the Minister involved in the proceedings?
—I understood that it was not a question, that Senator Jessop was commenting on something that had been said. That practice has been followed in previous debates.

—I just want to suggest to anyone interested, including the Minister at the table, that it would be quite in order for an invitation to be extended to anybody interested to come along to a future meeting of the National Library Council to determine whether proper lines of communication are established with respect to this subject. I notice that a fellow member of the National Library Council is sitting on the Minister's left. I am sure that he would agree that all members of the Council, including the Director-General, would welcome an opportunity to explain the difficulties and the problems associated with this subject. I am sure that everyone would be more enlightened. Probably this would assist in providing the National Library with more funds so that we can make certain that the National Film Archive is looked after in an appropriate manner.
—To save the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs time I simply indicate to her that I will explain to Senator Jessop just what was my complaint about the National Library's governing council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a comment on this matter. I think we should not lose sight of the fact that the National Library started the film collection, without which we might not have anything to talk about today. I must say that in a sense I think I have a personal deeper interest in the sound tapes and record section. I hope that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) will see that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) visits that section as well when he is there tomorrow. There are certainly some very interesting things in it.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that we need to make sure that money is identified for these collections so that they can be looked after properly.
