I think we need to be careful that we do not take a decision that means that more money is spent on the administrative arrangements when in fact it is needed for the actual preservation of records. I guess that means that the Library should keep the general overall control, but the collections need to be in separate departments of the Library. I want to see them in a separate building. I understand that this is possible, that there are long term plans for two more annexes in front of the Library. I hope that one of them, at least, on the ground floor, will be for the film and sound sections so that they can have a real shop front for tourists, and display things that ought to be on display for visitors to see. I would like to see a section where people can buy copies of old records and speeches and things of that nature and see the exhibits that can be displayed there. That perhaps is a little further into the future. But the buildings are identified on National Capital Development Commission maps and it is certainly my hope that at least one of them will house, at ground floor level, the best of these things to be seen by the public. There can be absolutely no doubt that if there is any discussion whatever about where these collections should be, the national capital must be their home. That is the very reason for our existence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask some specific questions about the National Film Archive. They relate to the Corrick collection of films, an historically unique and culturally significant collection, acknowledged by successive governments to fall into that category. It dates from as early as 1903. It was the subject of an agreement between the present owner, Mr John Corrick of Launceston and his family, and the Government. That agreement dates back to 1977. There was an agreement for the copying of the collection onto acetate stock for preservation but, as has been acknowledged by the present Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) that work has ground to a halt. I quote from his letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The Corrick Collection is a group of over 100 nitrate films unique in Australia because it is the surviving 'stock in trade' of a travelling entertainment troupe from the early years of this century and is a time capsule of the films widely shown to Australia audiences at the time. Indeed, no other similar collections are known to exist in any other country.

The arrangement whereby the Corrick Collection was to be progressively acquired by the National Film Archive, copied for preservation onto acetate stock and a proportion of the footage returned to Mr Corrick in the form of 16 mm prints, was begun in 1977. It gradually slowed to a halt because of the increasingly heavy demands on the Archive's small preservation staff, which has a huge backlog of urgent nitrate copying to cope with.
He goes on to say:
Copying of the Corrick Collection will be resumed in the near future.

That letter was written on 11 August. I ask the Minister whether he can indicate anything further in relation to steps being taken to provide in particular for the preservation of what is acknowledged, I think by everybody, to be a unique collection, in urgent need of preservation. The present custodian, Mr Corrick, is extremely concerned about the rate of deterioration. I hope that the resumption of the copying will be undertaken in the very near future and that the Minister will have some encouraging information in relation to that matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any specific information in relation to this matter, only to say that the Corrick collection is not the only collection of old nitrate film awaiting copying. Of course, the problems of the Corrick collection are problems of inadequate funding, as is the whole problem of the National Film Archive to date. I will make sure that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) is made aware of Senator Rae's concern about this collection.
— Could the Minister obtain from the Minister she represents some specific response to the question? There has been correspondence. I wanted to take the matter a little further.
—Certainly.
—The Minister indicates yes. I thank her very much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the appropriations for the Australia Council. The disbursement of the appropriation to the Australia Council has become an issue of controversy in recent days. Yesterday in the Senate I asked the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) a question relating to this matter. In reply she said that she had not seen certain reports and allegations to which I referred in my question. I appreciate that the Minister has been overseas and that the issue arose in the latter days of her time overseas but perhaps by now she has acquainted herself with a number of these reports and allegations. The first one to which I refer comes from a report printed in the National Times dated 4-10 November under the headline ' '' Climate of doubt'' clouds Australia Council's future'. There is reference to a number of issues in that item. There is also reference to the manner in which the Australia Council received some pressure in the allocation of the arts grant that is under its power of disbursement for this year. A number of issues are raised in this article and a number of things indicated.

SPEECH.PARA: On 8 November, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment received a question in the House of Representatives in relation to Australia Council funding and some other matters and he made some statements. I will refer to that again in a minute. The allegations which are made in the article in the National Times, named certain people, a Mr Sergio Sergi, who is on the Minister's staff, and a Mr Galvin, who is a member of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, as having expressed certain views, said certain things and done certain things. Whilst the Minister took the opportunity to make some denials in his response to the question in the House of Representatives on Tuesday, there has not to my knowledge been any denial of the substance of this article in relation to these other people.

One of the issues is whether the Australia Council will continue in its present role. A study group is due to report to a meeting of State and Federal Ministers shortly on the subjects of arts funding in Australia. It is known, and it is acknowledged in this article, that a proposal is being promoted by the Victorian Minister for the Arts, Mr Race Mathews on this subject. The article states:

Cohen was not available for comment this week but his adviser, Sergio Sergi, said that administrative changes in arts funding 'could well be put through Cabinet before the next budget'. He indicated--
that is, Mr Sergi, a member of the Minister's staff-
approval for a proposal by the Victorian Minister for the Arts, Race Mathews, that less money should be given to the Australia Council and more in direct grants to the States.

There has been no suggestion, before or since, that Mr Sergi did this on behalf of the Minister, but, as I have said, I am unaware of any denial or disclaimer. Therefore one takes it that the Minister supports the proposal by the Victorian Minister for the Arts that the method of disbursement of money spent on the arts by the Commonwealth Government be changed, so that more money goes directly to the States.

A further assertion in this article relates to the independence of the Australia Council and feelings that the Minister is alleged to have on this matter. I believe the Minister's statements before and since this article bear out the allegation. I will refer to them later. The article states:

From the start Cohen admitted that he had few developed ideas on arts policy but in a recent speech he declared that he was uneasy about large sums of money being spent without the involvement of the minister responsible to the Parliament.

That, of course, raises the whole issue of the role of the Australia Council and the role it has played and has been expected to play on the subject of the disbursement of its allocation in the Budget each year.

I referred, in my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment yesterday, to a letter written by the Minister. I believe she indicated that she was unaware of this letter. She might have had time to check on it since. The article continues:

In September the council met to allocate Budget funds. The Government increased the council funds by 14 per cent but, in a letter to the council, Cohen stressed the importance of distributing the money in a way which would reflect the ALP's policy on community arts.
Further on the article continues:
Galvin-
that is Mr Pat Galvin-
and the other ministerial appointee,-
that is, appointee to the Australia Council-
the new Chairman of the Public Service Board, Peter Wilenski, argued strongly against the recommendation-
that is of the Australia Council-

Throughout a two-day meeting, Galvin stressed Cohen's letter and Government policy. In the end, the Community Arts Board was voted a larger increase than intended. There was resentment among some council members who saw Galvin's role as Government interference.

Whether or not one chooses to use the word 'interference' it was certainly Government influence on the Australia Council. Having previously determined a recommendation, the Australia Council changed its mind clearly under representations from Mr Galvin, a Government appointee to the Australia Council. Further, the article claims that Mr Galvin was:
. . . promoting a change in the Australia Council Act in which the minister would have more control over the council.
At the end of the article there is an indication of why the Minister might like to have more control over the Council. It states:
At the AFI awards,-
that is, the Australian Film Institute Awards-

Cohen approached a group, including John Hawke and said that he was embarrassed the Community Arts Board had failed to fund a NSW Trades and Labour Council project which had been rejected because insufficient had been done in previous years.
The journalist then makes the comment:

It must be frustrating for Cohen not to be able to fund his own pet projects. Last week he flew a kite. He may find that his choice lies between having the power to fund those projects and having the support of the arts community.

Subsequently, Dr Timothy Pascoe, the Chairman of the Australia Council, resigned from the Chairmanship of the joint Commonwealth-State study group in order, as he said, to put the views of the Australia Council independently. Apparently he found some conflict of interest in being Chairman of the Australia Council and Chairman of the study group. He issued a statement in which he said:
I have resigned in order to be free to advocate publicly and actively the principles enshrined in the Australia Council Act.
In his statement he enunciated the principles of distribution or funding of the arts at the Commonwealth level. They are, he said:

First absolute statutory independence from political influence or involvement in grant decisions. Second, program policy in grant decisions made by peer groups of artists and other community representatives. Third, the need for policy formulation to flow from grant-giving experience and equally the need for a capacity to implement policy through funding.
At the end of his statement he referred to those artists who expressed dismay at the prospect of diminished Australia Council independence. He states:
The Council is approaching the Minister urgently seeking the Government's reaffirmation of these principles.

I do not raise the subject to canvass the issue of Dr Pascoe's resignation from that position. He made his position clear that he felt it was necessary, as Chairman of the Australia Council, to do that. I raise, instead, the general issues of the Government's intentions. The Government's intention, as indicated and not denied-in fact it has clearly been borne out by some statements of the Minister-is to funnel more money to the States and less money through the Australia Council, and to give the Australia Council certain instructions.

We have debated the issue of funding of the arts under Estimates here for the last few years. We debated the matter of whether the Australian Opera and the Australian Ballet should come under the Australia Council. Now because of a decision of this Government, they do. We have debated whether, if the Government has special projects, it ought to give special money for them. I instance a debate that took place in the Senate a couple of years ago about a grant from the Fraser Government to the Commonwealth Arts Festival which was held to coincide with the Commonwealth Games in 1982. It is always open to the Government to make decisions to spend money in particular areas and to allocate certain funds additional to the money given to the Australia Council for a specific purpose as was the case with the Commonwealth Arts Festival. It is open to this Government, if it does not like the recommendations and decisions of the Australia Council, to put additional money into its own pet project areas. If the Minister wants more money given to the community arts, then it is open to the Government to decide the amount of money to be allocated for the Australia Council and then to say 'Here is an additional amount of money for community arts funding'. The Government could perhaps ask the Australia Council for advice on distribution of the additional money, it could decline to ask the Australia Council for advice and just fund its pet projects.

I give a caution to the Government. It would be, I believe, a great pity indeed if the Commonwealth Government were ever to depart from those principles enunciated by Dr Pascoe in his statement of resignation from the study group. The State governments now, largely as a response to Commonwealth Government initiatives in setting up the Australia Council, also put a substantial amount of money into the arts. It approximately equals the amount of money that the Commonwealth Government spends. A lot of that money is very well and wisely spent. But nobody could deny that some arts funding under the State Governments is a pork barrelling exercise. Grants are given and projects are undertaken which are clearly political pork barrelling. The reference given in the National Times article to some pet project of the New South Wales Trades and Labor Council would come into that category. It may be a very worthwhile one. However, a peer group assessment looking at all the applications for funds, Australia- wide in this case, decided that it was not superior to the other applications for funding. To turn around then and to give money to it is to do it a favour. That is not to accept the advice of the specialist group. I say to the Government: 'Do that if you want to but do not do it out of Australia Council funds'.

I implore the Government not to pursue one line that has been suggested, that all the money that is given to the Australia Council be enough for the so-called flagship companies such as the Opera, the Ballet and the Elizabethan Theatre Trust and a few other major companies and that all the real decision making in the detailed applications and the many grants that are given each year be made by State governments.

Without a doubt, the Australia Council has set a very high standard of objectivity and independence. One may not agree with every last decision, but it has set a high standard of objectivity and independence. It has very strong support from the arts community in Australia. I believe it would be a tragedy for the arts if funding were changed so that only major companies were to be funded through the Australia Council, or else by Government giving specific instructions to the Australia Council on its regular recurring grant as to how that grant was to be spent. The recent actions of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs who represents the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment are without procedural parallel in the last 10 years. It is not surprising that the arts community is more than disturbed; it is extremely upset. Frankly it is of a piece with some other Government actions on policy.

The Minister, Senator Ryan, was shadow Minister for the arts when the present Government was in Opposition. She showed a keen concern for the arts. I am sure she still has the best wishes of the arts at heart. I hope that whatever role she can play in this it will be to keep the arts as independent as possible. As shadow Minister she stated that the then Opposition wanted to see money go to community arts and so on. Perhaps she could take the policy that she announced through to Cabinet and allow for special funding providing for those special areas that the Minister rates so highly. I am interested in Senator Ryan's response on the Government's policy attitudes towards the Australia Council. Perhaps now she may be able to answer some of the specifics that I raised both in Question Time yesterday and today in the Estimates debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —To the extent that Senator Martin's remarks constituted her views on how the Australia Council should be operated, I have no comment to make . However, with regard to her suggestion based on a National Times article that there has been a change in government policy with regard to funding and administration of the Australia Council, that is quite wrong. There has been no change, and any inference that Senator Martin has drawn from the National Times article to that effect is wrong. There has been no change in government policy. If there were to be a change in government policy that would come about as a result of a Cabinet deliberation and a Caucus deliberation and the various other procedures that this Government goes through before changing a policy, and it would be announced then, after those procedures had been gone through by the Minister. It certainly would not be announced by any staff person or take the form of a report in a newspaper of a comment that a staff person is alleged to have made. So I think Senator Martin can be reassured that there has been no change in the Government's approach to the administration of funding of the Australia Council.

SPEECH.PARA: As to allegations of pressure being put on the Australia Council to make a particular funding, I am informed by officers that such allegations are unfounded, if it is implied that they came from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen). It is a fact that Mr Pat Galvin, a member of the Council, exercised his right to advise the Australia Council of the Government's policies in relation to the funding of community arts, and in due course, having taken that advice into account along with the other matters that the Council would take into account on these occasions, the Council has made its decision. The other specific comment I have to make concerns the arts funding study group, about which Senator Martin has expressed an interest. There is to be a meeting of cultural Ministers here in Canberra on 18 November, next Friday, to consider, inter alia, the report of the arts funding study group, at which stage, of course, the Federal Minister will make, I am sure, a public statement with regard to the Government's response to that study group.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Facts are facts and people can draw their own conclusions. Yesterday and again today I referred to a letter which the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) wrote, which was referred to in the National Times article but which Senator Ryan has not mentioned in response. I reiterate:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in a letter to the council, Cohen stressed the importance of distributing the money in a way which would reflect the ALP's policy on community arts.

People will decide whether that is pressure or not. It is pretty clearly an indication from the Minister of what he expects the Council to do. That is one matter at issue, one that I raised yesterday and again today, to which Senator Ryan has not responded. I can accept one version of the claim that the Government has not changed its policy because I searched through the Government' s policy statements on the arts and nowhere did I find the words that the present role of the Australia Council would remain intact or continue unchanged or that its independence would be guaranteed. Those words are not there. That might just be coincidental, but if these words are deliberately left out, the Minister is saying that the independence of the Australia Council is not assured . The point I make is that there has been a tradition built up, which was stated by Dr Pascoe in his resignation and by me here earlier today in debate, on the role of the Australia Council. There are three principles. The first is: Statutory independence from political influence or involvement in grant decisions. Senator Ryan should address her comments on the subject to Mr Cohen's letter. The second is: Program policy and grant decisions made by peer groups of artists and other community representatives. Now the funding of the favourite projects of politicians does not come into that category. The third is: Policy formulation to flow from grant giving experience. The Australia Council has built up an experience which it uses in applying the funds. It is quite possible that as a result of its experience some recommendations might be made about different types of funding and presumably this study group is searching that out . But that is an important principle.
I draw the Minister's attention to the words of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment when he says:

When we became the Government I made it clear that I saw the role of the Australia Council as being to implement the guidelines of the Government's policy which were specifically to have greater access for the community and greater participation.
There is a little more about that. He continues:
As well . . . we wanted an extension of the community crafts program--
The Government is quite entitled to want those things. The Minister said:
. . . I am sure honourable members will accept the fact that it is its responsibility--
that is the Australia Council-
to undertake to follow the guidelines set down by the Government and not to go its own way.

Now going its own way, according to Dr Pascoe, is applying those three principles which have applied to arts funding in Australia for some time, but apparently not giving a priority that pleases the Minister to community arts out of its total allocation is going its own way. There is a conflict arising in the public arena between what has been and what is perceived to be the Australia Council's role, and the words of the Minister and the intentions of the Minister . I say to the Minister representing: It is entirely within my right and the right of any honourable senator to question her about future directions of government policy. Here today we are looking at the vote for the Australia Council and the vote for the arts. The Australia Council has had the right as an independent statutory body to disburse under certain headings: Literature, theatre, whatever. That has been its right. What is clearly coming out in the last few days is an indication that it will no longer have that right. If that is so, it is an issue of public debate and it is quite proper that it be debated here and that it be debated in the context of the Australia Council's estimates. I am just not going to accept the brush off from the Minister representing that I will be told when the Government has made its decision. Is the rest of the world going to be told when the Government has made its decision and told to get lost in the meantime; the Government will not make any comment? People within the Parliament and outside it have a right to know. I point out to the Minister, because she may not be aware of this, the words of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment in a speech at a community theatre conference in Adelaide last Friday:
I believe that the elected government in the Parliament should not be denied its say on issues affecting cultural life and, in the end, the right to set the priorities.

Now Mr Cohen is entitled to believe that. The Government is entitled to implement it, but I point out that if it does, that is a change of policy in relation to the Australia Council. It is a change, and people are entitled to know. The Minister is indicating that his opinion is in favour of a change, a change to set the priorities for the Australia Council. The Minister representing him cannot deny that. We seek an indication here under the matter of the funding of the Australia Council for the next year of whether the Government has intentions to change the statutory authority and independence of the Australia Council.

I shall read again some words that I read earlier, and I hope the Minister will take note of them. Mr Sergi is quoted as stating that administrative changes in arts funding 'could well be put through Cabinet before the next budget'. I am not prepared to wait until the date of the next Budget to find out just whether that is the direction we are moving in, whether a curtain is apparently lifted on Budget night and all is revealed-as Senator Gareth Evans is fond of saying in answer to questions here. We are entitled to know, and the Government, one would think, would be interested to know people's opinions so that it can formulate wise policy. If it is not interested in people's opinions on how the arts in Australia should be funded it is a very ominous sign indeed for its intention towards whether the arts will be funded on merit or according to the Government' s personal preferences, whatever they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not satisfied that the Minister is treating the debate in the Committee seriously. I can say only that the Opposition will continue to raise the questions that Senator Martin has raised to ensure that we get adequate answers in the Committee on matters that are rightly the concern of the Committee. Whilst it is not the policy of the Opposition to block Appropriation Bills, the Government should not feel that it is let off the hook when it does not give adequate answers. The Government will hear more of this until there is a proper explanation of the matters that Senator Martin has raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Teague for his support. Mr Temporary Chairman, last night in the Senate the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, when dealing with Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1983-84, adopted a particular tactic. Some questions had been addressed to him by Senator Walters. When she had finished asking those questions the Minister for Resources and Energy sat mum. When Senator Walters attempted to rise to her feet to ask the Minister whether he was going to answer the questions-and it is without precedent that Ministers just sit in silence and treat questions that way- Senator Walsh raised a point of order. He said that since Senator Walters had sat down after finishing her question she had finished her speech and could not speak again. By sitting silently the Minister attempted to avoid answering the question. He then had the cheek to attempt to stop Senator Walters asking him whether he was going to answer the question. If she had not sat down he would have used the fact that she was still on her feet as an excuse not to answer the question.

SPEECH.PARA: I have addressed a number of questions in two contributions to this debate. The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) gave some answer to some of the questions in her first response. I reiterated a number of questions that she did not answer in her first response. The Minister is now pursuing the same tactic as Senator Walsh did last night-she sits mum. If it had not been for the fact that Senator Teague intervened in support of what I had said, the Minister could have continued to sit mum, and, the Government would like to suggest, I would not have had the right to speak again on this issue. That is not good enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the situation is clarified by the Standing Orders. An honourable senator has a right to a second speech if no one else rises at the end of the first speech. I did not hear the point of order put to the Chair last night-I was not in the chair at the time-but I believe that it had no basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (11.53)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am not unwilling to respond on behalf of the Government to questions that are asked. But I interpreted Senator Martin's contribution as a speech about her views on the Australia Council. I do not accept her interpretation of the fact that Mr Cohen wrote to the Australia Council informing it of the Government's policies in the area of cultural affairs as being pressure. I am informed that it has been the practice of successive Ministers to inform the Council of the policies of the government on cultural affairs. It is entirely proper that Mr Cohen should do so. Senator Martin repeats the National Times report that Mr Sergio Sergi said this or that. I have told Senator Martin that government policy is not announced in a National Times report attributing remarks to a particular staff member.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been no change of policy. There has been no moving away from the view that the Australia Council ought to be independent. If there were to be a change of policy I have advised Senator Martin in the Senate of how the Opposition would be informed of that. But there has been no such change of policy. I have also pointed out to Senator Martin that the meeting of cultural Ministers on 18 November will, I expect, be followed by a comprehensive statement by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen). There is simply no factual information to give in response to Senator Martin's interpretations of a number of events.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: -I raise the matter of the Australian Opera and the lack of Federal grants to State opera companies. I think the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) will confirm that at this stage last year careful and sharp questions were raised about the Australian Opera's performances being excluded from Western Australia and South Australia, concentrated as they are in Sydney. It is further the case that some proportion of Federal Government money granted to the Australia Council does not go to State opera companies. For example, I have a letter dated 25 October from one constituent complaining about this situation and stating:

SPEECH.PARA: As a supporter of the State Opera,
that is, the South Australian State Opera-

I am disturbed to learn that for the year 1983/84, no portion of funds granted by the Federal Government to the Australia Council's Music Board will be allocated to the State Opera of South Australia.

I understand that funds will be allocated to the Australian Opera, but as that Company does not visit South Australia, little benefit accrues to the people of this State. This means that the funding of opera in South Australia is borne by the local company and the South Australian Government.
This situation I consider unfair, as all taxpayers contribute to Federal taxes, and accordingly, some portion of the funds made available for opera should be allocated to State companies.

Another constituent wrote to me on 3 November quite independently. He raises the same point but adds a contention that I have raised in the past during Estimate committee hearings and in this chamber; that is, that perhaps we are coming to a situation where the titles 'Australian Opera' and 'Australian Ballet' are misnomers and that they might more correctly be called the 'Sydney Opera' and the 'Melbourne Ballet'. I am not fundamentally opposed to there being excellence in a particular place in Australia-in Sydney or, in the case of ballet, in Melbourne. But let us understand what we are doing in terms of the distribution of Federal moneys which are raised alike from all States.
The second constituent writes:

I've just been to the Magic Flute (done by the State Opera Co.) and thoroughly enjoyed it; we'll probably subscribe next year. In the programme they had an indignant note to the effect that the Federal Government grant to the Australian Opera Co. had just been raised, although 'Australian' is a misnomer since they don't visit every state, whereas the State Opera Co. gets only local support. I imagine that this situation may be an accidental carry-over from the days when the Australian Opera Co. travelled more widely . . . Without wishing to seem too parochial, it does seem to me that the Federal aid to opera companies should be split up in proportion to services rendered, so that if we have 10% of the population and/or taxation revenue (or whatever the correct figures are) and the State Opera provides 100% of our opera (as they do), they should get 10% of the Federal Government aid to opera.

A year ago, on 7 September, during an Estimates committee hearing Senator Ryan, then in opposition and a member of that Estimates Committee, Senator Martin, Senator Haines and I closely examined these kinds of questions. Mr Veitch, the General Manager of the Australian Opera, was present, as was the Minister then representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Senator Peter Baume. He gave a number of answers, to which I will briefly refer. At the conclusion of our discussion, our questions answers, in the Estimates Committee hearing, I said:
. . . my concluding comment would be that members of the Parliament would protest to the Board of the Australian Opera about this.
I was referring to the concentration of the opera in Sydney and to some extent Melbourne, Canberra and Brisbane. I further stated:

However constrained, the decision was to deny a State access to a national institution of such importance as the Australian Opera. Whether or not that leads to further debate in the Senate is to be seen.

This is the further debate that I foreshadowed then. I note that for South Australians to gain from the Federal grants to the Australian Opera they need to go to Sydney. Mr Veitch indicated that for 1983 there were 163 performances in Sydney, 36 in Melbourne, 13 in Brisbane and nine in Canberra. No local contribution was made by Canberra towards those performances. The costs were borne entirely by the Australian Council, whereas State contributions were made by Victoria, Queensland and New South Wales, I understand, with regard to performances in Melbourne, Brisbane and Sydney. Mr Veitch explained-he gave a vary rational explanation and I do not in any way criticise his bona fides in speaking on behalf of the Australian Opera-that the Opera has a limited budget and needs to use it in a rational and intelligent way. He said:
The Opera Board remains committed to performing in capitals other than Sydney to the extent that it is financially responsible, but we cannot take actions that add to that accumlated deficit.
He was referring to the then current deficit of $1.3m. He continued:

The incremental cost of touring to Adelaide in the current year-we did the figures-was $181,000 deficit. That's just the incrementals costs of income and expenses. We had asked for half of that as assistance from the State but it was not able to provide it.

In the earlier period the State Government had provided $85,000 towards the Australian Opera's costs. For the year 1983 such money was not forthcoming from the State. I understand that that is something of an argument for discontinuation of performances in Adelaide. It still does not meet the point that a trend is emerging for performances of the Australian Opera to be concentrated all the more in Sydney. South Australia is missing out, as the protests of constituents which I have mentioned have indicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am with you. I am with you all the way.

—Senator Tate interjects that Tasmania also is missing out. Western Australia too is missing out. We have a situation in which taxpayers in the smaller States are becoming increasingly dissatisfied. We contribute alike to the Australia Council, an important Australian performing arts body, but no benefit is being derived by the smaller States. We have several options. One is to increase the money that goes from the Federal Government to the Australian Opera so that it can be assured of being able to go to the smaller States. Another option is to face the fact of the trends in recent years and say: 'We will rename the Australian Opera, which is based in Sydney and call it the Sydney opera company. We will make compensating payments to the State opera in South Australia'. It would then be comparable to the Sydney opera company based at the Sydney Opera House. There is some substance in the point raised by the General Manager of the Australian Opera, Mr Veitch, that there has been a lack of State subsidies for the Australia Council in the last decade, but the decision of the States ought to be taken into account. The States prefer to give support to their own State opera companies. We should be able to expect that the money granted to the Australia Council will be more fairly distributed so that existing State opera companies will receive appropriate and proportional financial support through that council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question raised by Senator Teague the point can be made, of course, that at worst he is talking in a parochial manner. However, he examined the broad aspects of the need for the Australian Opera Company to be accessible to people wherever they live in Australia. That is not a concept with which the Government has any quarrel. In fact, not only the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) but also the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have on many occasions said that our opera, culture and art generally should be accessible to all people throughout the Commonwealth. I am sure that Senator Teague appreciates that Australia is a very large continent. We have a commitment to meet that objective. Obviously it can be done only on the basis of additional funding and more planning. Accessibility is a dominant factor in the way in which these organisations operate.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure Senator Teague will appreciate that the Australia Council is an independent body. It makes its own decisions, independently of government. All the Government can do is to provide it with resources that are essential for it to carry out that wider function that we all support. To that extent, of course, some States may be able to assist in that process more than can other States. It is clear that people who live in popular centres like Sydney are able to have access to a lot of these important cultural pursuits-more so than people living in outlying areas or even the smaller States. I think the best we can do is to take on board the comments made by the honourable senator. In its broadest context, it is a view that we all share. However, it can only be referred to the Council itself for consideration.

I hope that in due course, given the resources necessary, the wishes of Senator Teague and, I am sure, of the Government will be realised in the wider context of extending what is an important part of our cultural life to an ever- increasing number of Australian citizens. Even if one accepts the criticism that the Australian Opera Company, in Sydney gets a larger share of funds than it should, people at Broken Hill, Tumbarumba, Casino and in the rest of New South Wales are disadvantaged to that extent. Let me assure the Senate that the Government is committed, in a philosophical sense-to the extent that funds become available-to realising in a purposeful way the objectives that have been suggested. I do not think the Government would disagree substantially with the views that have been expressed by Senator Teague other than to say it hopes that the comments he has made will be taken into consideration by the Australia Council, an independent body, when it is in a position in subsequent years to plan a more extensive itinerary for the Australian Opera.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the response of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) to Senator Teague. I simply want to supplement it by referring to a particular case which I think is helpful, as Senator Teague's example was. I refer to the Sydney City Ballet which, over a period of two weeks recently in Tasmania, performed in many towns and cities around the State to full houses. It gave tremendous pleasure and created an awareness of that particular form of dance and an appreciation of it right throughout the Tasmanian community. It was extremely well received. But over a period of two or three years it has failed to receive any grant from the Australia Council.

SPEECH.PARA: This is despite the fact that it is a very significant company. It employs 16 to 18 full time dancers, which is about 10 per cent of those employed in that form of dance in Australia. It is a classical ballet company which tours constantly throughout New South Wales, and gives not only school performances but also performances for post-school adult audiences of the normal kind. So this is classical ballet being brought to a very wide range of Australians, in this case throughout New South Wales and, by invitation, to a State such as Tasmania. Not only that, its training facilities, through dint of the hard work of the artistic directors and the whole company, have created an environment in which the most prestigious ballet scholarship available in Australia-I am referring to the 1983 Peter Stuyvesant cultural scholarship-was won by that ballet school, and the runner-up was also a product of the school.

The Australia Council has to become aware that it must make a very real choice between the stimulation of an appreciation and even a basic awareness of the various forms of art throughout Australia, as opposed to ensuring the survival or the assurance of financial support for one national company in a particular field of artistic activity, thus ensuring that one very excellent expression of that art form is to be found in Australia's cultural life. I do not say that those two aims are necessarily mutually exclusive, but in fact, as Senator Teague has rightly pointed out, they turn out to be so, because the major national company in this particular form of artistic activity does not undertake the touring, even to all capital cities throughout Australia, which ought to be the case if an awareness or an appreciation of that form of art is to be enhanced in the community. Certainly it does not visit the country towns and provincial centres and provide performances for school children which can awaken an insight and interest and give an awareness and appreciation of that art form.

I do not think that my remarks require any further response. I appreciate the previous response from the Minister. But I wish to reinforce that choice which the Australia Council faces, and I indicate to it that on both sides of this chamber there is a very real concern that the true object of Federal funding, from all Australians paid into the Federal Treasury, is not being fulfilled as many senators would wish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a brief continuing statement, I too, acknowledge the good intentions of the Minister and the Government in this matter. Similar statements were made by those now in Opposition. When we were in government we noted this problem, we certainly acknowledged the independence of the Australia Council, and we noted that it would be taking on board the comments made in the Estimates Committee, as it will our remarks here in the chamber on behalf of the people of Australia. But let me go further. It is not enough just for these comments to be taken on board. After some years of debating and questioning along these lines, we are looking for an outcome which gives a financial advantage to companies such as the one that Senator Tate mentioned; not the leading or the biggest funded ballet and dance group in Australia, but a very important one, nevertheless. The example I raise is the South Australian State Opera which is not the biggest funded. These groups should receive moneys through the Australia Council in lieu of the greater touring commitment of national performing arts bodies in earlier decades. So I am not happy that this Government, like the previous Government, is just taking on board the debate. I accept the Minister's genuine commitment, but I am looking for action. At this stage of the processes of the Parliament next year, when we consider the decision of the Australia Council and the Australian Government with regard to funding for the arts, those in South Australia will be very carefully looking to see whether in the distribution of funds for the performing arts an appropriate proportion comes to the South Australian State Opera.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that the Deputy President and Chairman of Committees, Senator Hamer, is now in the chair. We have spoken over many years about the two flagships of the Australian performing arts, the Australian Opera and the Australian Ballet. This year, for the first time, one of our goals has been realised. They no longer have separate line budgets. What had been separate allocations to the Australia Council, the Australian Ballet and the Australian Opera are now put under one line. For the first time, all funds for the arts go to the Australia Council. The Australia Council makes the decisions, rather than the Government or the Parliament, as to the proportion that will go to those two flagship performing arts companies. That comparison of the two big flagships with all the other craft, all the other activities of the performing arts, has been reflected in the change in the way in which the Budget is presented in this matter.

It is an illustration that in Australia we can encourage elite, excellent performance by a few, or we can go towards the other end of the spectrum and encourage not quite as excellent performers but much greater participation by the many. We make the same comparisons in sport. We ask whether we in Australia should encourage highly proficient, highly skilled and highly professional, expensive, elite forms of football, which tens of thousands of Australians may attend only as spectators, or whether we should put our money for encouraging sport into many smaller activities that will have the gain of participation. There must be a balance in these things. I still maintain that the balance is too far towards an elite form of opera and ballet in Australia that excludes appropriate encouragements for participation by others and appropriate support for other opera and ballet companies. Therefore, I thank the Minister for his response but say that we are looking for action by this time next year in the decisions of the Australia Council. In particular, I shall be watching most carefully to see that there is financial support for the South Australian State Opera.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General is on his way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to hear that the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) is on his way, because it seemed rather surprising that we should embark upon consideration of the estimates for his Department in his absence. Perhaps matters of a routine kind could be dealt with by the Minister representing him. Nevertheless, the matters I want to raise are ones that only the Attorney-General himself can deal with. Earlier this year, prior even to the election result, the Attorney-General reputedly gave to the Attorney-General's Department a list of matters to which he attached a series of priorities. I do not know that this particular document was ever actually published by the Attorney-General. It is unlike him not to publish widely the views he has on every subject under the sun, but at all events, this document found its way into the April edition of a publication known as Justinian.

SPEECH.PARA: The various priorities were given categories such as 1A, 1B and so forth. Category 1A represented those matters requiring immediate attention the autumn session of Parliament which was completed in June this year. Matters in the 1B category were to be completed by the Budget session. Matters in the 1C category were to be completed by the end of the year. Matters in category 2 were of lower priority and I will set them aside for the present moment. My attention has been particularly drawn to and my interest has been particularly engaged in the items to which the Attorney-General gave a priority for achieving before the end of this year. As that time approaches, I raise on this occasion the question of the extent to which those matters have been achieved, and ask what has happened about those matters which do not appear to have been achieved. When is it likely that they will be achieved and what sort of delays have occurred?

I am glad that we now have the attention of the Attorney-General to this matter . I would like to refer generally to the much vaunted claims of the Attorney- General as being a law reformer and custodian of civil liberties. I do not think that it is necessary to say very much about the latter attribute, because it has become very tarnished and widely questioned as a result of many of the actions that he has taken in his role of Attorney-General. I perhaps would express a little more sympathy for him in that respect, because of the difficulties of his office which, as I well know, require him to act in an independent and fearless manner on many occasions, which does upset people. Nevertheless, as I have said, the Attorney would have found that those demands on his office and his judgments do not enable him to achieve all the proposals for the advancement of civil liberties about which he used to speak so much when he was in opposition, and on which he lectured this chamber on a number of occasions.

During this consideration of the estimates for the Attorney-General's Department, I wish particularly to address myself to his claims to have achieved a great number of law reforms in a very tight frame. Generally speaking, it seems that most of the matters with which he has succeeded over the last eight months were ones that were well and truly developed and virtually ready to proceed at the time that he became Attorney-General. I instance, in particular, the one item to which he gave great priority, namely the re-introduction of the Family Law Amendment Bill and the establishment of a matrimonial property inquiry. That Bill, of course, had been lying on the table for some time and had been the subject of a great deal of comment; amendments that had been drafted and were ready were proposed and the legislation has now gone through the Parliament. But, as I said, the work on it had very substantially been done and it was ready for parliamentary debate when Senator Evans became Attorney-General .

The other Bill which has been processed and to which he gave priority under category 1A was the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill. It is interesting to read what he said would be achieved in that Bill, namely, that it would incorporate the amendments moved unsuccessfully in the original debate reflecting the Senate Committee's recommendations. Once again, the work for the Bill that he had introduced had already been done; indeed, he had done much of it himself when in opposition. But it did not include two of the major matters which had been the subject of great debate in this chamber, namely, the abolition of conclusive certificates and an additional role for the Ombudsman. Only by Opposition amendments did it include provision for the latter. Another area in which the Attorney has introduced legislation is that of constitutional reform. We know that his great aim in this regard was for the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill to become law and for a referendum to be held on this matter. We know the sad history, from the Attorney's point of view, of that legislation. It was introduced in this Parliament and was abandoned because the Government saw the dangers of that legislation and completely reversed the policies which the Attorney-General had been advocating so strongly.

Broadly speaking, therefore, that legislation which the Attorney-General has put forward in the legislative and law reform areas seems to be Bills which were already virtually in the pipeline ready for passage by this Parliament, or Bills which have failed to achieve the purpose he set out and those priorities which he gave in Justinian. As far as the constitution reform matter is concerned, the Fixed Term Parliaments Bill which I mentioned was, in fact, replaced by a proposal for constitutional reform identical with that put forward by the Fraser Government with regard to four year terms and simultaneous elections. The only matter to which the Attorney-General gave priority and in which he has succeeded was the South West Tasmanian dam legislation and his persuasion of the High Court to an interpretation of the external affairs power of the Constitution. Certainly I must concede that that was an achievement by him, but one at what cost? It was an achievement at the cost of confrontation not only with Tasmania, but also with the other States; it was at the cost of achieving an interpretation of the external affairs power of the Constitution which will be a constant source of deep concern not only to the States, but also to the Opposition and large numbers of people in this country.

We are concerned that we are now heading for a completely centralist system of government, not a Federal system of government. The more that that interpretation that the Attorney-General achieved in having adopted is tested and applied, the deeper will be the concerns about the future of our Federal system. So that may be claimed as an achievement, but it is an achievement of what kind, for what purpose and at what cost?

I want to raise some matters, which perhaps the Attorney-General can comment upon, which do not seem to have been processed in accordance with these priorities. I think 44 priorities were to be achieved by the end of this year and on my reckoning, it is not particularly apparent what has been achieved by 10 to 20 of them. I mention, in particular, priority No. 6 which is to secure implementation of the Premiers Conference residual links exercise. All that has been said by the Attorney-General on that issue seems to leave it virtually where it was back in 1982 when the Premiers agreed to it. It is most disappointing that progress in that matter has not been achieved in accordance with the intentions as expressed by the present Attorney-General. It seems to me that it has got bogged down, with the States trying to establish some access to the Queen, using the Commonwealth Government as just a post office box. But even that does not seem to have progressed very far. Because of that particular action all the benefits obtained by the Premiers Conference agreement back in June 1982, 18 months ago, have not been achieved and perhaps are in danger of being lost. That is a matter about which I would like to hear from the Attorney- General.

There are some other matters of considerable interest in this document. I noticed the Attorney gave a high priority to the review of the consitutional feasibility of re-establishing Commonwealth sovereignty over off-shore resources ; in other words, this Government's intention presumably would be to dismantle the off-shore consitutional settlement which was, I believe, one of the major achievements of the Fraser Government and one of the major examples of co- operative federalism that we have ever seen. Does this mean-we do not yet have any information about this-that the Attorney-General has embarked upon this review? What will happen? What will the Government do about this matter?

The Attorney-General also gave a very high priority to corporate affairs. He gave a category 1A priority to reviewing the constitutional basis for the unilateral Commonwealth companies and securities legislation and identified necessary references and/or referendum proposals. The Attorney has introduced legislation on that subject which we may debate shortly but again that only largely gives effect to the work done on that particular company law reform before this Government was formed. What is the Attorney-General doing there? What is his object with that review? Will he or the Government move to dismantle that other great example of co-operative federalism; namely, the co-operative arrangements in this area?

I notice that the Government-I give the Attorney-General credit for this-has now established the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee, although only a chairman has been appointed. Again, that is a matter which had been decided during the time of the previous Government. It had been agreed to by the Ministerial Council, in November last year, and it seems to me that there has been an extraordinary delay in getting that committee established even though it does look as though the timetable that the Attorney gave himself will be met. However, as I said, as far as I am aware only a chairman has been appointed at this stage and there has been, when one considers that the agreement to establish the Committee was reached a year ago, a very considerable delay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always thought of Senator Durack as wearing in this Parliament the mantle if not of a fully fledged statesman then at least of a potential one and it really does not sit well with that statesman-like aspiration for us to have to listen to the churlish, petty-minded and trivial diatribe that has just fallen from our putative statesman's lips. He has wobbled uncertainly about between on the one hand attacking me for not doing what he thinks I said I would do, and on the other hand, directing various barbs at me for doing many of those things that I said I would. All in all, it was a rather unsatisfactory and feeble performance from the shadow Attorney-General. I think it would be most charitable of me to put it down to a kind of touching wistfulness on the part of Senator Durack that he himself would have wished to be able to achieve as much in the long, dark years he occupied this particular portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: It is, of course, quite unfair of the honourable senator to place the reliance he did on the document which I, in the interests of free discussion, dialogue and information, circulated to a number of people, in particular my proposed new department at the time of the last election. The priority list of target projects and programs for this year and on to next year was designed to generate a response as to what the art of the possible might be. Of course there have been a number of adjustments to that as the year has worn on and as the pressures and constraints of the parliamentary timetable have imposed themselves on the aspirations of even the most energetic Minister.

As to the level of energy that has been involved in the conduct of my portfolio I should perhaps put into the record at the outset some rather interesting statistics as to the comparative rate at which submissions have hit my desk in the last six months and the amount of correspondence which has been received from the public compared with the average rate over the last year or so for the previous Attorney-General. The short fact of the matter is that Senator Durack received an average of 327 submissions a month, and 470 pieces of correspondence a month, whereas for the whole of this year those figures have been more than doubled. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a small table demonstrating that small indication as to the degree of industry with which this particular portfolio has been conducted.
Leave granted.
