TALK.START.PARA: —Let me focus more substantially on what some of those achievements over the last six or seven months have been. I will list them very briefly: constitutional reform was, I think, first on the list at the beginning of the year in terms of aspirations, and five Bills have been introduced into and passed by this Parliament-with the support, I readily acknowledge of the Opposition, although I fear that support is becoming somewhat muted now as we get closer to the barrier. Those matters will be put to the electorate next February. They are very substantial and they will amount to the most far reaching attempts to streamline and modernise the machinery of constitutional government in this country since Federation if they are in fact passed, as I believe they will be and indeed must be. As to South West Tasmania, as Senator Durack rather gracelessly acknowledged we set out to achieve and in fact did achieve exactly what we set out to do; that is, pass legislation and within an extraordinarily short space of time have it both enacted and upheld by the High Court. So far as the establishment of a national crime body is concerned, today legislation will be introduced into this Parliament which will honour that commitment and do so in a far more satisfactory way than the half-baked proposal for which Senator Durack's Government was responsible. That proposal had no support from the States and would simply have been unworkable as well as being indefensible in principle in a number of crucial respects.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as family law is concerned, we have now passed the crucial family law amending legislation, which certainly owed its content very much to the endeavours of the previous Government, but for nearly three and a half years that legislation sat around in the previous Government without its having the energy, the drive and the will behind it to actually get it through this Parliament. No credit at all can be claimed by my predecessor for his performance in that respect. We have set in train a major exercise on maintenance enforcement and collection to establish a national scheme. That had not even occurred to the previous Government. Hopefully, that scheme will come to fruition, on target around the middle of next year. As to the matrimonial property inquiry, true it is that that inquiry was initiated by the previous Government, but like so many initiatives it came to naught because of the utter inability, so often, to translate aspiration into any kind of achievement. The amount of mucking around that was associated with the establishment of that inquiry could be the subject of a substantial novella. It was not until we came to office that the inquiry was, in fact, established, put in train and resources devoted to it. We have a reasonable expectation of results next year.

In the human rights area, right on target we are doing exactly what we proposed to do; that is, we have set in train a major re-examination of the Human Rights Commission, and the Racial Discrimination Act. Associated with that, we have set in train the enactment of an Australian Bill of rights. There will be introduced -I hope before the Parliament recesses, but it may have to wait until the first week after it resumes-draft legislation, for exposure purposes, establishing an Australian Bill of rights. We are working on quite fundamental changes in the way in which rights and liberties are recognised and protected in this country. In the space of 10 days from the problem arising, we have enacted a major amendment to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 to overcome a High Court decision and, in the process, to preserve the operation of State anti- discrimination laws and machinery. That is something which, if the ideologues on the other side were to be believed, would be entirely outside our range of comprehension or likely aspiration. We did it because we do accept and are totally committed to the effective operation, on a Commonwealth and State basis, of human rights and anti-discrimination legislation in this country. We have introduced, as we said we would, the Sex Discrimination Bill. The Bill is now before this Parliament.

Still in the human rights area, we have fundamentally changed the ground rules governing the conduct of film festivals, overcoming anomalies that were the bane of the life of the Chief Censor of the Film Censorship Board, Janet Strickland, in respect of which she could not get any movement at all out of the previous incumbent of my office, notwithstanding the years he spent sitting there twiddling whatever it was he twiddled. All censorship restrictions on imported films and recognised film festivals have been lifted. We have come to grips, in a way that seemed utterly beyond the powers or capacity of our predecessors, with the explosive problem of videotape sales and hiring and the necessity to get some rationality into the censorship process as it affected that. We have negotiated an effective Commonwealth-States agreement. The pieces in that agreement are now being legislated in every jurisdiction in this country. We have responded to the challenges imposed and revealed by a series of court cases this year to the area of contempt of court, both in the courts and tribunals and before royal commissions, by giving a major, a very important reference to the Australian Law Reform Commission.

In the area of business law, which Senator Durack touched on but lightly-that was understandable given the lightness of his achievement in that area-we have established, as he said, the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee, which was no more than a gleam in my predecessor's eye. We are in the process of appointing-the appointment will be made within the next week or two-a chairman of the Accounting Standards Review Board. We will have that Board on foot this financial year. We have taken further the process inititated by the ministerial council, in the last 18 months by enacting in this Parliament this year the first major piece of reforming legislation in the companies and securities law area, the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill.

We are about to introduce cheques legislation which has been hanging around this Parliament for 20-odd years without getting to first base. We are about to introduce an insurance contracts Bill which will implement another major recommendation of the Law Reform Commission in the commercial area. We have passed legislation on freedom of information. We have initiated, in other law reform matters, the establishment of a branch office for the ALRC in Canberra. We have achieved more hard actual law reform in Canberra over the last seven months than the previous Government did in the last seven years. The clock being what it is I will interrupt this litany of achievement for the moment, but will come back to it, I hasten to assure my predecessor, as soon as the parliamentary timetable allows me to do so.
Consideration interrupted.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS (NUCLEAR MATERIALS AND HARDWARE PROHIBITION) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 November 1983, on motion by Senator Chipp:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, in this debate on the Customs ( Nuclear Materials and Hardware) Prohibition Bill, I want to address Australia's responsibility, not in an international sense, but to its own population. Since the 1940s uranium has been mined in Australia for atomic weapons and for nuclear power production. It was Australian uranium which supplied the British nuclear weapons program during the 1950s. Woomera, Maralinga and Monte Bello were familiar place names during that decade, being the Australian sites at which atomic test bombs were detonated. There were few misgivings among Australians in those days. We knew that large areas of inland Australia were supposed to have been suitable for such tests because of the virtual absence of population. We were assured that Aborigines in those areas were few and far between and had, in any case, been moved out of harm's way. There is now, 30 years later, much concern as the facts emerge about totally inadequate protection of personnel and the Aboriginal population, and of contamination. The United Kingdom Government has been compelled to accept some of its responsibility for what now can only be described as criminal negligence in the light of what is understood about the effects of even low levels of radiation.

SPEECH.PARA: To the extent that they were informed, which was not very well, Australian workers accepted the necessity to assist the British. This, of course, was the era of the Cold War. The dangers of mining uranium were not widely known. Like their counterparts in the asbestos industry, uranium miners were exposed to hazards which would certainly kill some of them in the next 20 to 30 years, but they were never told of these hazards. They accepted official assurances that they were adequately protected or were exposed to only a negligible risk. All of us have heard ad infinitum, ad nauseam, about how much radiation we receive from our bedside clocks. We now know that, including Olympic Dam or Roxby Downs, Australia's desposits comprise possibly 30 per cent of the world's reserves. The once uncontroversial business of mining and exporting uranium has come to be recognised by masses of thinking Australians, not necessarily the ones who were polled by the Bulletin, for what it is, that is, unsafe at the least, deadly at the worst. No one has yet proven otherwise.

July 1976 saw the first demonstrations in Adelaide against uranium mining. At the time of the presentation of the Fox report, the report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, in October 1976, it was becoming an important public issue. The first of the unions to place a ban on handling uranium was the Australian Railways Union which has continued to take a highly principled stand on this issue. At that stage the Australian Council of Trade Unions Executive was not prepared to confront the then Government on the issue. By November 1976 there had been a national consultation of anti-uranium forces and they were asking at that time a 5-year moratorium, which seems to be a very reasonable request. The Fraser Government, unfortunately, managed to pre-empt the second Fox report and to award licences for the export of uranium. By 19 November 1976 3,000 to 4,000 anti-uranium demonstrators were prepared to march in Melbourne. By April 1977 the numbers had grown and 20,000 took part in a nation-wide demonstration all over Australia.

By the late 1970s public opinion, as recorded by polls, was showing a clear majority opposed to uranium mining but by then Australian uranium was being regularly exported despite the best efforts of some of the trade unions. By then , too, the Aborigines of the Northern Territory had been bullied into submission by a government whose Prime Minister told them effectively to sit down and shut up. According to the book We All Live on Three Mile Island by Greg Adamson, Fraser, as Prime Minister, had told the Northern Land Council Chairman, Galarrwuy Yunupingu:

I have the power to block any law in the Northern Territory; I'm the number one man in Australia. We're not going to negotiate. Shut up and sit down. We're going to dig that hole anyway. It doesn't matter if you don't want it. We're still going to do it.
If this agreement is not signed you will lose the Northern Land Council. I will take it off you . . . you won't have anything.

Since 1976 Australia has exported over 12,000 tonnes of uranium to seven different countries and existing contracts, not counting those reported very recently as having been signed, will not expire until 1996. Even the best 'phase out' policy, which I would like to see as eventually leading to the same end as the one sought by Senator Macklin's Bill, cannot stop exports as of now. Therefore, Australia's responsibility is undeniable.

Australia's uranium has been used and continues to be used for power generation and probably for the manufacture of weapons and is being reduced to waste. That waste is part of the extraordinarily difficult problem of waste management and goodness knows whether that waste has already been disposed of and, if so, how much, by dumping in the ocean or in holes in unstable geological formations. Professor Ringwood's work on Synroc seems to show promise but he certainly does not claim to be on the verge of going into production or even that he is in a position to say that he has, or will have, the answer.

I suggest that Australia does not need to continue exporting uranium indefinitely in order to remain a significant force in international forums. If our scientists remain in the forefront of this crucial work on waste disposal, we reserve our right to be consulted and when we have terminated our role-I hope sincerely that that will be on some day not too far in the distant future-as dealers in this ugly trade our position will be unimpeachable. I question, further, the argument about leverage and that Australia can influence international opinion only by remaining within the trade. That argument has never been used to justify Australia's inclusion in deliberations of the United Nations and conventions which study and in fact ban, biological and chemical warfare. As far as I am aware, Australia is not bound actually to manufacture these agents in order to be consulted.

Death and destruction associated with other forms of energy generation are acknowledged, and have been for generations. A society which has tolerated such occupational mayhem is one which places profits ahead of the health of workers. I am afraid that in many respects this describes the history of Australian industry. A phenomenon very familiar to those of us who have industrial experience is that profits are all pervasive and the health of workers is accorded a very low priority. There are generations of neglect to rectify- neglect which successive coalition governments have managed to ignore. Some people continue to insist that because workers have been maimed or killed in coal mining and power generation and because of the ghastly 'greenhouse' effect from the combustion of fossil fuels, there is relative safety in nuclear power industry. This is as specious an argument as the defence of smoking tobacco on the grounds that alcohol kills more people-which, incidentally, it does not-and therefore the smoking of tobacco need not be attacked on every ground.

Those who battle against vested interests in order to make the work place healthy and safe would welcome some support from those such as Senator Peter Rae who spoke earlier in this debate and who deplored, very sincerely I believe, the dangers of mining and processing coal. I, for one, was not at all cheered to hear Hugh Morgan of the Western Mining Corporation assuring us all on an A.M. program earlier this week that his company gave the health and safety of its workers a high priority. It is no coincidence, I believe, that the young and aware mining employees of the Pilbara and their families are amongst the most vocal in support of our phase-out policy. They know how mining companies operate and have no faith in such assurances.

In relation to the development in South Australia of the Olympic Dam reserve, there are matters of grave concern when it comes to the health and safety of workers. At the time the indenture was signed by the Liberal Government of South Australia with the joint venturers, the health and safety codes for the protection of workers within the industry were already superceded in terms of international standards. Those codes were outdated at the time and the then South Australian Labor Party Opposition attempted to improve the standards. I have been assured that if the South Australian Government subsequently attempts to legislate to improve those standards or to upgrade them even moderately that could be used as a justification for the cancellation of the indenture altogether. I think that many of us would see that as no bad thing. Clearly, however, further consideration of the protection of workers by proper health and safety codes needs to occur.

During the Roxby Downs blockade a deputation went to the administration of the Roxby Management Services seeking answers to six questions of concern. One of these questions concerned the monitoring of workers' health. When the question was put the answer received was that they gave workers two X-rays a year and that further monitoring was claimed to be too expensive. It was added that to ask such a question was like asking when a person will stop beating his wife. Obviously, Western Mining at that stage-and that was a very short time ago-was not taking the issue very seriously at all. I also believe that mining companies are not required to keep medical records of the health of their workers. Such a lack of records helps to conceal the true health facts of uranium mining. The fate of workers in the asbestos industry, one would have felt, was an object lesson in the indifference of mining and industrial companies towards their workers' health. Miners, generally speaking, have accepted that their work is dangerous, that work underground is arduous, unpleasant and hazardous, that some of them will die at a young age and others will be invalids living on workers compensation on account of injuries or disease such as silicosis by the time they are in their early fifties. This fatalism, I believe, accounts for the willingness of workers to undertake such hazardous work as mining uranium, to accept the well paid jobs being offered, contrary to the policy of the ACTU and, in some cases, contrary to the policy of their own unions. I believe that most of us in this chamber and in the other place this week would have received from officials of a number of unions a message of support for the phase-out policy of the Labor Party. Those unions include the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia, the Seamen's Union of Australia, the Federated Furnishing Trades Society of Australasia, the Electrical Trades Union of Australia, the Food Preservers Union of Australia, the Victorian branch of the Theatrical and Amusement Employees Association, the Victorian Teachers Union, the Australian Tramways and Motor Omnibus Employees Association, the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, the Royal Australian Nursing Federation, the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association, the Amalgamated Metals Foundary and Shipwrights Union, the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia, the National Australian Railways Union, the Victorian branch of the Australian Railways Union, the Actors and Announcers Equity Association of Australia and the Federated Confectioners Association of Australia.

Some awareness of the dreadful effects of radiation must, however, be slowly developing. Employees at the Ranger mine have recently been on strike for seven days in order to have the water supply properly cleansed from contamination by yellowcake. I wonder whether these miners yet realise that a common effect of low level radiation is sterility. In uranium producing countries concerned for the size of their future populations, mining has been greatly curtailed because of the drastically diminished birth rate. I have previously drawn to the attention of honourable senators in this place the fact that there is evidence of the early aging effect of quite low levels of radiation and the distinct probability that no level of radiation is safe. I was born and brought up in South Australia. I lived there until the early 1950s, at which time I went to Western Australia to do my midwifery training; and I have lived there ever since . Atomic tests commenced at Woomera and Maralinga in the early 50's. Over the years there have been thoroughly docu- mented incidents of clouds of contaminated dust being carried by the prevailing winds over the city of Adelaide and its suburbs. When I go home, as I still call it, to South Australia three or four times a year and talk to my contemporaries, I find that I am being told of the premature death or disease of people of my own age, people who, I believe, have been exposed to this contaminated dust in a way that I was never exposed to it and in a way in which my contemporaries in Western Australia were never exposed to it. Of course this is anecdotal, but should give South Australians great cause for concern. I believe there is urgent need for investigation of what I see as a phenomenon which cannot be ignored. Michael Denborough, Professorial Fellow at the Australian National University, with impressive medical qualifications, being a Doctor of Medicine, a Doctor of Science, a Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians and a Fellow of the Royal Australian College of Physicians has written to us all pointing out that there are no adequate safeguards for uranium mining.

The willingness, of South Australians to have their State exposed to further contamination was given considerable weight in the course of the redefinition of Labor Party policy this week. Apparently South Australians are prepared to ignore the lessons of Radium Hill, which also have been clearly documented over the last few years. Among those workers who were employed at Radium Hill in the 1950s and early 1960s and who have already died, something like three times the normal expected deaths by cancer have occurred. Disposal of waste in foreign countries or in the oceans of the world may seem remote and academic problems to many Australians. But the waste in tailing stamps is with us already from earlier mining, presenting a threat in times of heavy rain and also in dry times when contaminated solids have been dispersed widely. We in the Labor Party do not have the luxury of being able to contemplate the immediate cessation of the export of uranium. Supporting the Bill before us would be a tempting but futile gesture, with more than a hint of hyprocrisy, not to mention expediency. I have today restated the reservations of thinking Australians. My Party, according to its policy, in 1977 and 1982 placed stringent qualifications on any expansion of the uranium industry in Australia. As far as I am aware, those qualifications still stand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not uncommon in this place to listen to emotive speeches from members of the Australian Democrats, as well as the left wing supporters of the Australian Labor Party. Last week I listened with interest to the emotive speech made by Senator Mason. At page 2213 of Hansard it is recorded that he talked about the amount of plutonium that is produced and he referred to the loss of some of that plutonium. In his speech he suggested that the total nuclear power production capacity for 1980 would have produced 80,000 kilograms of PU-239. The figure is incorrect, being much too high. The total capacity of the 294 licensed commercial nuclear power plants as at 1 January 1983 was 173, 000 megawatts. Assuming that 70 per cent of this capacity was available throughout 1982, then the total production of all isotopes of plutonium in 1982 would have been approximately, dealing with light water reactors, 36,000 kilograms; Candu reactors, 3,000 kilograms; Magnox reactors, 2,500 kilograms; giving a total of 41,500 kilograms, not 80,000. That is typical of the way in which opponents of the nuclear industry exaggerate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason went on to talk about the mutagenic effects that radiation has on human birth. The truth of mutagenic effects is that, in the Hiroshima-Nagasaki area, more than 75,000 children of irradiated parents from the two bombs were studied and surprisingly enough, no increase in genetic problems was associated with those children. They demonstrated the usual 3 per cent birth deformity rate which is the epidemiological expectation throughout the community. That report was done in 1975. It was known as the Bier report.
The Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council's publication No. 3 also made reference to that. It stated:

There are no data with direct relevance to radiation mutagenesis in man. It is possible to set upper limits to the magnitude of the possible genetic effects of radiation in man by argument from the existence of natural background radiation or from the apparent absene of induced genetic effects in children of the survivors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
Senator Mason, in an emotive speech on the debate on 3 November is recorded at page 2214 of Hansard as saying:

Let us examine the latest report from the United Press International only yesterday, relating to the Windscale area in the United Kingdom. The headline is 'Child cancer levels jump near nuclear plant'.

He went on to talk about alarming levels of leukemia and cancer being found in children living in the vicinity of a nuclear power plant in north west England. This report was on a television documentary. He also went on to suggest that the reason that there were deformed limbs on calves and that calves were born without tongues and ears was that the cows had been grazing in the area near that nuclear power station. I have visited England to study the subject. I have been impressed with the way the health physicists monitor the environmental radiation background regularly to ensure that the normal background radiation level is not exceeded. They monitor out from a radius of, I think, about 18 kilometres from each station. This is done regularly because, if there is any departure-there has not been since 1956 when the nuclear industry commenced in England-they would certainly be anxious to determine the cause.

I suggest that the television program in England from which the Press statements appeared in Australia was unfair because British Nuclear Fuels Ltd suggested that the television company should have produced some comment from its company at the same time. I would like to read some comments that have been made . I asked for some information about the program. The telex in reply states:

The Yorkshire television documentary to which you referred in your telex was transmitted last night (Tuesday, 1 November). BNFL had been in negotiation with the programme makers for over 12 months about this project and had co-operated by providing a great deal of information, special briefings and filming facilities at Sellafield.

We agreed to respond to the claims made in the programme in an interview to be recorded just before transmission. This was done yesterday afternoon by our Director of Health and Safety, Peter Mummery, and the programme as transmitted and seen as a whole was reasonably fair in that at least an opportunity was given to make our position on the main charges quite clear.

However, we were insensed that YTV choose to release details of their film to the press last week well before transmission and before even we had recorded our response. The result was a great deal of one-sided press publicity a version of which has obviously reached Australia.

That is typical. We get one-sided presentations. It would be different if we could have a balanced presentation. People would then be in a position to make a judgment on the facts presented by both sides of the argument. The telex continued:

Our position is clear. We accept that YTV appear to have discovered clusters of cancer cases including leukaemia in children in two small communities close to the Sellafield works and that these represent rates well above national averages . We reject, however, the idea that these can be attributed to radioactivity from Sellafield.

This view has been supported on the programme by Cumbria County Council's own radiological adviser, Professor John Fremlin of Birmingham University, who considers a virus to be a more likely explanation of these clusters as well as other clusters to be found elsewhere in the country well away from any nuclear installation.

That is true. We have to examine the whole thing in a sensible, unemotional way. We will find throughout England and throughout any community clusters of people who have some abnormality or other. I listened to Senator Giles talk about the incidence of cancer amongst the employees in the nuclear industry. This has been studied very carefully. I have seen surveys on many nuclear workers in the industry in America and other places. The epidemiological evidence is that the incidence of cancer amongst those people is less than in other parts of the community. Look at the workers in the coal mining industry. Let us face it, coal mining is a carcinogenic hazard. There is carbon in the environment in which the coal miners work that contributes to emphysema and lung cancer. If we look at that industry we see that there is reason for great concern about the health of workers in the coal mining area.

I always try to keep my feet on the ground with respect to this subject. I have gone out of my way to become informed on the medical, scientific and engineering problems associated with it. I do not claim to be an expert on it, but, I think I am, at least as informed as most people in this Parliament can be. I took the trouble before I went into this subject in great detail to go to Lucas Heights with the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment to be informed on the technology associated with uranium enrichment, with the storage of nuclear waste and with the way radio isotopes are used to make assessments of mining productive capacity and so on. I was impressed by the scientific information that was presented on that occasion. I was told that the scientists at Lucas Heights had done a background environmental study in the Kakadu National Park area eight years before mining in that area commenced. They did biopsies on the livers of fish, feral buffalo and birds and discovered that, in the dry season before mining commenced, there was a tremendous amount of heavy metal pollution in the livers of those animals and birds, so much so that one would think they would die. But in the wet season when the dilution of the waters occurred, those animals returned to normal. I was impressed with the infinite care with which the Lucas Heights scientists went about that work. Of course, I visited the area before mining commenced. I visited there after the Nabarlek mining was completed, before processing commenced and after processing was completed.

I have been in a position to exercise some sort of surveillance over the environmental care that is taken up there. Certainly slight accidents occur. There was a spillage-an insignificant spillage as it turned out-which was blown out of all proportion in the Press. When it was investigated there was found to be no problem or hint of a problem with respect to the health of the people working up there. I am sure that the people who are working in the Ranger uranium mine area or who are contemplating working with Pancontinental Mining Ltd would be suitably unimpressed by the attitude of some members of the Australian Labor Party who threaten to stop the industry altogether and deprive the workers of their jobs and deprive many of their fellow workers of the opportunity of future employment. Mr Deputy President, I do not want to overly burden the Hansard but in the interests of time I would like to incorporate in Hansard-I have told the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) about this-a Press statement from British Nuclear Fuels Ltd on the Yorkshire television program.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
BNFL PRESS STATEMENT ON YORKSHIRE TV PROGRAMME

British Nuclear Fuels limited emphatically rejects claims made in a Yorkshire Television programme to be shown on Tuesday that operations at the Company's Sellafield site (formerly Windscale) may have caused cancer in children on the Cumbrian coast. The Company also deplores the fact that YTV have released details of these alarmist claims before it has completed the programme by interviewing BNFL's nominated spokesman, Mr Peter Mummery, Director of Health and Safety. A formal complaint will be made to the Independent Broadcasting Authority.
''YTV bases its accusations on its own unvalidated findings that the incidence of cancer among children in three villages near Sellafield is higher than the national average'' Mr Mummery said today.

In small areas variations from the national average, both upward and downward may be expected. It is well known to experts in cancer statistics that sometimes unusally high numbers can be found in relation to the size of the community. These are described as ''clusters''. A quick examination of some available cancer incidence statistics by BNFL has already identified a town in Cumbria some 30 miles from the coastline where a cancer cluster exists.

''The incomplete programme discussed by YTV with journalists at the weekend, ignores the studies carried out by BNFL itself on the number of deaths from cancer among those people who have worked at Windscale since nuclear operations began.''
''This major epidemiological survey was discused with the YTV programme's producer in considerable depth.''

''It covers some 11,500 workers and ex workers at Sellafield. It shows that there is no greater number of deaths from cancer among the people who actually work or have worked with radioactive materials at the plant than in the population at large.''

''Indeed, the total number of deaths from cancer (293) is lower than might be expected (337) among such a group on the basis of the national figures. The number of deaths from leaukaemia to which YTV pay particular attention is eight with an expectation of nine. The average radiation exposure to those workers arising from operations at Sellafield is 100 times greater than it is to the general public in Cumbria.''

''BNFL also intends to deal with claims made in the programme relating to the environmental effects of discharges of radioactive materials from Windscale provided that YTV uphold the promise they gave us seven months ago that we would be given a reasonable opportunity within the programme to answer any serious criticisms made against us.''

''Nearly all the allegations relating to the environment raised in the programme were thoroughly discussed at the 100 day Windscale Inquiry held in 1977 and refuted'' Mr Mummery said. ''We have continued to monitor environmental effects and published data on them regularly, discussing it with local area representatives on the Sellafield Local Liaison Committee.''
We particularly object to the statement in the programme that there is a hazard to children playing and walking in the Sellafield area.

''Assuming the highest figures quoted in the programme for levels of radioactivity to be correct, children would have to eat 20 lbs of dust in a year or sit in one tiny spot on a muddy estuary for 500 hours in a year (if such a spot could still be found each time the tide has turned) before permitted limits would be reached.''

''Discharges of radioactive materials from Sellafield are within the limits set by Government appointed regulatory bodies which have access to the best available scientific advice from the National Radiological Protection Board, the International Commission for Radiological Protection and a number of advisory bodies.''

''Finally the programme implies that the accumulation of plutonium along the coast and in particular at Ravenglass has been taking place at an increasing rate in recent years. The reverse is the case. The amount has been decreasing reflecting the decreasing plutonium discharges. The YTV film refers to the plutonium getting into people via the lung-that is via the air they breath. Measurements made regularly and published over many years show that the level of plutonium in the air in the Ravenglass area for example, has always been tiny by comparison with the permitted limit and is currently 1/1000th of that limit.''
''In no way can the situation be described as one in which the levels are dangerous.''

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I think this subject is extremely important to the future of Australia. I am surprised that Senator Chipp does not recognise the job opportunities that would be created, the potential for the generation of industry in Australia. I regret that he has become emotionally tied up with people whose support he naturally wants to gain in Parliament. I suggest that the vast majority of Australian people-I think the last Morgan gallup poll suggested 79 per cent of the community-are in favour of the expansion of the nuclear industry in this country. If the referendum on 25 February were to include this issue along with the constitutional matters that we are going to be dealing with, I believe we would find that the majority of people in Australia would encourage the development of the uranium industry in this country. I suggest it is very important to recognise the comments of Sir Mark Oliphant on this subject. I quote from an article in the Australian of 13 October by Leslie Kemeny, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: On the sensitive subjects of bombs and proliferation, which arouse so much emotion in both government circles and among the Australian public, the recently published comments of one of the 'elder statesman' of Australian science, Sir Mark Oliphant, bear repeating:
'Withholding Australian uranium would not prevent the erection of a single reactor or the production of one nuclear weapon in a world where 50,000 to 60, 000 such weapons already exist . . .
'I am convinced that Australia would be foolish not to mine, use and sell uranium.'

We must remember-this is another thing that is overlooked-that the plutonium which is being used to furnish those countries with the nuclear weapons that they possess comes from sources other than domestic nuclear power sources. This was made clear, I thought, in what I regarded as a good answer given yesterday by Senator Walsh, when he made the point that special treatment needs to be carried out and special processes and technology have to be used. Of course, we are all interested in the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons. We would all like to see the Russians, the Americans-all those who possess these weapons- destroy them so that we need have no concern about them any longer. But that still would not necessarily mean that Australia would not become the target for some of the communist countries which may be looking at our national resources with greed and envy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on now. Who? Name one.
—Japan.
—Is that communist?
—South Korea. Right, okay, let us look at the countries that need energy and we will find that plenty of left wing socialist countries are in that category.
—Name one country that has the logistic capability of invading and occupying Australia, other than the United States and the Soviet Union.
—I think that Senator Chipp is the high priest--
—Name one.
—All right, I am suggesting to Senator Chipp that there could be several.
—Name one.

—We named them the other day. There is a country in Europe, in the Eastern bloc, without sufficient uranium for its own use. I believe it would be very anxious to acquire uranium from any source at all.
—But name one that is capable of invading and occupying Australia. That is what I am asking.

—Let me proceed and reply to the high priest, I think they called him, of the uranium trade. The countries that would be anxious to acquire uranium from Australia I suggest would be China, which has an inadequate supply, and Vietnam, which has none. They are countries that I think are militarily anxious to acquire uranium for their purposes. They are a couple of examples.

SPEECH.PARA: I share Senator Chipp's views that nuclear weapons are bad, but if a country wanted to attack the North West Cape, for example, it could do it with conventional weapons. Countries have satellite weapons now and laser technology which is going to present problems. So I think the Australian Democrats should really strut the international stage. They should talk to the people in Moscow and tell them that they believe the Russions should get rid of their nuclear weapons. I think that would be a very commendable thing to do for the future of mankind. If the proposition were that we should agree that all these countries should phase out their nuclear weapons, I would support that entirely.

I do believe that with the way in which technology is improving, with the advances that are being made, all our worries about the storage of highly radioactive waste should be gradually subsiding. Technology is becoming more satisfactory. The infinitesimally small amount of residue that is left after nuclear power generation presents far fewer problems than the massive toxic wastes that are left when we burn coal. I have made the point time and time again that for every tonne of coal we burn 2.8 tonnes of carbon dioxide is produced, together with all the other oxides of sulphur and nitrogen that could damage the ozone layer in the long term. How do we dispose of the mercury, cadmium and other toxic wastes that are left in mammoth quantities throughout the world? Since the advent of nuclear power the accumulation of waste throughout the world would cover the Phillip Oval here in Canberra or the Adelaide Oval in South Australia to a depth of one metre. The total accumulation of radioactive waste in England since 1956 would cover an ordinary two-bedroomed suburban home. We are looking at waste of that magnitude. If we in Australia provided 15 million people with nuclear power for 12 months we would be looking at a residue of radioactive waste which would fill a room 10 feet by 10 feet by 10 feet.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is high level waste, is it not?

—Three cubic metres of high level waste, yes, but waste which is easily disposed of in the glassification process. I wish that Senator Mason would check his facts before coming in here and talking about mutagenesis. I wish he would study the subject a little more carefully in the future. I wish he would get the facts with respect to the amount of plutonium that is being produced in the world today. I hope when he reads the facts that I have presented he will revise his thinking on this subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the Customs (Nuclear Weapons and Hardware Prohibition) Bill 1983 although I find many characteristics of the Bill attractive. The Bill, of course, is for an Act to prohibit the export of nuclear materials and the importation of nuclear hardware and for purposes connected therewith. The Bill is superficially attractive because it refers to the exclusion of various nuclear hardware in the interpretation section of the Bill. However it goes further and in clause 4 reference is made to natural uranium, yellowcake. Of course, the Bill would have the effect of attempting forthwith to prevent the export of uranium. That position is not supported by the Australian Labor Party. The Labor Party's position is to phase out uranium mining and indeed, in paragraph 63C of the Australian Labor Party platform it is stated that the Australian Labor Party's minimum position is a total unequivocal commitment to phase out Australia's involvement in the uranium industry. That is something that I completely support. I refer to the Labor Party platform which encompasses the principles that we in the Labor Party have adopted, having given a great deal of consideration to the many problems that exist in the uranium industry. In relation to that industry, the Labor Party's platform states:

SPEECH.PARA: Recognising that the provision of Australian uranium to the world nuclear fuel cycle creates problems relevant to Australian sovereignty, the environment, the economic welfare of our people and the rights and well being of the Aboriginal people;

believing that, having regard to the present unresolved economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental and technical problems associated with the mining of uranium and the development of nuclear power, and in particular-
a to the proven contribution of the nuclear power industry to the proliferation of nuclear weapons and the increased risk of nuclear war; and
Further, we believe:
b the absence of procedures for the storage and disposal of radioactive wastes to ensure that any danger posed by such wastes to human life and the environment is eliminated;

Last night I was reading the Guardian, from the United Kingdom, in the Parliamentary Library. It stated that the British Government, in seeking to use a particular dump for the disposal of nuclear waste, found that containers that were used a number of years previously were unsafe because dampness around the mine areas had caused the corrosion of the containers. What is so frightening is that throughout the world the problem of waste has not been solved. We face the problem that governments throughout the world are trying to solve their problems with the nuclear industry when there are no proven ways of being able to secure safely waste products over a period. Of course, even those products that have been tested have, relative to the dangers of radioactive waste, a very long life before anybody can be certain that they will be safe at all.

The Labor Party platform takes the position, to put it colloquially, that the uranium industry in every facet that I have just described is suspect. It has to be shown that it is not guilty of being a dangerous industry. It has to be shown that the mining processes are not dangerous. Many potential dangers exist in relation to the mining of uranium, especially deeply mined uranium. Nevertheless , we believe that we must take special steps. We have indicated that we inherited a situation when we came to government whereby the Fraser Government had made treaties and authorised contracts to supply uranium to a growing number of countries which make little effort to impose controls and conditions on its supply. The incoming Labor Government was committed to repudiating all existing commitments. The Labor platform states:
In adopting our repudiation commitment an Australian Labour Party government has neither a moral, legal, or political obligation to compensate the industry as such;

(c) Understanding the difficulties which could be encountered in the implementation of that commitment our minimum position would be a total unequivocal commitment to phase out Australia's involvement in the uranium industry and that certain conditions as outlined will and must be applied to those mines . . .
Of course, we were referring to mines in production in July 1982. The ALP platform continues.
(d) as an ALP government we give total commitment to preventing any new mines from being developed during our period of office.
That is the platform of the Australian Labor Party, to which I particularly subscribe. I commend it to honourable senators.

There is another aspect of Senator Chipp's second reading speech with which I completely agree. He referred to the general question of nuclear arms proliferation. I feel that it is the main problem we face today. The danger of nuclear war is the greatest problem we face. I think this moment in history is perhaps one of the worst the world has faced. I am pleased that the Labor Party platform on disarmament and arms control very clearly states that a Labor goverment will:
Oppose the development, proliferation, possession and use of nuclear, chemical, bacteriological and other techniques of mass destruction.
The platform continues:
Work to apply and strengthen international conventions to secure universal prohibition of nuclear, chemical, and bacteriological and biological warfare. In relation to nuclear weapons, Labor will-
a urge achievement of major qualitative restraints and quantitative reductions in Strategic Arms Limitation Talks and in regional arrangements;

I mention this because the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp) has referred to it. I believe that the situations we face now in Lebanon and the Middle East, with Iran and Iraq locked in a very vicious war, and the recent developments in Central America and the Carribean mean that we have every reason to worry. We have two super-powers, two nuclear powers. It is impossible to separate uranium and its supply from the nuclear weapons issue because they are interlocked. It is bad enough that we have in the world today the development of conventional arms and a tremendous buildup towards war. The wars I have just mentioned are the most obvious ones. There are many places where the world powers are supplying conventional arms and there is the threat, in the long term , that additional powers will obtain nuclear arms.

In 1981 world military spending totalled $625 billion. This is at least $110 for every man, woman and child on earth. Fifty million people are directly or indirectly engaged in military activities. In a world in which energy resources are supposed to be in scarce supply, 6 per cent of petrol consumption is used for military purposes. For those who argue that we should extend the uranium industry surely one practical way of reducing the ordinary call on the petroleum industry would be to reduce the arms race itself. One quarter of all research funds go to military research and development. Here again, if one examines how little has been spent, relatively speaking, on alternative sources of energy one can see that we are not sensibly allocating responsibilities in the world. For example, so little is spent on solar power and other forms of safe energy, but so much is spent on conventional weapons.

The international trade in conventional arms is staggering. It amounts to $26 billion a year. The trade in arms by both developed and developing countries, particularly the Soviet Union, the United States, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Brazil and Israel is of great concern. Those matters of conventional arms are serious enough, but we are reminded of nuclear weapons technology, the frightening proportions that it has reached, and the nuclear overkill mentioned by Senator Chipp when he referred to the fact that 50,000 nuclear weapons are now deployed. Their combined explosive power is one million times grater than the bomb dropped on Hiroshima. When one considers that, one realises that an error by any country which possesses nuclear weapons could lead to the final solution concerning the world's population.

The problem is that not enough money is going towards solving the world's problems in a positive, human and life-force way because we have so much money in the area of destruction. There is no way that one can differentiate, as we are going down hill in the danger of nuclear war, between the ordinary use of uranium for power generation and, finally, one way or another, the danger of yellowcake, in a processed form, getting into various hands in the form of nuclear weapons. I accept that there are people who genuinely believe that by exporting their uranium they might have some say in the final situation concerning weapons. I reject that view. I do not believe that it is sensible. All the examples that have been given of the expropriation of uranium in transit show that it is possible at any point for a nation state or terrorists to gain sufficient to be able to endanger the world in a situation in which there is a proliferation of reactors and the wherewithal to establish at least dirty nuclear weapons, as they are called.

We are doing all this when the United Nations has pointed out that 8 per cent of the world's total output is spent on the arms race, when one child in four suffers from malnutrition, when four out of five children in rural areas do not have adequate water or sanitation, when two out of five children aged 6 to 11 years do not attend school, and when four out of five children have no modern health care. The world's military spend the equivalent of the annual budget of the United Nations Children's Fund every four hours. When we look at the other aspect, we see that just one strategic bomber which costs $US100m is the equivalent of the spending by the World Health Organisation to wipe out smallpox .

These are the choices that we have. Senator Susan Ryan, in a speech at an international symposium in Canberra earlier this year, pointed out that our own nation spends $4 billion on defence when our homelessness, unemployment and proverty are still matters of concern. I noted that Senator Jessop, who is a sincere supporter of uranium mining, referred to communist countries invading and occupying Australia to get our uranium. When he was challenged, that was found to be just another of the frightening statements that people such as Senator Jessop are making. He was not able to nominate one country that could be in the position of doing that. But later I shall draw attention to the fact that , unfortunately, this is a world situation in which tensions are increasing. Irresponsible statements such as that made by Senator Jessop today are the sort of things that are multiplying in the world and that make the consideration of this private member's Bill something about which we should be concerned, because the threat is a genuine threat of world war in our time.

It is very hard for people as egotistical and as narcissistic as politicians tend to be to face up to the fact that there will be nothing left if there is a nuclear war. For them to consider the Bill, they must consider that it relates critically to what we are to do to prevent this almost inevitable war. If it is thought that I am exaggerating, I should refer to a recent issue of the International Herald Tribune, of 31 October this year, I think. This is a prominent American and international journal and it reflects a very balanced and conservative view of world affairs. This issue contains an article headed:
'Kremlin Preparing Soviet Population For a Deterioration in Ties with U.S.'
Dusko Doder writes from Moscow:
The Soviet leadership has begun a broad effort to mobilize the population for an anticipated crisis in its relations with the United States.

Well-informed sources said Communist Party members are being told in closed meetings that there is no chance of reaching an agreement at the Geneva arms talks and that the country and its economy must be prepared to meet all challenges imposed by the situation.

According to participants in the meetings, a Central Committee letter to the party's 18 million members gives a gloomier assessment of East-West relations than publicly stated by President Yuri V. Andropov.

The letter reportedly asserts that Moscow should not expect an improvement in relations with Washington for several years, and the wording suggests that it expects a deterioration of relations during that time.
This is a letter from an American correspondent describing the tension that now exists in the Soviet Union. The correspondent goes on to say:
The letter is said to emphasize the need for greater internal discipline, vigilance and sacrifice, and it puts particular emphasis on stopping loose talk by citizens who know state secrets . . .

There has been an unusually strong emphasis on the importance of the KGB, the Soviet secret police. The Communist Party newspaper Pravda recently carried laudatory remarks about the KGB that have not been heard in public for decades. It quotes a Soviet citizen as thanking 'the fighters on the secret front.'

A documentary film that premiered on national television Saturday night portrayed the United States as a dangerous 'militaristic' power bent on world domination. The 45-minute film, prepared by the Defence Ministry, contrasted shots of U.S. nuclear explosions and various U.S. missiles with scenes of war victims, Soviet war memorials and words of Moscow's peaceful intentions.

A series of public meetings held throughout the country Saturday also emphasised the threat to the Soviet Union posed by the scheduled deployment in December of new U.S. nuclear missiles in Europe and Mr. Reagan's foreign policy.

I refer to that article because I think it indicates the paranoia that obviously exists and is even, perhaps, being encouraged by the Soviet Government. It occurs at a time when within three weeks the deployment of Cruise and Pershing 2 missiles begins in Western Europe. Relations between the United States and the Soviet Union are at an all time low. We know that the Soviet Union is threatening to walk out of the intermediate nuclear force negotiations as a reaction to the deployment of the missiles in Europe. The Strategic Arms Reduction Talks, START, which convened in Geneva earlier this month, have become the 'STOP' talks. We cannot emphasise enough the it is only a matter of time before progress in super- power dialogue stops. It is sad that this dialogue is lacking because President Reagan, in his address to the Thirty-Eighth Session of the United Nations General Assembly, stated:
. . . progress in weapons technology has far outstripped the progress towards peace.

In order to get the balance of the views of the two super-powers I state my position. There is a very real danger in the very near future of deteriorating relationships between the Soviet Union and the United States. This deterioration could create the situation that could cause war in any of the trouble spots in the world or war could occur simply because of the usual probability that we have with nuclear weapons, that is, a malfunction of the techniques of nuclear weapons. I would also like to draw the Senate's attention to an article entitled 'When Talks Undercuts Arms Talks', also from the International Herald Tribune, dated 4 October 1983 in which Anthony Lewis stated:
The Reagan policy for dealing with the Soviet Union-bristling words and an all- out arms race-is flourishing as never before.
He went on in that article to say:

If meaningful communication breaks down, the consequences could be immediate and severe on the question of medium-range missiles in Europe. The United States is to begin flying Pershing-2 missiles to West Germany in about six weeks.
Of course, this deadline is now about three weeks away. He continued:

Many Europeans have been hoping for last-minute progress in Soviet-U.S. arms talks that would forestall the deployment. But the Andropov statement turns that possibility from remote to just about nonexistent.

Once the deployment of Pershings and cruise missiles begins, the Russians may take some threatening action in response. They might deploy missiles in East Germany, or move nuclear-armed submarines closer to the American East Coast.
The article concluded by saying:

A perception of such danger seems suddenly to have struck the Reagan Administration. Secretary of State George Shultz has reportedly told colleagues that the strident and prolonged criticism of the Soviets over the downing of the airliner may have had unintended consequences.

But only someone grossly uninformed about the Soviet Union could have failed to appreciate how the Russians might react to the words used by this administration -and not just since the incident. For two and a half years Mr Reagan has directed the harshest language at Soviet leaders, really denying their legitimacy, and they do care morbidly about attacks of that kind.

That quote from an American correspondent of the International Herald Tribune draws attention in its very criticism of the strident and, I think, destructive statements that have been made by leading personalities in President Reagan's Administration, statements that just fuel the mutual paranoia of the two super- powers that I think both those quotations establish. For those of us who strongly oppose the development of the whole nuclear weapons cycle, we have the United Nations, we have a world-wide movement for a nuclear freeze, we have a movement which was reflected in the United Nations devoting time in 1978 to discussing disarmament and in 1982 the United Nations Second Special Session on Disarmament was convened. A feature of this session was the strong march for nuclear disarmament and the million people who went to New York to indicate their concern about what is going on. Of course, in Australia we have the same sort of movement of people across political barriers and people who are concerned about nuclear weapons.

When considering a private member's Bill such as that which we are debating today, we must consider every aspect. It is not as simple as dismissing our responsibility. It is my belief that the Australian Labor Party's platform of phasing down uranium mining is a very serious contribution to establishing our position as one of having severe doubt about the suitability of the uranium mining industry and of nuclear power as such, and of the dangers that exist with nuclear power wherever it is in the world. I believe there are so many reported problems with nuclear power stations that we cannot be certain that once again within our immediate lifetime there will not be an accident in a nuclear power station that will cause a meltdown or some other crisis that will only throw back even further the uranium mining industry.

I am reminded of a recent article I saw regarding South Korea, which has been heralded by some people as a place to which we should look. In South Korea it was recently reported that the South Koreans are a bit concerned because pressures have come from government and other sources of administration to skimp on safety measures. There is a serious review taking place in South Korea at the moment to try to rectify what appear to be major faults in their reactors which have been overlooked by authorities. Now, in retrospect, they are trying to solve that problem. I think that one illustration indicates that the nuclear power industry is a dangerous one. Unfortunately, it is the nature of the industry that although other figures might be quoted, the industry has to make only one major error, has to have only one major catastrophe like Three Mile Island almost was, and that is it.

In view of everything else I have said, the proper expression for me to use might be that it is like playing Russian roulette; it is a very dangerous gamble as far as the safety of the world is concerned. It is one in which we in Australia should play our part in making sure that people do not participate. Although I oppose this private member's Bill, I sympathise with many of the aspects incorporated in the Bill by Senator Chipp. But I believe that, under all the circumstances, the Australian Labor Party platform is the appropriate charter for the phasing down of uranium mining in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the fact that it is almost 2 o'clock, but I rise very briefly to open my speech on a private member' s Bill, the Customs (Nuclear Materials and Hardware Prohibition) Bill, the aim of which is to remove any possibility of the movement of nuclear materials, including fissile materials, to or from Australia. The Bill itself is supported by those who argue that by so doing, by the prevention of such movement, there would be a signifcant contribution by Australia towards the lowering of the threat of nuclear war, the lowering of the threat of producing fissile material for wartime purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m. under sessional order I call on questions without notice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I inform the Senate that Senator Ryan will be absent from the chamber this afternoon. Any questions which normally would be directed to Senator Ryan in relation to her portfolio or the portfolios of Ministers she represents should be directed to me.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is there any difference between official Australian Labor Party policy and the policy of the parliamentary Labor Party on uranium? If he believes them to be one and the same thing, is he concerned at the statement by Senator Ruth Coleman on this morning's AM program which draws a clear distinction between the two? Does he believe that the obvious refusal of some Labor parliamentarians to accept Monday's Caucus decision and their determination to campaign publicly against it in the lead up to next year's national conference will revive the uncertainty which has dogged the Government's uranium policy for so long to the detriment of business and investor confidence generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government announced its policy in relation to uranium mining and associated issues some 10 days ago and, in accordance with the normal procedures adopted by the parliamentary Labor Party, that decision was submitted to the membership of the Party on Monday of this week. The decision of the Government was confirmed by that meeting. I think it is common ground that there are differences of emphasis and interpretation in relation to the national platform of the Australian Labor Party on uranium, adopted at the 1982 conference. Nonetheless, the decision of the Government is quite clear. The decision of the Government remains, and I am not in any position to speculate about what particular members might do in the foreseeable future, in pursuit of their individual rights as members of the Australian Labor Party as suggested in Senator Chaney's question.

ANSWER.PARA: I was also asked whether I was concerned about statements made by Senator Coleman on the AM program this morning. Yes, I am. I believe Senator Coleman's statements are not correct in their totality and, as the honourable senator asked this question, I also believe that, on any interpretation at all of the national platform of the Labor Party, the Bill introduced in the Senate by the Australian Democrats is contrary to the policy of the Australian Labor Party. Apart from that, I just confirm the Government's position. There will be no uncertainty engendered by the decision of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I observe that I agree with the last part of the answer about the inconsistency between the Bill and the Labor Party's policy. I remind the Leader of the Government that I asked him whether, in his view, there is any difference between official ALP policy and the policy which has now been adopted by the Government and endorsed by the parliamentary Labor Party's Caucus.

—In my view there is no inconsistency between the view expressed by the Government and the national platform of the Australian Labor Party. I qualify that only by saying that the national platform of the Labor Party did not have applied to it the drafting skills which have been applied to the Government's decision, which will remain the decision of this Government and be implemented.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware that there appear to be some doubts about the way in which initial community employment program projects have been selected in Queensland? Can the Minister investigate why initial allocations appear to have been granted on a random basis and do not appear to represent high unemployment areas? Can the Minister give an assurance that the CEP selection will be based on priorities determined by levels of unemployment in that State and that the $41m allocated to Queensland will be targeted to areas of high unemployment? Furthermore, can the Minister reassure Queensland women that, as set down in the community employment program guidelines, they will in fact be entitled to equal access to those jobs created?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in a position to give Senator Reynolds the assurances which she seeks. I am informed that of the 18 projects recommended for approval under the community employment program 17 are in areas where the highest rates of unemployment are found in the State of Queensland; that is, the rates of unemployment in those 17 areas are higher than the State average. The eighteenth project is in an area with an unemployment level only marginally below the State average. A number of other applications have been received and they are receiving more detailed assessment at this stage. I am not in a position to say anything about them.

ANSWER.PARA: I should inform the honourable senator that the consultative committee which has the function of selecting these programs will be meeting again on Friday of this week and will recommend projects from various other areas of Queensland. But it will do so according to the same criteria which it has adopted in respect of the existing programs and which are, as it were, standard requirements for the program. I am also informed that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations expects to be in a position in the next few days to release a joint statement with the Premier of Queensland announcing a wide range of projects approved under the CEP in Queensland. I think Senator Reynolds will be aware that the CEP guidelines contain special provisions relating to the employment of women, and in respect of Queensland those special provisions have been taken into account along with the other criteria to which I have referred.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ASSOCIATION OF SOUTH EAST ASIAN NATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: Is the Government concerned about the deterioration in Australian's relationship with the Association of South East Asian Nations which has been developing since the Government took office and which has suddenly worsened in recent days? What does the Prime Minister propose to do to repair the damage which has already been done to this long-standing and important relationship? Will the Prime Minister instruct the Foreign Minister to cease making provocative statements in the current climate?

—The first thing to deal with in answer to that question is the implication that there is some difference of view about this matter between the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. There is not. Every statement which has been made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and every consultation he has had with ASEAN governments has been on the basis of prior consultation and agreement with the Prime Minister.
—Did he clear his speeches?

—I do not know whether it goes that far, but there is agreement. Whilst the Opposition parties, when they were in government, may have had the Prime Minister vetting speeches-they certainly sounded like that-the Foreign Minister in the present Government does not have the Prime Minister vetting his speeches, but they are written consistent with the views agreed between the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I might say that the attitude of the Australian Government has been explained on a number of occasions to ASEAN countries in relation to the initiative which the Australian Government took on Kampuchea. We do not see it as any long term deterioration of our relationship with ASEAN, and this week the Minister for Foreign Affairs has been having a series of consultations with ASEAN ambassadors about this matter. The Prime Minister will be visiting Thailand-I am not quite sure when, but in the immediately foreseeable future.
—What about Mr Hayden?

—What about Mr Hayden? The Prime Minister will be visiting Thailand and the views he expresses there will be consistent with the views which have been put by the Australian Government through its Foreign Minister and, where necessary, through the Prime Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. It concerns the level of the unemployment benefit for under-18-year-olds. The Minister is no doubt well aware of my continuing interest in this matter and the questions I have raised on it in the Senate over the last six months. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the 16-year-old hunger striker in Melbourne who has claimed that she will maintain her strike until she receives a positive response from the Government? When will the Government make a decision on income support assistance for under-18-year-olds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do know of Senator Foreman's continuing interest in the level of the unemployment benefit for under-18-year-olds, which was this week increased to $45 a week from the $40 a week it was previously. I remind honourable senators that for a long period, from 1975 on, that figure remained at $36. I do not for one minute pretend that that is necessarily a satisfactory level of unemployment benefit, but the decision to increase it by $5 was an election promise made by this Government. The promise was made in the light of the economic climate and the difficulties that we faced. Of course, we want to do more. As I have said before, Senator Ryan, Mr Willis and I are looking at the whole problem of the unemployment benefit for the young people in this age group . Australia's retention rate for young people in the education system and in training schemes is much below that of other countries. We are looking at consolidating the various forms of income support for young people into a more rational system, a system which will better serve them and this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the young lady who is on a hunger strike in Melbourne. Neither I nor the Government had any approach from this young woman before she started her hunger strike. I have sent an officer of the Department of Social Security to talk to her. I hope that in the next couple of days one of my colleagues will talk to her, as I am unable to be in Melbourne. I appreciate the strength of her feelings which have led her to take this action, but at the same time I do not think it assists the situation for her to do this. I wish that she would use other methods. Certainly, I wish that she had approached the Government and me before she decided to take this action. We are developing new policies. We have no immediate plans to increase the unemployment benefit for the under-18-year- olds as we have just done so in the Budget. However, we will keep the matter under close observation. As I said, Senator Ryan, Mr Willis and I are continuing to work towards a more rational policy in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs a question. He will know that the Soviet Union and the United States of America possess between them something like 50,000 nuclear warheads, 20,000 of them presently able to be instantly deployed against people. Is the Minister aware that this arsenal has a destructive capability equivalent to 1 1/2 million Hiroshima-sized nuclear bombs? While my question is not recommending unilateral disarmament for the United States, is it not a fact that as a strong indication of good will the United States could reduce its nuclear arsenal by, say, 25 per cent without reducing its capacity to totally destroy all major Soviet cities? Has the Australian Government considered these facts? Will the Government use its good offices with the United States to suggest that such a course of action could result in a meaningful and real move towards nuclear disarmament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to confirm or deny the accuracy of Senator Chipp's precise figures. Certainly, the destructive power of the world's nuclear arsenals is enormous, horrifying and, indeed, such as to defy the imagination. It is a fundamental element of the Government's disarmament policy that these arsenals should be reduced and, of course, ultimately eliminated. The Government has noted statements by United States Government spokesmen that the United States has, since the 1960s, reduced the number of nuclear weapons in its stockpile and their total megatonnage. For example, in his report to Congress for fiscal year 1984, Defense Secretary Weinberger stated that the number of nuclear weapons in the United States stockpile was one-third higher in 1967 than in 1980, and that the total number of megatonnes in the stockpile was four times as high in 1960 as it was in 1980.
—But they have replaced them with new weapons which are more dangerous.

—That may be so, but let me indicate the answer to the question in the terms in which Senator Chipp put it. Since 1979 the United States, with the agreement of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, has unilaterally withdrawn 1,000 nuclear weapons from stockpiles in Europe. On 27 October NATO's Nuclear Planning Group announced its decision to withdraw a further 1,400 nuclear warheads over the next few years. NATO spokesmen have said that by the time this decision is implemented NATO's nuclear stockpiles will be at their lowest levels in over 20 years. The Government takes the view that it has so far seen no evidence that the Soviet Union regards these actions as any indication of good will on the part of the United States.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government can see value in good-will gestures of the kind that Senator Chipp proposed when these serve practical purposes, but our objective remains that of securing sound and reliable agreements. Our position has been to urge that agreements should be reached between the super-powers which will lead to both qualitative restraints and quantitative reductions in nuclear forces. Such agreements have to be balanced and appropriately verifiable. Australia has presented its views on disarmament to the United States and to other governments and makes use of our position as an ally of the United States to pursue these objectives. Accordingly the Government does not see it as constructive in present circumstances to propose a 25 per cent unilateral reduction in nuclear armaments by the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security whether he is aware of recent television programs on child pornography and child prostitution which have featured comments by the Pedophile Support Group and others claiming, among other things, that the children consented and, therefore, there was no need to worry. Can the Minister comment on the exploitation of these young children and on any actions the Government is taking to protect their interests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the publicity and controversy involving child pornography in groups such as the Pedophile Support Group. Last night I saw an item on the program Nationwide concerning this subject. During that program I noted that one spokesman for an organisation said that because consent was involved it was of no concern to him or the community. He made the comment also that one of the reasons this exploitation occurs is that social support for children of this age group is inadequate. I was surprised at that approach, an approach which suggests that because consent of those who are under the age of consent is involved things are all right. I thought that went contrary to the laws and the general views of people in this community.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is, of course, aware of the fact that in recent years we have had an increasing problem with child homelessness. In fact, a committee of the Senate of which I was a member reported on some of the problems of homeless youth.
