We are aware that more needs to be done not only in the way of providing refuges but also in providing long term accommodation for young people, and particularly in providing training in life skills. We intend to develop this in association with the States. I hope to negotiate with the States a more comprehensive program in this area in the near future.

I make the point to the person who made the comment on the program last night that this sort of illegal behaviour is not confined to homeless children. The people who indulge in this sort of thing do not confine their activities to those who are homeless or those who are on the streets. To try to excuse this sort of behaviour on the ground that the children consent is, I believe, nonsensical. To try to suggest that we will solve this problem by just social security, or income support measures, is equally nonsensical. I hope the debate on this matter in the future will be more responsible than I believe it was last night.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I ask whether on 24 October 1983, at and after a Metal Trades Industry Association Inc. meeting chaired by Mr Justice Ludeke, the Minister, firstly, in his speech said:

QUESTION.PARA: On-wage costs-
then a little later in the sentence-
is a significant cost impost which has to be addressed.

Later in answer to a question by the Chairman seeking elaboration of those comments, the Minister said that he was referring to long service leave, holiday pay, workers compensation and payroll tax. Secondly, is it a fact that after the meeting the Minister held a Press conference? Thirdly, is it a fact that there he told journalists that he was referring to penalty rates amongst the on-wage costs and that he would not say they should be abandoned, and that he also said that on-wage costs 'must be addressed by government, industry and unions alike'? I now ask the Minister: If they are facts, is it not also a fact that to avoid the wrath of certain unions and Mr Wright, or for some other reason, the Minister attempted to mislead the Senate on 2 November when he attempted to quarantine his statement to those sections contained in the written speech only?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really do not know where to begin because Senator Rae's version of what took place is the product of a mind cluttered with useless and incorrect information. However, let me try to pick my way through the debris which he threw into the Senate in the course of his question and tell him what did take place. I would have thought that before asking the question he would have adverted to the speech I made to the Metal Trades Industry Association because it is freely available, and I am sure that the honourable senator's source of information would have given him a copy of it which would have enabled him to quote more accurately from it.
—There it is Minister, and the parts I quoted are marked.

—No, they are the parts which the honourable senator did not quote. The honourable senator did not quote the parts. He pushed them all together in one sentence and a useful paraphrase for his purpose, which had nothing to do with what I said. Let me say first of all that in the speech I referred to on-wage costs. In talking about on-wage costs I specifically referred to long service leave as something which we have in Australia which other countries do not have. I was making the point, which the honourable senator ignored, of course, that on-wage costs in Australia are not significantly different from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. I made that point.

ANSWER.PARA: Then, subsequently, in the course of my answer to a question from Mr Justice Ludeke, who asked me who should address the problems of add-on costs, I said that governments had to address certain of those costs, including payroll tax, workers compensation premiums, and so on, and that unions and employers had to address some of the questions of on-wage costs. I subsequently had a Press conference where, for the first time, the question of penalty rates was raised. In the course of that Press conference, yes, I said that penalty rates, with other add-on costs, were questions which had to be addressed.

I was then asked my view about penalty rates and I said in response: 'If you think I am going to discuss my views on penalty rates on television you are going to be disappointed'. Subsequently in the Senate I have been asked a number of questions about my views on penalty rates and I have indicated in answer to those questions that I in no way regard myself as an expert on that very complex and difficult topic. However, they have to be addressed in the context of all the other issues to which I have referred and they have to be addressed by the people I suggested ought to address them. I do not know whether I can add anything to that by way of explanation. However, that is what happened. If Senator Rae likes to try to turn that series of statements by me into an allegation of cowardice or something in terms of answers that I have given in the Senate, of course, that is typically desperately consistent with his whole performance as Opposition spokesman on industry and commerce in this Senate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS BENEFICIARIES RESIDING IN NEW ZEALAND

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs been drawn to recent publicity concerning movements in the rate of exchange between the Australian and the New Zealand dollar and the consequent 'short changing' of departmental beneficiaries resident in New Zealand? Can the Minister give an assurance that beneficiaries residing in New Zealand are not at a disadvantage because of fluctuation in the exchange rate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been numerous changes in the exchange rate. In fact, in many cases we can recall the exchange rate being in a constant state of fluctuation, which has some effect on pension beneficiaries of not only the Department of Veterans' Affairs but also the Department of Social Security. The question is particularly relevant because the pension payments of several hundred veteran pensioners living in New Zealand have varied as a result of exchange rate variations. Naturally, a considerable number of other beneficiaries, who come under the jurisdiction of Senator Grimes, the Minister for Social Security, have also been affected.

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that under the agreement between my Department and the New Zealand Department of Social Welfare, which is the authority that pays the pensions of Australians who are resident in New Zealand, the predetermined rate of exchange for such payments is reviewed whenever the daily exchange rate varies five cents or more above or below that rate. Unfortunately, that trigger arrangement creates problems for us. Nevertheless, it is preferred to one under which daily rate fluctuations would cause a different rate to be applied every time a pension payment was made. We have a problem in getting some stability and constancy in those payments. However, this arrangement leads to confusion, inquiries and complaints. It has been suggested that somehow or other my Department is short changing veteran beneficiaries. That is not the position at all.

Taking into account the criticism, the Department is setting about to computerise the payment of overseas pensions as part of the benefits processing system which will come into effect in 1984-85. I understand that the Department of Social Security is monitoring the exchange rate, perhaps more than it has done previously. It has now agreed to carry out this function on behalf of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. At the moment we pay $NZ1.33 to meet the adjustment problem. We will continue to do that until the new system comes into operation. I assure Senator Giles that the Department is mindful of its responsibilities in this area. We have set in train an arrangement under which these fluctuations will be taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware that a Soviet built vehicle named the Lada is being sold in Australia and that it is reported that component parts of this vehicle are manufactured in Soviet prison camps? How does this square with article 16 of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulation, which prevents the import of vehicles into Australia if they were made in whole or in part by prison labour? Will the Minister, consistent with his view and, I know, the view of the Prime Minister, take action to investigate the situation and prohibit the import of this non-union Gulag labour vehicle?

—I am aware that a Russian light commercial vehicle is imported. I am aware of that because Senator Harradine told me at a quarter to two this afternoon. I was not previously aware of it. I am totally unable to offer any comment at this stage on Senator Harradine's unidentified reports that this vehicle is manufactured in Soviet labour camps by slave labour. If there is such a vehicle-as I believe on the basis of Senator Harradine's information-imported, and if it is manufactured by slave labour, as Senator Harradine suggests, then it is quite apparent that to import it would be inconsistent with the terms of the Customs regulations as read to us by Senator Harradine. I really have no information at this stage about any of the matters raised by Senator Harradine. I will make some inquiries and see whether I can give him an answer.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In respect of the last matter, would it be of concern to the Minister and to the Prime Minister if this were so?

—With the greatest respect, I am not able to speak for the Prime Minister as to whether he would be concerned. All sorts of things about the Soviet Union are of concern to me and all sorts of things about motor cars are of concern to me. Whether I put them both together on my feet at Question Time in the Senate on this particular Thursday, Senator Harradine will have to wait and find out. I will not make hypothetical judgments about hypothetical information. If the information is available, I will make a judgment about the matter on the basis of that information. I am not prepared to do so now.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Has the Minister seen the editorial in today's Sydney Morning Herald on funding for the non-government schools? Does the editorial in fact support the Government's assertion that there has been an increase in funds and a redistribution of funds within the non-government schools sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has been the subject of long and, if I might say, quite vehement debate. Listening last night to the debate on this question of funding of non-government schools, I heard speeches by Government spokesmen on the issue which I thought were relatively clear, but the burden of what was being argued seemed to elude the Opposition. The facts of the matter are that there has been, under the program announced by Senator Ryan, a one and a half per cent increase overall to non-government schools and a 3 per cent increase to the most needy non-government schools. A redistribution has taken place. There has been a redistribution of some $4m from 41 schools to the most needy in the non-government school group. I give those figures because they seem fairly simple to me and I should like them placed on the record for the benefit of the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Zakharov asked me about the editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning which referred to the rally held at the Sydney Town Hall which took place, I think, on Monday night of this week and which has been the subject of some discussion in the Senate. I refer the Senate to that editorial, which states:

TALK.START.PARA: —You will read all of it?

—I think perhaps I will just read the bits which are pertinent to the argument that I am putting and then I will have the rest incorporated in Hansard so that honourable senators on the opposite side of the chamber can go back to their rooms and pick over it over the next week or two with the hope of a more intelligent question than has been asked on this subject so far. The section of the editorial to which I wish to refer states:

ANSWER.PARA: When there is such a discrepancy of views,-
such as manifested at this meeting-

we are clearly in the realm of perceptions, not facts. We have Scots College, Bellevue Hill, purchasing for $1.2 million a former bowling club to turn it into a recreation centre for its students. At the same time, the principal of Annandale North Public School has been forced to use a brochure to encourage parents to use the school.

Lost within the uproar of the rhetoric are a number of home truths: people with a lot of money have a great deal more freedom of choice than those less well off ; some schools have extravagant facilities for their students; the resource-poor schools in both systems have tended to decline rather than improve; and the debate has increasingly neglected the purpose of the exercise, the education of children.
Listening to the arguments brought forward on Monday night-
I might interpolate there, last night in the Senate as well-

it is difficult to remember that neither Mr Mulock nor Senator Ryan reduced the amount of money being given to non-government schools. What will happen is that the very well-off schools will get less money and needy schools will get more. The policy, so far, involves a redistribution of grants, not a reduction of them .

I have given the figures. The writer of the article in the Sydney Morning Herald , as a paid journalist, is perhaps putting it more explicitly and more clearly for the benefit of the Opposition in the Senate than any of us have been able to do. But it could not be clearer than that in terms of the principles involved, and the figures which I gave could not be clearer than they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does he remain steadfast in his determination to impose a capital gains tax on the people of Australia and his intention to advocate it both publicly and within the Government at every opportunity, as he said he would on 21 September? Has he found an opportunity since then to press his views on the Government? If so, has he had any success? Will he continue his public advocacy of the tax or will he pursue a more subtle approach, better suited to his membership of that group of lurking ideologues about whom he spoke with such fondness in a recent Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio interview?

—This is a very difficult question. I have not changed my mind. Insofar as the honourable senator has questioned me about my conduct, that is to say, have I taken every opportunity to advocate it, I may be a bit remiss. I do not talk about capital gains taxes all the time. I have a view about them which I have said in this chamber I will advocate at the appropriate time in the appropriate forums. I do not wish in any way to deny the honourable senator information which might be relevant to the pursuit of her political career, but I really cannot advance the cause any further than that. Insofar as an ABC program to which she referred is concerned, I do not know what she is talking about. If she wishes to pursue that, I will try to answer it.

—Is the Attorney-General aware that the South Australian Commissioner for Consumer Affairs, Mr M. A. Noblett, defines the word gobbledegook as meaning 'pompous, official or professional jargon'? Is the Attorney aware that Mr Noblett, in his annual report tabled in the State Parliament on Tuesday, awarded the first annual gobbledegook award for mind boggling incomprehensibility in consumer contracts to the South Australian Commissioner for Highways for a contract in which there is a clause that contains 438 words in two sentences, and that the Housing Industry Association came second because of a consumer contract with a 214 word sentence? Can the Attorney-General say whether the Commonwealth deplores this sort of gobbledegook ? If this Government ran a similar competition, would there be found similar indulgent and verbose legalisms? Does not gobbledegook often deny people their legal rights by confusing them or daunting them with fine print? Finally, when will lawyers stop perambulating down the corridors of florid, flowery phrases and start using plain, simple, clear and precise English?
—Mr President, I am feeling a bit sensitive in the light of that question.
—Do you seek the protection of the Chair?

—I know there are no untoward intimations underlying Senator Cook's question so far as the conduct of my own portfolio is concerned. I, of course, have never been guilty of the pomposity to which he refers. I do acknowledge that it is an endemic problem in both the legal profession and indeed public administration. It is a problem of which the Government is indeed conscious and which we are endeavouring, within the best of our linguistic and intellectual capabilities, to do something about. In fact, I think it has to be said that the drafting of Commonwealth legislation is among the clearest and most succinct, with the conspicuous exception of taxation legislation, of any probably in the British Commonwealth as a function of very dedicated efforts made by successive draftsmen over the years in my Department and Senator Durack' s previous Department. Anyone who doubts that suggestion ought only to read a page or two of United States legislation or, for that matter, Westminster legislation or, again, legislation in most of the Australian States. As incomprehensible as it may appear to most laymen, there is, of course, often a very good reason for the complexity of legal language because it is designed to achieve precision which is so often necessary in that situation. I say to Senator Cook that all we can do is our best. We will try hard and perhaps we will commence by the shortness of our answers in Question Time. I appreciate that and with that thought in mind I will sit down duly encouraged by the flavour of Senator Cook's question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Given the Australian Labor Party Government's new policy in favour of uranium exports, can the Minister confirm that the International Atomic Energy Agency, the authority charged with monitoring safeguards, has only 138 inspectors to cover 774 facilities? Firstly, is it not the case that inspections take place, at the most, three times a year? Secondly, is it not the case that inspectors often have to rely on interpreters provided by the country in which the reactor is sited? Thirdly, is it a fact that facilities must be notified well in advance of an inspection? Fourthly, is it a fact that countries can reject inspectors because of nationality? For example, Iraq will accept only Soviet or Hungarian inspectors. Does this not suggest that the safeguards treaties are mere documents of convenience and that a large number of signatories do so precisely because they are not restricted and because such treaties do not impinge on national desires and needs?

—I am not able, off the top of my head, to give an answer to a question which seeks the sort of precise detail that this question seeks; for example, if I got the figures down correctly, 138 inspectors for 774 power stations or something like that. I will seek an answer in terms of the precise details for which Senator Macklin has asked. I can confirm that nuclear power stations are not under continuous observation by International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors but there is, as I pointed out yesterday, a back-up system designed to trace significant amounts of plutonium that have not been accounted for in addition to the actual inspections which occur, I think Senator Macklin said, about three times a year. I think that is broadly correct. I cannot give more precise details than that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. My question refers to the explosive situation in the Middle East and, in particular, the conflict between rival Palestinian factions in Tripoli. As many Lebanese living in Australia have relatives in the region, does the Government have any information on the current situation there?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The best I can do is repeat the fact that the Government has heard reports that a ceasefire agreement has been reached in the bitter fighting between rival Palestinian factions around Tripoli in northern Lebanon. The Government can do no more than hope that that ceasefire which has been worked out by a high level Arab delegation in Damascus will hold and that differences can be resolved through negotiations. Too much blood has already been spilt in Lebanon. The Government hopes the ceasefire will help to alleviate the suffering of innocent people, many of whom are, as Senator Sibraa said, relatives of Australians and people now living in Australia and have been caught up in that cycle of violence and destruction.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the situation in the area generally, the Government has noted reports that Syria has mobilised additional troops and that Israel is preparing for a previously announced call up exercise. Taken together with the strengthening of American naval forces in the Mediterranean, these reports are undoubtedly worrying. However, the Government has noted also that the new Israeli Prime Minister has reportedly tried to calm anxiety during a previously arranged visit to Israeli positions in Lebanon and is reported as saying that he does not see any reason for special concern because of the Syrian mobilisation and that Israel has no interest in waging war on anybody, including Syria. The Australian Government welcomes this type of assurance and hopes that all parties will refrain from any further actions which could add further to tension in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. It relates to an article appearing in the Weekend Australian of 5 November concerning the latest warning by Dr Robert Endean, a reader in zoology at the University of Queensland and a recognised marine expert, that, because of a crown of thorns starfish infestation, the Great Barrier Reef faces destruction over the next 10 years. I ask the Minister: First, what action is being taken by the Government or government agencies to help arrest and control population outbreaks of the starfish on the reef in view of the past failures of State governments and other authorities to do so? Secondly, how will the Commonwealth Government ensure that the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service which will now have responsibility for the day to day management of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park will take action to contol the activities of tourist spearfishermen and professional fishermen who are greatly reducing the number of giant triton, groper and other natural predators of the starfish on the reef? Thirdly, will urgent consideration be given by the Government to employing a coastguard service to police the reef as one way of controlling fishing activities? Finally, will consideration also be given by the Government to Dr Endean's suggestion to put into practice a bounty system similar to that used successfully by other nations to wipe out the threat posed by the starfish?

—I did see the article in the Weekend Australian to which Senator Missen refers. I must say that I was alarmed by it, not having realised the seriousness of the situation or thinking that the situation had improved.
—You were told five years ago.

—I understand that, but I thought there was some more optimism about it than the article in the Weekend Australian revealed. Senator Missen asked me four specific questions which I was going to refer to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment but as a result of information which has just been passed to me I might be able to help him now. I am informed that there are large populations of these starfish on some reefs between Lizard Island and Townsville . There is still no generally accepted scientific explanation of the phenomenon. There is no effective method of widespread control because the infestations are far more complex in their occurrence than the impression given by the Press articles. Research is continuing and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority will consider supporting well-founded projects investigating the infestations. It invites reports of occurrences of starfish so that as complete a record as possible can be obtained. The Authority will survey where appropriate reefs on which infestations have been reported. That information might be of some help to Senator Missen. But his question is far more specific than the answer which I was able to give. I will direct the specific points which are, in a sense, constructive ones to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and try to obtain a response.

—Can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs confirm or deny the report in today's Australian referring to a document, prepared by his Department , which details 121 cases over the last two months of persons with very considerable assets receiving service pensions, often at the maximum rate? If so , can the Minister say whether these persons are receiving these pensions simply because they have artificially arranged their affairs so as to bypass the present income test on service pensions or are they, in some instances, in genuine need? Can the Minister provide the Senate with an indication of the range of liquid assets which these 121 persons hold? Finally, can the Minister indicate his best estimate of what percentage of service pensioners will be affected by the foreshadowed assets test?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can confirm that my Department has done another survey in respect of the problems associated with the service pension area and the intention of the Government to establish an assets test in relation to such service pension applicants. To do that of course it has examined a number of cases that have been processed through the Department. As Senator Colston has suggested, 121 such cases have been examined. Of the 30 New South Wales cases, 27 include details of substantial sums of money, ranging from $65,000 to $227, 000 and averaging about $120,000, held in non-interest bearing accounts, mainly cheque accounts. Because they have been placed in non-interest bearing cheque accounts, people have deprived themselves of income. On that basis they are able to apply for, and be granted in the overwhelming majority of cases, the full service pension. That is a clear case of income deprivation, and is one which, of course, circumvents the income test in respect of age and service pension.

ANSWER.PARA: Those cases also list extensive holdings in bonds, debentures, shares, life insurance policies, annuities, trusts and friendly societies. In all these cases the persons are wealthy, and in some cases they can only be described as very wealthy. I would estimate that those people would fall within the top 5 to 10 per cent wealth range in our community. There is no question that any of those people I have referred to, whose cases form part of this report, are in genuine need. Most of these people, by such contrivances and arrangements of their affairs, have been able, on reaching 60 years of age, to get the age pension five years early and to qualify for full service pension payments.

As to the second part of the honourable senator's question, the Department has estimated, to assist the Government in its consideration of assets test legislation, that of all of those approximate 350,000 people who currently receive the service pension 60 per cent will be unaffected because they are people with modest incomes and assets, 17 per cent will get increased pensions as a result of the 10 per cent notional charge that will be placed on assets, 20 per cent will get reduced pensions and 3 per cent will have their pensions cancelled because they come within the wealthy designation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I notice from the House of Representatives Hansard of Tuesday, 8 November that in answer to a question the Minister for Foreign Affairs expressed concern about the detention without trial or proper processes of law in South Africa of one Miss Catherine Hunter. Can the Attorney-General explain the attitude of the Australian Government to the detention of Bishop Muzorewa in Zimbabwe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bishop Muzorewa was detained on 31 October by the Zimbabwe Government under a detention order made under the emergency powers regulations alleging that he had made certain derogatory statements about the Zimbabwe Government during a recent visit to Israel. I understand that the original detention order was invalid. A second detention order has been issued under a different section of the emergency powers regulations, and Muzorewa is being held at the Goromonzi detention centre and is reported to be on a hunger strike. The Government has seen reports also that the Bishop's son, Mr Philemon Muzorewa , was detained for several days by people he believed were associated with Zimbabwe security authorities. We understand that the Zimbabwe Minister of State Security has denied that this was the case.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been numerous detentions without trial in Zimbabwe as well as instances of re-detention after acquittal by the courts on politically related charges, and these have involved both blacks and whites. The Australian Government's response to these events can be summarised as follows: We of course have an interest in the application of internationally accepted standards of judicial and human rights in Zimbabwe, as anywhere else. The Government will wish to see that the due processes of law are observed in this matter. The Australian Government remains very concerned by the Zimbabwe Government's continued recourse to emergency powers regulations carried over from the Smith regime which provide, among other things, for detention without trial. The High Commissioner in Harare is keeping the Minister for Foreign Affairs informed of developments. No doubt the Government will be considering further what position it might be appropriate for us to take to try to advance the condition of liberty a little further in that country than it seems to be at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer encouraged by the fall in unemployment on a seasonally adjusted basis in October? How long is it since the unemployment rate has fallen by 0.5 per cent in a single month? Does the fall in the unemployment rate to single digit levels give hope to the many Australians currently without work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fall in the unemployment rate from the last month to the most recent, that is October-depending whether we take the seasonally adjusted figure or the raw figure-is of the order of 0.5 per cent. There is a slight variation between one and the other. That I understand is the biggest decline in a single month since the current series commenced in February 1978. Naturally that is a very encouraging sign that the economic recovery is continuing and that the macroeconomic policies of this Government are working. I think we ought however to add one cautionary caveat to that in that the change in the unemployment rate reflects quite substantially the very large fall in the participation rate. Indeed, in seasonally adjusted terms, the number of people employed increased by only 3,000 during that month, but that figure is 71,000 above the April trough. That shows that over this six-month period employment growth of the magnitude anticipated by the Government and the growth rate which is the Government's objective are in fact being achieved.

ANSWER.PARA: But there have been some very marked fluctuations in recent months in month to month figures of the same indicator-variations of such size that it is difficult to give a rational account of them because, I understand, the samples upon which all these figures are based are turned over during an eight-month period. In other words, in any particular month seven-eighths of the respondents to the sample were in the sample during the previous month. Given that that is the basis upon which the sample is taken, it is very difficult to understand why the figures should have fluctuated on a month to month basis as much as they have. However, looking beyond the very large and seemingly inexplicable month to month fluctuations, the trend line is quite clear. The trend line is that the employment situation is improving to much the same degree that the Government had anticipated and planned for, and it is a clear sign that the Government's macroeconomic policies are succeeding in achieving their objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the meeting he and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations had with representatives of the Transport Workers Union on 21 October to discuss proceedings taken by the Trade Practices Commission against the union. Is it a fact that the Attorney agreed at that meeting to halt the Commission's action and pay the union's $10,000 legal costs? Did the Attorney instruct the Trade Practices Commission to cease proceedings against the union? On what grounds does the Attorney interfere with the workings of an independent authority carrying out its duties as specified by law? Is this another example of the Government's policy of corporatism which seeks to protect the interests of monopoly, labour and capital and which can only work against the interests of average Australian workers, consumers and small businesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no foundation in the suggestion that the Trade Practices Commission was instructed or directed to withdraw the proceedings in that particular matter. I do have a statutory power to do that should the occasion arise but it was certainly not necessary to deploy it in this instance nor was there any question of deploying it because that was the result reached by mutual agreement between the Government and the Trade Practices Commission as being the most appropriate course to follow in all the circumstances and in the national interest, something to which Senator Messner apparently finds it difficult to relate. The truth of the matter is that the agreements between the Transport Workers Union and the Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association, which had triggered the Trade Practices Commission action in the period since May, had been agreed to be withdrawn by the two bodies in question. There was, accordingly, no further foundation for the litigation to proceed on the basis on which it was originally constructed.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the circumstances of the Government agreeing to pay the costs incurred by the trade union in its defence of the matter, that agreement was reached pursuant to the appropriate provision in the Trade Practices Act which requires the Government to have regard to a number of criteria, including hardship for the body in question and more particularly reasonableness, having regard to the totality of the situation. In my consideration of the application of those criteria I decided a proper and sensible case could be made out for giving the union the relief it sought in that instance. I notice that a series of other applications have been made by bodies including the oil companies which are rather better equipped to handle the rigours of expensive litigation. But it will be a matter for further determination and consideration by me as to whether it is appropriate for legal aid, in effect, to be awarded in those cases as well .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier at Question Time I referred to an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald in answer to a question from Senator Zakharov. I was asked to incorporate the whole of the editorial in Hansard. I seek leave to have it incorporated.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The editorial read as follows-
NEWTON AND THE TOWN HALL RALLY

If Sir Isaac Newton had been a political scientist he might have put forward a law along these lines; for every political action there will be an equal and opposite political reaction. This law partly explains the extraordinary meeting on Monday night which saw the Sydney Town Hall and its environs packed with a crowd of about 7,000 people. The stated purpose of the rally was to protest against the cuts made by the Federal and State Governments to the funding of 15 top private schools in N.S.W. In fact, the meeting was an attempt to match the N .S.W. Teachers' Federation. The federation has been twisting the State Government's left arm; the supporters of the non-government schools have now determined to twist its right arm.

The rally had overtones of the passions aroused by the state aid issue during the 1950s and 1960s. This revival of sectarianism, after it has been dormant for a decade, has worrying implications for social divisiveness. One of the major achievements of the Whitlam Government was to defuse the political and social explosiveness of state aid. A complicating factor in the current dispute is the Federal Minister for Education, Senator Ryan. She has not explained her policies adequately. And she appears unwilling to do so. To her opponents, she represents the unacceptable face of modern womanhood-assertive, single, and threatening to the old ways.

Both she and the State Minister for Education, Mr Mulock, a favourite target of the Teachers' Federation, were strongly criticised at the meeting. What this indicates is that the purposes of education are being submerged by all the contending groups to the interests of politics. Mr Mulock's sin, as far as the federation is concerned, is that he has been too generous to non-government schools. The non-government school lobby believes he is not generous enough to their schools.

When there is such a discrepancy of views, we are clearly in the realm of perceptions, not facts. We have Scots College, Bellevue Hill, purchasing for $1. 2 million a former bowling club to turn it into a recreation centre for its students. At the same time, the principal of Annandale North Public School has been forced to use a brochure to encourage parents to use the school.

Lost within the uproar of the rhetoric are a number of home truths; people with a lot of money have a great deal more freedom of choice than those less well off ; some schools have extravagant facilities for their students; the resource-poor schools in both systems have tended to decline rather than improve; and the debate has increasingly neglected the purpose of the exercise, the education of children.

Listening to the arguments brought forward on Monday night, it is difficult to remember that neither Mr Mulock nor Senator Ryan reduced the amount of money being given to non-government schools. What will happen is that the very well- off schools will get less money and needy schools will get more. The policy, so far, involves a redistribution of grants, not a reduction of them.

The fear, from the non-government school lobby, is that once the precedent has been created of reducing grants to elite schools, other less elite schools will be made to suffer later. This fear is a response to the unrelenting campaign by the Teachers' Federation against any Government funding of non-government schools. Watching all this, Newton the political scientist might have proposed a second and third law: political opponents need and grow on each other; their growth rate is unrelated to the needs of the world around them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In answer to a question I asked earlier the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) claimed that I had misquoted a speech of his and that I had no substantiation for other parts of the question which I asked. To put the matter beyond any doubt I seek leave to table page 8 of the speech which Senator Button made on 24 October 1983, as distributed by him, the middle paragraph of which indicates that the quotation I made was absolutely and abundantly accurate. I also seek leave to table Press reports from the Australian of 25 October 1983, the Sydney Morning Herald of the same date and the Age of the same date, all of which report the meeting and Senator Button's statements. They were also drawn upon for the purpose of asking the question.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Until very recently few people in Australia were aware of the existence and spread of organised crime in this country. Today, however, warned by a succession of reports by royal commissions and other inquiries, the great majority of Australians are conscious of the threat that organised crime represents to the economy, the amount of revenue available for spending on necessary and desirable forms of community activity and indeed to our whole way of life. At the same time these Australians are conscious of the need, if a new institution is to be established to deal with this threat, for the new institution itself not to endanger the rights and liberties of individuals. For these reasons most Australians will welcome the establishment of the National Crime Authority. Designed to effectively coordinate and lead on a national basis the attack against organised crime, the Authority will nonetheless be constructed in such a way, and with such checks and balances and limitations on its powers that prejudice to the rights and liberties of individuals will be avoided. The Authority will be established by Commonwealth legislation, but with provision for extensive State participation in its operations.

When the present Government assumed office in March, it set about immediately reviewing the National Crimes Commission Act enacted last year under the previous Government. This Act has aroused considerable disquiet and concern in many sections of the community and any form of participation had been rejected by the States. The reasons were obvious: It gave no role to and lacked the support of the States; had ill-defined functions; had insufficiently defined and limited powers; and lacked overriding safeguards like oversight by the Ombudsman and regular judicial audits. In the course of that review, the Government published a Green Paper prepared by the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) and myself which raised and discussed the very serious issues involved in a proposal to establish a body of this nature. On 28 and 29 July in this chamber a national conference was held, attended by more than 100 representatives of Commonwealth, State and Territory governments, police, the legal profession, civil liberties organisations, royal commissioners and other highly qualified and interested individuals. The conference was remarkable for the informed, lively and constructive debate which occurred. While many diverse views were expressed, and while I would not suggest that complete unanimity was reached-or ever could be reached in an area as sensitive as this-there was evident by the end of the conference broadly-based support for the establishment of some kind of national crime authority provided that it remedied the deficiencies perceived in both the traditional royal commission model, and the 1982 National Crimes Commission Act. Copies of the Green Paper and the record of the conference discussion have been tabled in the Senate today.

Subsequently a series of discussions were held with the States and the Northern Territory culminating in a meeting of Attorneys-General and Police Ministers in Melbourne on 9 September. This meeting reached substantial agreement on a model for the Crime Authority which is now embodied in the present Bill. The Government believes that the proposed Authority will meet the major objectives and concerns that have emerged during the public debate on the Crimes Commission issue over the last six months, viz: The need to avoid the fragmentation of effort in the previous series of ad hoc royal commissions, and to ensure co- ordination and continuity in the fight against organised crime; the need to maintain intact the resources, and expertise of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and to ensure the continuation of its work; the need to take account of the many fears and concerns expressed about a permanent criminal investigation body with unlimited terms of reference and uncontrolled investigative powers; and the need to secure the active involvement and co-operation of the States. The question that is most frequently asked in relation to the proposal is why is there a need for a new body and how will its operation differ from police investigations as they are now conducted.

Police investigations are concerned essentially with particular offences known or reasonably believed to have been committed, with the starting point usually being the complaint of a victim or discovery by the police of the results of a crime. By and large, the police forces of Australia do an excellent job and there is no question of the Crime Authority supplanting those organisations.

However, it is of the nature of organised and sophisticated crime that particular manifestations of that crime-particularly in the areas of drug importation, corporate fraud and tax evasion-may not come to the attention of the police forces. Activities of this kind may be so intricately interwoven, may involve so many jurisdictions and may be so well camouflaged under apparently legitimate ways of doing business that they may well not cause any one police force to take notice.

The Costigan Royal Commission has shown that, by following a series of financial leads in a determined exploratory fashion, widespread and serious conspiracies can be uncovered. The techniques involved, and the need for them to be deployed by a national authority specially designed for the purpose, have been clearly described by Mr Costigan in a passage of his Sir John Barry Memorial Lecture delivered on 13 October 1983:

The first thing to remember is that the organisation of crime is directed towards the accumulation of money and with it power. The possession of the power that flows with great wealth is to some people an important matter in itself, but this is secondary to the prime aim of accumulating money.

Two conclusions flow from this fact. The first is that the most successful method of identifying and ultimately convicting major organised criminals is to follow the money trail. The second is that once you have identified and convicted them you take away their money; that is, the money which is the product of their criminal activities. Both these conclusions have now been accepted in both the United States and the United Kingdom and other western countries.

Tracing the flow of money, of course, is the first step. Once this is recognised as the appropriate course it is necessary to identify the techniques necessary to enable an investigator to follow this trail. Bear in mind that the amounts involved are large and the frequency of transactions great. Accordingly, in most cases use is made by the criminals of the existing facilities of the community. The banking system is used, as are solicitors' trust accounts, building societies and merchant banks, monies are transmitted overseas, property is bought and sold, shares are acquired, investments are made, credit cards are used, joint ventures are entered into, passports are applied for, immigration cards are filled in at every port of entry and exit, telephone calls are made, hotel bills are paid and so on.

All these transactions are to be found recorded in public and private documents or on computer tapes. The ultimate dilemma facing the criminal who wishes to acquire wealth so that he can enjoy the pleasures and facilities provided by our society is that the enjoyment of those pleasures and facilities results in a recording of his activities. No matter how careful he may believe himself to be in covering or disguising his tracks, the tracks are there to be found and followed. But the tracking can be done successfully only if the person making it is equipped with the appropriate powers.

There are many bodies in this community which have been given power by Government in their own discrete area; examples can be found under the companies legislation, Income Tax Assessment Act, Immigration Act, Customs Act and so forth. Some of these powers are far greater than I would wish invested in a permanent investigative agency. But because these bodies are limited to the area of their particular interest, they cannot see the whole picture.

The Reserve Bank is concerned with possible breaches of its regulations relating to the movement of money in and out of the country, but is not concerned with breaches of law within the boundaries of Australia. The Customs Department is concerned with goods coming into and leaving Australia but is not concerned with domestic transactions. A State police force is concerned with the activities of a person within the State boundaries but has no jurisdiction over any activities in another State or Territory. The Treasury is concerned with monitoring the activities of the banking industry and the insurance industry but cannot look at solicitors' trust accounts. State legal authorities are concerned with solicitors' trust accounts but not with banking transactions outside their State.

In the result, those who wish to do so can hide their activities from any concerted investigation by adopting techniques well known to white collar crime and which are on the whole very successful. My experience over the last three years has left me in no dount that the problem of organised crime cannot be tackled unless you vest in the one body, with all suitable protections, the power to monitor the activities I have described and to follow in detail all the steps taken.''

One of the most difficult policy questions with which the Government has had to wrestle is whether it is necessary or desirable for the kind of body to which Mr Costigan refers to be established with full traditional royal commission powers. After considering carefully the contrary viewpoints, the Government has taken the position-as did the Fraser Government before it with the National Crimes Commission Act 1982-that there are basic differences between the role of a royal commission and that of an on-going crime authority, and that this should be reflected in the makeup of the Authority.

The basic task of a royal commission is and has been to establish publicly the truth of a particular matter given to it to investigate and report upon: a royal commission is frequently called upon to clear the air where there is apparent public scandal or considerable public disquiet. On the other hand, the basic role of the proposed Crime Authority-although there are others as well-will be to operate as another arm of the criminal investigation process, gathering and assembling evidence for transmission to other law enforcement agencies and for use ultimately in conducting prosecutions. To this end it needs to be a standing rather than ad hoc body, accumulating expertise and becoming the repository of necessary skills and knowledge and the technical equipment to go with them.

Because of their different roles, the powers appropriate to be given to a standing crime authority differ from those appropriate for a royal commission. Given the traditional 'expose true facts' role of the royal commission, it has always been thought justifiable to deny the excuse of self-incrimination to witnesses before a royal commission, provided that this denial is balanced by a provision making the evidence inadmissible in proceedings other than for perjury . But where the gathering of admissible evidence is essential, as is the case with the proposed Crime Authority, it would be wrong in principle for this to be extracted over claims of self-incrimination. A different kind of balance between powers and limitations on power is required, because what is involved is a very different kind of investigative body. A number of deficiencies in the 1982 Act that have come to notice in the course of this year's review have been made good in the present Bill.

In the first place, there is now satisfactory provision for participation by the States and the Northern Territory. The National Crime Authority will consist of a Chairman, and two other members selected respectively by the unanimous decision of the Attorneys-General and Police Ministers of the Commonwealth and participating States. An input by the States in the selection of members of the Authority is thus clearly provided for. There is further provision for an inter- governmental committee to generally monitor the work of the Authority. Each State and the Northern Territory as well as the Commowealth will be able to be represented on this committee, which should give the States a clear window into its operations.

Secondly, the concern-widely expressed in relation to the proposed 1982 Crimes Commission-that the body would be able to roam at will over the whole field of its jurisdiction, without having to justify its investigations to those politically accountable, has been specifically addressed by the requirement in the present Bill that the Authority only exercise coercive investigative powers in the context of specific references initiated by the appropriate government and approved by the inter-governmental committee. There is further provision for the Committee to request the Authority to provide information as to specific matters relating to an investigation or as to the general conduct of operations of the Authority.

Thirdly, the 1982 Act lacked a precise statement as to the outer limits of the Commission's jurisdiction, giving it a general jurisdiction to inquire into, of its own initiative or at the request of the Attorney-General, any circumstance suggesting that an offence had been committed against any law of the Commonwealth or a Territory. The outer limits of the National Crime Authority's jurisdiction are now precisely defined by the description of 'relevant criminal activity' and 'relevant offence' in clause 4 of the Bill.

The combination of the precisely limited jurisdiction and the requirement for a specific reference or references will ensure that the area of lawful inquiry by the Authority in any one case is readily ascertainable. If the Authority should stray beyond that area, it can be restrained by judicial order.

A fourth perceived defect in the 1982 legislation was the absence of clear or precise ministerial responsibility in respect of the body. There should be a clear and unmistakable line of responsibility to, and control by, one Commonwealth Minister. Divided or shared control means no control.

The present Bill does provide a clear line of responsibility for and control of the Authority. Thus, under clause 16, the Commonwealth Minister may give directions or guidelines to the Authority with respect to the performance of its functions-directions or guidelines with respect to the performance of State functions will require the agreement of the relevant State Minister. Under clause 46, the Authority is required to keep the Minister informed of the general conduct of its operations in respect of references and its more general functions under clause 10. Further, the Minister may request the Authority to furnish information concerning a specific matter relating to its operations under a Commonwealth reference. A proper balance is thus maintained between the need for a clear line of responsibility to and control by the Commonwealth Minister generally and the proper interests of participating States in the operations of the Authority, particularly under references given by State governments.

Fifthly, under the 1982 Act, excessively wide powers were given to the Commission to deal with alleged contempt of the Commission. These have been pared in the present Bill-clause 21-to what is really necessary and justifiable having regard to the special role of the Crime Authority. Similarly, the draconian powers intended to be given to the Crimes Commission to deal with witnesses who decline to attend or answer questions have been reduced to what is strictly necessary and justifiable for the purposes of the Authority.
Sixthly, the present Government has decided-unlike its predecessor-that the Authority should be specifically made subject to the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman, and clause 44 so provides.

Seventhly, a further appropriate requirement-lacking in the 1982 Act-is provision for examinations at regular intervals by a judge of a superior court of the operations of the Authority with a view to determining whether the Authority has, during the relevant period, effectively performed its functions and whether it has done anything contrary to the law or trespassed unduly upon the rights and liberties of individuals. This is the effect of clause 47 of the Bill.

Eighthly, there are much stronger provisions in the present Bill, contained in clause 21, to ensure that individual reputations will not suffer as a result of damaging but possibly unsubstantiated allegations made during the course of Authority hearings. Whereas the 1982 Bill vested only a discretion in the Commission to order hearings to be held in private, or the publication of evidence to be prohibited, the present Bill creates a positive obligation on the Authority to so direct in circumstances where, among others, the reputation of a person would be prejudiced. Furthermore, there will be no protection in defamation law for any report of Authority hearings, except in so far as the publisher is prepared to rely on the defence of justification. These various measures, though quite inapproprite in the context of court hearings, reflect the role of the Authority as an investigative agency, and should ensure that the publication of hearsay and scuttlebutt does not become a feature of the Authority's operation.

Finally, the present Bill contains in clause 46 an additional layer of protection, quite lacking in the 1982 Act, in the requirement that any report made by the Authority that sets out a finding that an offence has been committed , or makes any recommendation for prosecution, is not to be made public unless the finding or recommendation in question is expressed to be based on admissible evidence.

Mr President, as a result of the extensive recasting of the legislation following the Government's review, we have, I believe, a much better Bill. We have legislation that will ensure that States will participate and play a proper and effective role having regard to their legitimate interests, legislation that will remove any vagueness as to the limits of jurisdiction of the Authority and will spell out a clear and unmistakable line of ministerial responsibility and control, legislation moreover that will give the Authority a proper balance of power, adequate, but no more than adequate, for its functions and responsibilities. The Bill will, I repeat, enable the Authority to discharge effectively its role in dealing with organised crime offences within its jurisdiction, but without prejudicing the rights and liberties of individuals. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incoporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

To be fully effective, the National Crime Authority to be established by the National Crime Authority Bill 1983 which I have introduced today will require access, in appropriate circumstances and subject to necessary safeguards, to information held by the Australian Taxation Office and royal commissions. To this end the present Bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Royal Commissions Act 1902. The Bill first amends the Income Tax Assessment Act to allow a royal commission which has received taxation information under amendments to the Act made last year, to communicate that information to the National Crime Authority where relevant to an investigation being carried out by that Authority.

Next, by way of variation of the general rule that information held by the Australian Taxation Office may not be divulged, provision is made for the Crime Authority to apply to a Federal judge for an order authorising the Commissioner of Taxation to disclose to the Authority particular information. The Judge must be satisfied that the information in question is relevant to an investigation being conducted by the Authority and that it is not readily obtainable by the Authority from a source other than the Commissioner. While the Authority will be permitted to use the tax information as part of its store of information it will not be permitted to divulge the information to outsiders nor may the information be used as evidence in court proceedings.

Finally, the Bill will amend the Royal Commissions Act to permit a royal commission to communicate to the National Crime Authority information or evidence in the possession of the Commission relevant to an investigation being conducted by the Authority. Mr President, the amendments to be made by this Bill will make a significant contribution to the effectiveness of the National Crime Authority but at the same time appropriate safeguards are provided against misuse and unjustifiable intrusion upon the privacy of individuals. The amendments permitting royal commissions to communicate to the National Crime Authority information previously obtained by them from the Taxation Office as well as from other sources will assist in the smooth transition from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to the National Crime Authority, a matter to which the Government attaches much importance. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Bill now before the Senate represents an important and historic development in the law and practice governing the prosecution of offences against Commonwealth law. The Bill establishes an Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions with the main functions of conducting Commonwealth prosecutions and exercising discretions in relation to prosecutions. Similar offices of Director of Public Prosecutions have existed in the United Kingdom since 1879 and in the State of Victoria since 1982. The experience of recent years, particularly the revelations of unacceptable delay and other deficiencies in the administration of the Commonwealth criminal law contained in the reports of royal commissions conducted by Mr F. X. Costigan Q.C. and Mr Justice Stewart, has made clear the need to revitalise and re-organise Commonwealth prosecution processes.

The establishment of an Office of Director of Public Prosecutions, which was foreshadowed in the Government's pre-election statement on law and justice, is an important step in this regard. It will interlock with the setting up of the National Crime Authority under the National Crime Authority Bill which I have also introduced today. Moreover it is a step recommended by Mr Justice Stewart and Special Prosecutor Redlich. The establishment of the office will proceed concurrently with the review of the Attorney-General's Department which is well advanced.

The circumstances relating to Commonwealth prosecutions are significantly different from those relating to United Kingdom and Victoria prosecutions and consequently the Commonwealth legislation will necessarily differ from the legislation enacted in those jurisdictions. At present, all prosecutions for Commonwealth offences, apart from very routine prosecutions conducted by a small number of Departments, are conducted by officers of the Crown Solicitor's Division of the Attorney-General's Department. These officers belong to the Deputy Crown Solicitor's offices in the six states and the Northern Territory and Australian Capital Territory. The number of persons in each of these offices engaged on prosecution work varies considerably from about 33 in Sydney to less than three in Hobart.

In consequence, it is necessary to allow considerable flexibility to the Director when first appointed as to how he will discharge his functions in the various States and Territories. In the large States, I would expect that he will establish his own offices at an early date. In the smaller States, he may well wish to exercise the option given to hm by clause 32 to enter for an initial period into an arrangement with the Crown Solicitor for the Crown Solicitor to perform the Director's functions in the smaller States subject to agred conditions and restrictions. As part of the review of the Department it is proposed to establish an Australian Government Solicitor in place of the Crown Solicitor, but in the meantime references in legislation must be to the Crown Solicitor.

However, whatever arrangements are in fact made by the Director for performances of his functions in the States, the Director appointed under the Act will provide leadership, guidance and direction to, and will set high professional standards for, all persons engaged in the prosecution work of the Commonwealth.
Role of the Attorney-General

The Attorney-General, as First Law Officer, has always borne the ultimate responsibility for prosecution decisions and the legislation enacted in England did not alter this position. This, in my view, is as it should be and, by clause 11 of the present Bill, the Director, in the performance of his functions, is made subject to directions and guidelines by the Attorney-General. These must however be published. Day to day prosecution decisions will ordinarily be made by the Director or his officials. It will indeed be very unusual for the Attorney-General to give a direction in a particular case. The possibility must however be provided for so that the Attorney-General may discharge his ultimate responsibility to Parliament and to the people for the conduct of the prosecution process.
Functions and Powers of the Director

The Director will be empowered to institute, carry on or take over proceedings for the summary conviction of persons in respect of Commonwealth offences, committal proceedings for Commonwealth offences and prosecutions on indictment for Commonwealth indictable offences.

In relation to matters or classes of matters specified by the Attorney-General, the Director will also be empowered to take civil remedies in respect of matters connected with or arising out of prosecutions instituted or carried on by the Director or institute proceedings for recovery of pecuniary penalties or co- ordinate or supervise the taking of such proceedings. Experience gained under the Special Prosecutors Act 1982 has demonstrated the value of such a power.

Under sub-clause 9 (6) of the Bill the Director will be empowered to give, where appropriate, undertakings to prospective witnesses that evidence given by them in prosecutions conducted by the Director will not be used against them in proceedings other than a prosecution for perjury. Several recent Royal Commissions have recognised the need to provide such undertakings in appropriate circumstances. The Director is further empowered by clause 11 to give directions or furnish guidelines with respect to the prosecution of Commonwealth offences to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, the Crown Solicitor or any other person conducting criminal investigations or instituting or conducting prosecutions for Commonwealth offences.

The Bill does not change existing law under which, except in relation to a limited number of offences, any person may institute proceedings for Commonwealth offences. It does however enable the Director to carry on, or take over, any such proceedings except proceedings instituted by the Attorney-General or a Special Prosecutor. Mr President, the Bill is a carefully considered and positive response by the Government to the national awakening to the need to upgrade and improve the system of prosecution of offences against the laws of the Commonwealth. Moreover, it meets the special circumstances and difficulties that apply in relation to Commonwealth prosecutions. Establishment of the Office of Director will meet a pressing need to place existing prosecution arrangements on a more effective basis. It will also, I believe, restore public confidence in Commonwealth criminal law enforcement.

The present Bill, taken together with the National Crime Authority Bill and the Special Prosecutors Act (which will remain in force) will be the means by which administration of the Commonwealth criminal law, particularly in relation to organised crime and coruption, will be rendered effective, expeditious and just. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC PROSECUTIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill makes amendments to fourteen Acts of the Parliament in consequence of the Director of Public Prosecutions Bill. The amendments can be placed in several categories. The first category represents amendments to Acts which vest in the Attorney-General an exclusive right to commence or conduct prosecutions or prosecutions of a particular kind. A like right will be given by the amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions. This category comprises amendments to the following provisions:
Geneva Conventions Act 1957, section 7
Public Accounts Committee Act 1951, section 21
Royal Commissions Act 1902, section 10
Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, sub-section 7 (7).

The second category comprises amendments to Acts which require the consent of the Attorney-General or an official to prosecutions. The proposed amendment will extend this function to the Director but preserves the Attorney-General's function. The provisions in question are:
Defence (Transitional Provisions) Act 1946, section 15
Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971, sections 11 and 23.

The third category consists of amendments to various procedural provisions which refer to the Attorney-General or an official. The proposed amendments will add references to the Director. The provisions in question are:
Crimes Act 1914, sections 20AA and 21AA
Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963, section 24
Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act 1972, section 22
Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973, section 19.
A fourth category comprises amendments to Acts to remove doubt as to the operation of the Director of Public Prosecutions Bill and certain Acts. The provisions in question are:
Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act, section 53
Judiciary Act 1903, sections 69 and 71
Special Prosecutors Act 1982, section 8.

Two amendments remain for mention. The first amends the Schedule to the Commonwealth Places (Application of Laws) Act 1970 to add a number of provisions of the Director of Public Prosecutions Act to the provisions referred to in the Schedule, being provisions that do not apply when, in effect, arrangements have been made with a State for the prosecution of offences under applied State laws committed in Commonwealth places. The amendment to be finally mentioned is that made by clause 29 to section 6P of the Royal Commissions Act to add the Director of Public Prosecutions to the list of persons and authorities to whom a royal commission may communicate information. Mr President, this Bill is a necessary complement to the Director of Public Prosecutions Bill and will enable the Director to discharge effectively the functions given to him by that Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS (NUCLEAR MATERIALS AND HARDWARE PROHIBITION) BILL 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the interruption of this debate, I had commenced to indicate that this is a private member's Bill, the aim of which is to prohibit the movement of nuclear materials to or from Australia. I had added that the proponents of the Bill had argued that this would in some way reduce the threat of the use of fissile material for nuclear weapons throughout the world. Indeed, if that were to be so, then, of course, everyone would support the Bill. It would be, beyond any doubt, highly desirable . Certainly everyone on the Opposition side of the chamber is opposed to nuclear armament and is implacably keen to produce nuclear disarmament and to reduce the threat of nuclear war. The real question is whether this proposed legislation would do any such thing.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of debate on this proposed legislation, a considerable number of statements have been directed towards what is alleged to be nuclear escalation and, therefore, by implication, the need of the great nuclear powers for more fissile material. Basically, I want to repeat that if there were any suggestion that an action by Australia to cease to produce or to export uranium would help significantly to bring about nuclear disarmament, we would all be very keen to support that. The facts are totally opposed to that situation. The facts are that the nuclear weapons in existence today were produced well before nuclear reactors were built to generate electricity. The argument being made is that the uranium exported from Australia for nuclear power generation for peace time purposes would somehow go to produce nuclear weapons. I have to say that the great powers of this world have far more fissile material, far more plutonium, available to them now than they would need, beyond anyone's most insane dreams of the multiplication and proliferation of nuclear weapons.

Anyone who has any information on this subject knows that the great powers do not need any more fissile material. The illusion that is created is twofold: First, that more nuclear weapons are being produced; secondly, that more fissile material is used for their production. I want to put into Hansard a statement made recently by Mr Richard Perle, who was in Australia recently. I was able to listen to him and to have some discussion with him. He is the Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy in the United States of America. He said these things:

It is thought practically around the world that the United States and the Soviet Union have been engaged for years in an arms race that is most commonly described as an ever upward spiral of nuclear weapons. We stand accused, to use a phrase that one hears commonly, of piling weapons upon weapons. And yet, the fact is really quite different.
This is important; I repeat his words:

Since the late 1960s the United States has been steadily reducing the number of nuclear warheads deployed in its inventory-to the point where we have today some 8,000 fewer nuclear weapons deployed worldwide than we had in the late 1960s. And the megatonnage of those weapons-the destructive power of those weapons-is today barely one-fourth of what it was in the late 1960s.
So there has been a reduction of 8,000 nuclear weapons.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still about half a million times more than the Hiroshima bomb, is it not?

—If Senator Chipp had listened, he would know that I have deplored nuclear weapons totally, as I always will, and I have said that there are more weapons than are necessary to destroy the whole world, and that that is an evil thing and is wrong. What I was saying was that many people argue that they need more fissile material to build more weapons because there are more weapons, whereas this shows that the United States has been substantially reducing the number of weapons and the megatonnage and, indeed, the fissile material.
—But other nations have the same ambitions.

—I appreciate and share the sincerity of Senator Georges. If he had listened to Mr Richard Perle, he would know that when Mr Perle was asked 'What happens with regard to fissile material for new weapons when obsolescent weapons are scrapped?', he said that there is a total recycling and not a drawing upon new fissile material. I make that point quite clear. The megatonnage is considerably lower and the fissile material is considerably lower , and the number of weapons is lower. Our aim should be to reduce the number of weapons enormously. The nations making nuclear weapons, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the United States of America, and so on, have an abundance of uranium and of plutonium. No contribution of extra uranium from Australia could affect that one iota. What is more, if tomorrow Australia stopped exporting uranium, there would be an abundance of it around the world for other people to use. There would be no shortage at all. Perhaps there would be, as the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) has indicated, a mild upsurge of price.

SPEECH.PARA: There is at present a very significant number of nuclear reactors for the peaceful generation of electricity around the world. They are growing in number. The estimate is that by the mid-1990s, 20 per cent of the electricity of the main countries will be produced by nuclear energy. It is estimated that the demand for uranium will double in the 1990s. One cannot turn away from the simple fact that uranium will be used, that there will be an abundance of it, and that the possibility of anyone with evil intent seeking it from those who do not monitor it is very much there. So that does not help one little bit. It is useless to say: 'Let us take away our uranium from the world'.
