By doing that we shall not have added in any way to the reduction of people's ability to make nuclear weapons. That is arrant nonsense. They do not need it. They can get it on their own. In any case, they have more.

But the important point is that not only does that not reduce the risk but it can, either marginally or substantially, increase the risk of nuclear weapons, because if Australia produces and exports uranium to the world, Australia will exercise its own safeguards through its own safeguards office, through its membership of the International Atomic Energy Agency, and through its own responsibilities under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. In doing so, it will monitor the use of Australian uranium through the whole of its cycle, thereby ensuring that it is used for peacetime purposes and not for nuclear weapons. If one accepts the fact that there is an abundance of uranium in the world and that there is a need for the world to use uranium for nuclear reactors, one accepts that the best way for us to work towards peace if for us to supply uranium to the world and monitor it as strictly as it is humanly possible. By denying access to our uranium we direct others to places with fewer monitoring requirements and fewer controls with the accompanying danger of safeguards being broken.

Some mention was made today of the fact that if one restricts the flow of energy to the world, it could be perilous in terms of world destabilisation. I repeat an important point which everyone must start from in debating this subject. The International Energy Agency which is composed of 23 of the main nations of the world, encompassing the whole range of political faiths, has indicated that there is not only a necessity, but also a growing and very substantially growing need for the use of uranium to generate electricity in the years and decades ahead. Honourable senators have heard me repeat what the Agency has said, namely, that all the conservation measures adopted, however strong, all the use of renewable energy sources and all the use of coal, gas or any of the alternatives, will not be sufficient to maintain the living standards of the world. Indeed, the growing world population-some 4,000 million now, and likely to be 6,000 million by the end of the century-will put such pressure on demand for energy that if we deny it the one significant substantial extra source, that is uranium, there will be a very substantial lowering of living standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Senator Coleman says 'rubbish' to a statement put out by 23 of the main nations of the world of all political beliefs. I always look with surprise-I should say astonishment-at any honourable senator who professes to know more than the collective wisdom of the 23 nations that unanimously made such a statement. The honourable senator is entitled to her view. If that is the situation, I can only call on the old saying: 'I would like to buy her at my price and sell her at hers'. It puts a very unreal value on statements of the IEA. My comment was made with all the kindness on earth. I repeat that the fundamental source for the statement is information from those countries. It represents their beliefs. They believe that the world faces destabilisation, first in its living standards and, secondly, in the possible political implications. I remind Senator Chipp and others who today have asked about the dangers of political destabilisation, of what the historians have written about the intervention of Japan in World War II. It was said that it was allegedly resources diplomacy that aided that tragic action. Therefore, we do not want to go into resources diplomacy. Quite apart from our position on uranium, weapons will be made and the best way of monitoring the position is by ensuring that it is Australian uranium that is moved around the world and not that from other countries which do not monitor its use as heavily.
—That is an odd position to take. How your intellect can sustain it, I do not know. I would have thought that you could see the weakness in that argument.

—I would be very happy to accept, and as always I do accept, the genuine sincerity of Senator Georges in his attitude, as I accept the attitude of anyone participating in this nuclear debate. I am trying to put the facts as I understand them. Like everyone else here I have a family. I want the generations ahead to live free from all war, including nuclear war. I have as much interest as anyone in that. The logic of it is clear. Let me put into the record a number of other facts. The Minister, amongst others, has mentioned the effects upon humanity of the continued burning of coal and oil. Indeed, I think that Senator Georges said that that is trivial compared with the use of uranium.

SPEECH.PARA: I have asked leave of the Minister for the incorporation in Hansard of three tables. The Minister has looked at them and agreed to their incorporation. The first table is headed 'Radiation doses (Man-rem/year) due to airborne radioactive releases from a 1000-MWe power station, integrated over a radius of 88.5 km'. It compares the effect upon the various organs of the body and the whole body of coal stations with chimney heights of different measurements and nuclear power stations. It concludes overwhelmingly that the radiation effects of coal stations are immensely more dangerous than those of nuclear power stations.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is in the emissions?
—That is the ordinary radioactivity of phosphorescent rock dropped on the world.
—There is a simple way of correcting that.
—So far nobody has corrected that. The second situation is this.
—There is a way of correcting it.
—Order! Senator Georges, you are interjecting too frequently. Senator Sir John Carrick has the call.

—Nobody so far has put up an argument to stop the radioactive spread from coal-fired power stations. Nobody so far has put forward any palliative to the acid rain which oil and coal power stations have been causing. Throughout the world it is killing people in thousands, it is damaging the health of thousands and it is destroying ecologies. Why is it that those who look towards the effects of uranium will not look towards the effects of acid rain? Senator Coleman may reject the proposition, but the IEA has repeatedly put out statements pointing out the terrible and permanent damage to the world ecology from acid rain. I point to the fact that some thousands of lakes have been destroyed permanently in Canada and that some thousands more have been destroyed in Scandinavia. The flora and fauna of this world are being damaged and tens of thousands of people each year die and many more become ill because of acid rain. Yet what do we do? When have we heard a debate here, except the other day by the Minister, on the greenhouse effect of the overheating of the stratosphere? The effect of acid rain creates enormous damage, both practical and potential.

SPEECH.PARA: I want also to incorporate in Hansard a table presented in the House of Commons showing the death rates per thousand employees over the period 1967 to 1976 in the United Kingdom for various fuel industries such as deep mines, gas, offshore oil and gas, oil refining and nuclear. Of course, the table shows overwhelmingly that the safest industry is nuclear. The third table shows the cost of power generation by nuclear, coal and oil fired stations in 1979-80. It shows that nuclear stations are considerably cheaper than coal or oil fired stations. I seek leave to have these three tables incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
