TALK.START.PARA: —The proponents of this Bill argue that if we do not send the fissile material we will contribute to the reduction of the threat of nuclear weapons in the world. It has become quite clear that that argument falls to the ground. Whether or not Australia were to add uranium to the world, there is such a surplus of fissile material in the world that weapons can be made in infinitely greater numbers than before. I have demonstrated that we do not need more such material to make more weapons, as obsolescence overtakes present weapons and new ones are made. I have pointed out that the Minister for Resources and Energy has said in this chamber that if we deny uranium to the world it will have two likely effects: Firstly, the price will go up because of a shortage; and, secondly, and more importantly, marginally or otherwise the threat of nuclear war will increase because since we will not be monitoring the use of this material, as it will be obtained from other areas, the danger is that there will be no monitoring and therefore there will be real trouble indeed .
—Doesn't it worry you when you are on the same side as Peter Walsh ?
—The honourable senator may have noticed that I commended him on the speech he made.
—It would be the first time in your life you have agreed with him.

—Yes, because undoubtedly he went to his Department and found from the speaker's notes that I had used many times when I was a Minister in his chair all those points on acid rain, the greenhouse effect and monitoring systems that I had made. Incidentally, when I made them the Australian Labor Party, then on this side of the chamber, rejected them. It was good to know that on the road to Damascus there had been some conversion of Saul to Paul. Who am I not to welcome that conversion of Saul to Paul because when the blindness falls off-
—He went from Peter to sweeter.
—I thank Senator Chaney for that interjection.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an enormously serious subject. The fact of the matter is that, demonstrably, no one is going to stop the building of nuclear power stations for peacetime generation. Contrary to the statements being made there is no turning away from those power stations except in the recessive situation in which there is a turning away from coal and oil as well. There are some 260 power stations in operation, many of which have operated for 25 to 30 years. An equal number is being built and about to be commissioned, and others are on the drawing board. So the real question is: What will we do if we stop this development.

Incidentally, perhaps I have missed it in the Bill but I presume the proponents of such a Bill do not want the free movement throughout the world of medical and industrial isotopes. Therefore, we would need to have some kind of research reactors and we would have the same problem of control; we would have the same problem controlling fissile material. I take it that everyone agrees that more and more the world will need the use of scanning isotopes, both medical and industrial. It would be a nonsense situation if we could not produce them. After all, although we make them at Lucas Heights, we have repeatedly flown them to Australia in the wing tips of planes because we have not been able to meet the demand here. In any case, some countries need to make them because they use short life isotopes, with lives as short as 24 hours. That, in itself, is abundantly not clear. I understand the need to bring this debate to a quick end. I repeat the principles involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the need for that?

—I think the Government wants to get onto general business; that is my understanding, my advice, in regard to the situation. The fact is that we have examined this issue and we all share the view that nuclear weapons should be absolutely eliminated if that can be done. I have pointed out that contrary to people's belief, America has done a great deal in the reduction of nuclear weapons in recent years. I have pointed out that in these times the making of nuclear weapons has absolutely no relationship whatsoever to the operation of nuclear power stations. They are two entirely separate operations. If we want to monitor the movement around the world of fissile material, and in particular to have that movement carried out under the strongest safeguards there are, the sensible thing to do is to get the uranium from countries that have strong safeguards, and Australia has some of the strongest safeguards in the world. That would be a move towards the very goal that the proponents of the Bill seek; that is, if we want to have less risk of nuclear weapons, we should monitor as closely as we can the movement around the world of uranium which is purported to be for in the operation of nuclear power stations.

SPEECH.PARA: If we think that the world can do without nuclear energy as a source of power, we are moving against the tide of unanimous opinion of virtually all countries of the free world. If people think that such a proposal is not posing the most enormous threat to the very survival of Third World countries and that extra 2, 000 million people who will join this cosmos of ours in the next 20 years, they had better get back to their drawing boards and look for another source of energy. Certainly in this temporary glut of oil we are using oil at a much faster rate than we are finding it. We are using and abusing the non-renewables- the oils, the gases and indeed the coal of this world. We will need to find another source of energy to bridge the gap for the next 30 years in the hope that nuclear fusion may then move off the scene. In the absence of that, I reject this Bill. I would welcome a debate in this Parliament, and would encourage such a debate, on nuclear disarmament. I believe it would be to the infinite betterment of this Senate if we were all to join together to discuss-

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot separate them.

—I would be very interested to hear Senator Georges on this-to discuss the common goals of reducing the threat of nuclear war. I think we would find a bipartisan support in the Senate on this subject. But, if we are to talk about the export of uranium, let me simply say this: On Monday, the Australian Labor Party made it abundantly clear that it is willing to export uranium free, quite clearly in its mind, of any risks both in its production and in its milling in Australia or any risks of it adding to nuclear warfare as it journeys round the world. That is the implication of the Labor Party's policy. I believe it would be sensible not to get involved in resources diplomacy. I believe resources diplomacy has produced wars, instability and impoverishment and I, therefore, cannot find it in my heart or mind to support this Bill. Of course I totally support the concept of nuclear disarmament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always intrigued and slightly astounded by the knowledge of members of the Opposition of the Australian Labor Party's platform. Let me first say there has been a lot of interpretion as to what I said on a particular current affairs program this morning. I do not want to denigrate the media in any way but I am always slightly alarmed to find that lead-ins to stories do not always match up to the stories themselves. The introduction by Red Harrison on the program AM, as reported in a transcript of the program which I have had made available, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrat Leader in the Senate is introducing a Bill to ban the export of uranium and Labor Senator Ruth Coleman told Pru Goward she will support the Bill .
My very first sentence in that interview was:
We're got Senator Chipp's Bill coming up which prohibits the export and import of radioactive materials. I will have to give serious consideration to the contents of the Bill as to how I vote.

That is what I said. Later on in the interview I said I would vote in conformity with my Party's policy. I have always made that position quite clear to Senator Chipp and the Australian Democrats. My situation does not change at all now because, of all the people in the Parliament and in this chamber at this time who say they have given consideration to the Customs (Nuclear Materials and Hardware Prohibition) Bill, I would say that I have probably given it more serious consideration than the majority. I agree entirely with the sentiments of the Bill. I am sure it was put forward in this form in an endeavour to establish a completely non-nuclear society in this country. That is commendable. As I stated on the AM program this morning, the Bill would have to be in conformity with my Party's policy. It is not, and I cannot support it.

A number of areas come into consideration. For instance, clause 7 of the Bill prohibits the importation of any nuclear hardware into Australia. Senator Sir John Carrick touched on this. I do not very often find myself in a situation of agreeing with much of what he says but I agree with him on the problem which we would face given that we do require medical isotopes to be imported or exported. It would mean also that there would be a prohibition of the importation of equipment which I might see as being necessary for the proper repair and maintenance of Lucas Heights. Mr Deputy President, as you would be aware, the manufacture of nuclear medicine does take place at Lucas Heights. It is a matter of fact. It is used. Society has learned to live with nuclear medicine. It is here to stay. Whilst I have a number of doubts about that establishment-I will go into those a little more in a moment-I consider it would be extremely dangerous if we were not to have proper care, repair and maintenance of that facility.

I want to look at the matter in isolation because of my concern with all things nuclear. That is a situation of which Senator Chipp is well aware. I have to question the necessity and even the advisability of having a nuclear reactor in Australia which provides 80 per cent enrichment. I might add that that is a much higher level than that which normally applies to the majority of nuclear power stations. Because of my concern in the area of nuclear power generation and the accidents, incidents and failures which have occurred in those establishments, I have gone to a great deal of trouble over past years, as I am sure all members of the Senate and the House of Representatives and members of the community are well aware. I have compiled a book of newspaper reports and other reports of accidents and incidents.
Quite recently we heard of the report from Seascale by a television documentary team about the higher cancer levels that apply there.

On Tuesday in response to a question, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Cohen, in the House of Representatives, indicated that a situation had occurred at Ranger where a uranium mine worker had received a radiation dose virtually at the annual limit after he and a fellow worker were knocked down by a tonne of yellowcake. Mr Cohen went on to say that this was the only significant infringement of environmental requirements at Ranger between April 1982 and June this year. The Minister said that Ranger Uranium Mines Pty Ltd had also reported eight minor or potential infringements during that time which had no significant impact.

We have heard reports of the situation at Lucas Heights and at Ranger over a number of years. I have gone to the bother of listing some of those, which I intend to read because they are important. When we consider the television documentary on Seascale, I think it is important too that we recognise that in the last few years there have been as many as 39 accidents or leaks with radioactive liquid from that facility. The point I want to make is that Lucas Heights and Windscale are about the same age. We have to anticipate that because of its age, if for nothing more, equipment is being used at Lucas Heights which will create problems in the very near future. I draw attention to the fact that as long ago as April 1979 the following report appeared in the Daily News in Western Australia:

In the controversy by Harrisburg, a previously unpublished report has come to light. Two million gallons of radioactive cooling water from the reactor has been dumped into the local Woronora River every month for the past 19 years.

I am sure that all honourable senators would be concerned to know that a water facility which is used by people in Australia is being subjected to two million gallons of radioactive cooling water being dumped there every month. The report went on to say:
Unconfirmed reports suggest that there has been a higher than normal rate of birth defects in the local hospital.

The reactor will be closed down in mid-September for repairs especially to two leaks which occurred in the primary cooling system in 1978. Workers have threatened to refuse to start the reactor as it is old, understaffed, and has inadequate monitoring devices.

That was in 1979. The facility is now four years older. As far as I have been able to ascertain nothing has been done about it. Let us consider what has happened at Radium Hill. In July 1979 it was stated:

A N.S.W. Government report on workers at Radium Hill, although not yet finalised, shows that since 1960 59% of those who worked underground at Radium Hill over a period of two years died of cancer; showing a death rate four and a half times the Australian average.

Page 1218 of the Senate Hansard of 11 October 1979 records Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, then representing the Minister for Health, in response to a question by former Senator Cavanagh, as stating that, on the information she had available to her she was able to confirm that of the 3,000 employees at Radium Hill 600 had been traced, that 22 of those who had died had spent in excess of 12 months underground and that nine of those-that is, 40 per cent-had died from cancer. On 30 October 1979 the New South Wales Premier, Mr Wran, criticised the Federal government for its lack of communication over a leak at the atomic energy plant at Lucas Heights. A newspaper stated:
A radio news item reported a radioactive leak of tritium.
The General Manager of the Commission said the leak had been isolated and the parts involved would be replaced. He said nothing had escaped from the reactor.

One has to question what type of information was available to him on whether in actual fact there had been a release of any radioactive substance from the reactor. As I said earlier, the situation in regard to Windscale is quite horrific. When I compiled the book of Press reports I found that over a period of years a large amount of radioactivity has been released into the water supply , which has been used, in turn, by cows in the immediate vicinity. The milk from those cows has got into the food chain. There is a suspicion-it is only a suspicion, because the report has never been made public-that that has been responsible for the increase in the incidence of leukemia and cancer. I turn to a study undertaken by the Manchester University of the situation in England in 1979. The survey showed that cases of myeloid leukemia had doubled between the late 1960s and the early 1970s. A report stated:
No chemical cause found but cause linked with increased radioactive pollution monitored off the North-West coast.
Cover-up is suspected because:
Public secrecy after radioactive releases when reactors were used for bomb production;
Unexplained failure to publish leukemia statistics since 1970.

Those results are in line with the studies in the United States of America where a two to three times increase in cancer, particular leukemia, can be found in the vicinity of nuclear plants. Despite that situation, and despite the study done by the Manchester University, the British Government had already determined that it would be relaxing controls on the dumping of low level wastes, preparing to raise objections to high level waste dumping and proposing to raise allowable radiation exposure levels to workers and the public in line with the recommendations of the International Commission on Radiological Protection.

As I see it if we are to have an ideal world in which to live, where energy is available to everybody, we have to consider that there are alternative forms of energy which perhaps do not have the inherent dangers which nuclear power appears to have. Of course, a number of these have been mentioned. I can remember some years ago-possibly as far back as 1977-when I was campaigning in Tasmania a proposal had already been put forward to look very seriously at providing land for the growing of sugarbeet to produce methane which was seen then as a method of replacing the liquid fuels about which Sir John Carrick spoke. I am always interested to note that Senator Sir John Carrick never gives consideration to that form of alternative energy. A report I saw in relation to the Tasmanian pilot plant estimated that something like 700 people would be provided with permanent employment. This source of energy would create less demand for liquid fuels and would contribute towards a better environmental situation which the honourable senator appears to advocate.

Australia supposedly has a number of safety procedures, particularly procedures which safeguard our health. I am a little concerned to find that a number of reports point out that safety procedures are not always taken into account. That causes me a great deal of concern. There does not appear to be adequate monitoring of the safeguards situation. I am sure that this matter will be taken up very quickly. A lot of research has been carried out in Sweden into the causes of such things as cancer and increases in leukemia. One of the counties in that country is issuing iodine tablets to people living around the four nuclear reactors to help protect them from cancer of the thyroid gland. I would have thought that that in itself would have at least turned on the warning light to many people that perhaps we are overlooking the most obvious form of cancer. We are concerning ourselves only with those forms that are a little more sensational and dramatic, such as leukemia and cancer of the marrow, which seem to have been developing at a greater rate since we introduced such things as nuclear power stations and uranium mining.

Let me refer to the Canadian situation. In 1980 deaths from lung cancer, which were probably caused by uranium mining operations in Ontario, were taking place almost monthly, according to a United Steelworkers of America employee. It is interesting to note that he states that 496 present or former Elliot Lake mine and surface workers were identified as having lung disabilities in whole or in part as the direct result of dust exposure in the uranium industry. He said:
'spills and breaks which spew contaminants in to the environment happen all too frequently . . . the affected Serpent River watershed remains destroyed'.

One can go through this report and find frequent complaints that people have been made aware of these statistics but have done very little about them. The Korea and South East Asia Forces Association of Australia has been demanding compensation for the alleged cancer causing effects of radioactive water used in soft drinks supplied to Australian troops in Korea. I could go on in this way for any length of time.

I commend the Australian Democrats for having the courage to introduce this legislation. As I have said, I will not support it because it is not in line with my Party's policy. If Senator Chipp wants further clarification of why it is not, I simply point to clause 6 which explicitly bans totally and immediately any exportation of yellowcake and hexaflourides. I am sure that Senator Chipp is aware of Australian Labor Party policy. He is aware that we have advocated a phasing out of the uranium industry. The 1978 and the 1980 Labor Party conferences reaffirmed that there would be inherent difficulties in endeavouring simply to close off an industry because of the employment problems that that would create and because of the difficulties that that would create for the economic survival of the company concerned and for any number of other reasons. That is not to say that the Party does not recognise the difficulties of uranium mining, nuclear power and nuclear proliferation. It is simply to say that because my Party has an unequivocal commitment to phase out Australia's uranium mining it is not possible for me to support the Bill. Perhaps at some future stage we will find ourselves in a situation where that position is not as clear cut as it is today.

This is an ideal opportunity for me to touch briefly on other matters which concern me. One such matter is the proliferation of nuclear weapons. A number of senators in the chamber at the moment were at a parliamentary committee meeting on disarmament some weeks ago which was addressed by Mr Dan Smith who is co- author of a book called the War Atlas. Mr Smith spoke to us about what was happening in other parts of the world. His talk was frightening because we learned, or I certainly learned, for the first time that a situation is developing between the super powers which means that in actual fact there is no possibility that anybody who might even be anticipating pressing a button will have the opportunity to do so because of a delightful program called ' anticipatory retaliation'. I draw the attention of honourable senators to that phrase for which I would use another word. The only other word that is applicable is the word 'attack'. There is no way that one can anticipate retaliation; one can only anticipate that someone is going to take action which means that one has to retaliate. However, if one believes in anticipatory retaliation, and I am given to understand that the United States of America does at the moment, what one is saying is that a program is already in hand which will mean that the Americans are quite prepared to go ahead and attack if necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —At best it is launch on warning.

—At best, which I understand gives us something like four minutes. That is also a very alarming situation. I want to touch briefly on the uranium situation itself. As everyone will be well aware, it is a matter on which I have spoken out many times both inside and outside this Parliament over the last nine and a half years since I have been in this place, and I will continue to do so. I want to say just this because it is most important to this debate: Twenty years ago we were saying that asbestos was quite safe. Twenty years before that industry knew it was not safe but governments did not introduce any safeguards to ensure that it was. We are now saying that uranium is safe although industry has known, and I am sure that governments have known, for the last 20 years that that is not so. Specific and particular attention needs to be given to safeguards. There is no way that one can simply rely on industry itself to adopt a fully safeguarded attitude. In this country kilograms of yellowcake have simply just disappeared. Admittedly, the material was found later. That is an indication of the lack of safeguard that we have in those areas where we should be applying a much more stringent attitude. I would suggest that perhaps now is the time for the Government to look at such things as non-proliferation treaties and treaties that we might be involved in throughout the world. It is certainly the time to be looking at the domestic situation and looking at safeguards, not only for uranium but also for all those other areas which create an unsafe working condition or an unsafe environment for the majority of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, there has been a lot of interpretation of what I had to say on the AM program this morning. It was the subject of a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) earlier today. I have made it clear. The transcript of what I said on the AM program is here. I repeat that the introduction to it says:
. . . Labor Senator Ruth Coleman told Pru Goward she will support the Bill.
I had a lengthy interview with Pru Goward yesterday afternoon. What I said then and what I am reported as having said immediately following that statement by Red Harrison is this:
I will have to give serious consideration to the contents of the Bill as to how I vote.
I have now given serious consideration to the Bill. It is not in conformity with my Party's policy. I am not able to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the Customs (Nuclear Materials and Hardware Prohibition) Bill I follow a speech by Senator Coleman. I take the opportunity to express to her my appreciation of her strength and courage over the years in her fight against not only the oppression of civil liberties but also her fight against those things which would lead us to catastrophe and in particular those things which lead to the development of nuclear armament and to all of those things which would lead to our placing the world under threat. I refer to the mining of uranium and the spread of the use of uranium and all its products. Her courage has been an inspiration. She has been active in the recent demonstrations in Western Australia against the increased use of nuclear armaments in the Indian Ocean. We support her in that. Her opposition to uranium mining is well known. There have been massive demonstrations in Western Australia against the things that will bring us to risk. I say that and I understand her position. Today I would not want to do anything different from that which she has decided to do. But I know the difficulties which she faced in making her decision and the pressures which have been brought to influence that decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me speak for myself. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in answer to a question put to him today, said that there is no relationship between the policy of the Australian Labor Party and the Bill before us, and that it could not be supported by members of the Labor Party. That is quite correct. There is no relationship between the Party policy as it now stands and the Bill that is before us. He failed to go on to say that within the labour movement and the Labor Party-there is a slight difference in that the labour movement is greater than the Labor Party-there is an opinion that the Bill before us is an advanced upon our policy. In fact it is the policy, as many members of the labour movement see it. It calls for a complete ban on the movement of uranium and its by-products, an absolute stand against the mining of uranium and its export, a complete support for a nuclear free zone in the Pacific and Indian oceans and in our region and that Australia should be a nuclear free zone. That is what the Australian Democrats have proposed, although they have gone too far. They did not indicate that there were certain measures in the Bill which would prevent research in Australia in the health area being undertaken. Nevertheless, the Bill as it stands places a complete ban on the mining, exporting and importing of uranium or any of its by-products or waste in or by this country. I thought that was the pure position of the labour movement. Perhaps that is in the past and there has been a slide away from the basic intentions of the party and its policy. That erosion commenced in 1982 at the National Conference and we thought at that stage that that was the end of the movement away from the basic position which many of us take as a matter of conscience. There was opposition to the mining of a material that threatens our existence, the mining of material that increases the radioactivity of this planet by a variety of means to the point that life of all species on this planet could become extinct. That slide went further. We find now that the policy which the Party adopts at this time and the policy of the Liberal Party as expressed by Senator Sir John Carrick, are fairly close together. If we examine them properly what they really mean is that every scrap of uranium that exists in this country will be mined and exploited. We cannot move away from that position because that is it exactly. Those of us who are now caught in that sort of situation or who are in a conscience position are now in a trap.

I recognise my responsibilities to the Party and the loyalty which the Party demands. I accept that. Nevertheless, I feel that it is necessary to express my view. In spite of the disciplines which the Party imposes upon me, at this point I say that the Party expects far too much from me. Party loyalty demands-there are reasons for the strict discipline to the Party-that once Party policy is determined, once a decision is made, a member of the Party must adhere to that discipline, to that policy, or resign. Let me say this: The question arises as to whether policies determined by the Party this week in the parliamentary sense are the policies of the party itself. That is where the quandary exists. My interpretation of Party policy, as expressed in 1982, was that there would be no new contracts, and a phasing out of uranium mining. My interpretation of Party policy is that no matter how much I objected to the change at the time, the Party, by way of conference, determined that. There can be no change to Party policy except by conference, and that conference will take place next year.

The bind which we face within the Party at the present time is that there has been a shift in policy. As I say, that shift in policy will mean the further exploitation of uranium within this country. That policy is in conflict with a series of other policies for which the Party stands. Why do I say that here? I say that here to make it clear that those who ignore the growing strength within the community against the mining and the export of uranium and all that that will lead to, will ignore it at their cost. The Democrats may have some ulterior motive for bringing this matter forward. Perhaps I ought not denigrate them in this way. Perhaps they do not have to accept the reponsibility for what they do. Nevertheless, if their motives are pure, their position is clear and their position is the purest in this place at the moment.

The struggle within the labour movement will continue. Perhaps it rests in the hands of people at whom we look somewhat askance because, perhaps, they do not express themselves well or perhaps they do not behave themselves as we think they should. Perhaps we have allowed the main struggle to rest in the hands of a few who are prepared to put themselves and thier bodies on the line. There is a tendency to sneer at that but they are, strangely enough, the vanguard of the movement and the movement grows. I come back to the point that those who ignore the growing feeling against this madness which has developed and to which we give some sort of support at the present time, will ignore it at their political cost in time. I do not know how one can express the feelings of those who look beyond their own time. Each of us, I trust looks beyond his own time. When we procreate we go beyond our own time. We should give the future generations a thought. The thought is that they should be able to live and to continue to exist in peace. We should make certain that every decision that we make here protects their existence.

There will be a vote here today. I could opt out and say to the Australian Democrats: 'You do not need my vote today because I think the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party will combine against the Australian Democrats on this Bill, with all its shortcomings; but nevertheless, as I have indicated, with all its worth'. But I will vote against the Bill because that is what I am required to do. There is one more thing that I will do. I will go back to the people who supported me in my endorsement from within the Party and within the movement, and I will ask them whether or not I am of any further use to them because what happens in this place on this very subject has become a matter of conscience. If it is accepted in this place that those who seek to protect life make that a matter of conscience then we should extend that conscience to the wider concept of protecting not only the unborn but those who are born and have to exist. If it is a matter of conscience in that regard, then it is about time that this matter concerning our very survival also became a matter of conscience. That is how I see it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —By necessity I will be brief. As a result of that brevity I will refer only to that aspect of this Bill described as the Customs (Nuclear Materials and Hardware Prohibition) Bill 1983 in terms of the mining and export of uranium. Before I start I want to say that while it is not true of a great many who would seek to prevent the mining and exportation of uranium from Australia I have absolutely no doubt about the altruistic and sincere intentions of the Australian Democrats in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The critics of uranium mining in Australia have a variety of arguments which they draw upon, seemingly as the whim takes them. One argument relates to the proliferation of nuclear weapons and the fear that Australian's uranium may be reprocessed into weapons grade material. That is an argument that would cast Australia in the role of world policeman, a role which clearly it does not have the capacity to perform. Australia's contribution to cumulative world uranium production to date is a mere 2 per cent. Even had Australia never produced a single pound of uranium, stocks of reprocessable material would have been virtually unaffected. A protest by Australia by refusing to mine uranium would be almost totally ineffective. It is argued that if the proposed developments go ahead Australia will become a much more significant uranium supplier. Certainly, that is the objective of the companies which have already spent several million dollars in exploration and development work to date. However, at best, Australia contains only 16.4 per cent of the Western world's reasonably assured low cost uranium resources. In terms of the proportion of the Western world's resources, Australia holds about the same reserves as Canada and slightly more than South Africa, both of which are actively developing uranium mines. More than a quarter of the low cost reasonably assured reserves are located within the United States of America. The only effect of Australia's withholding its supplies would be, perhaps, to increase slightly, in the long term only, the price at which uranium is traded. Even that is unimportant since the cost of the fuel is a very small part of the overall cost of nuclear powered generation. In other words, a total ban on the mining and export of Australia's uranium would be a pyrrhic gesture, at best, that would neither significantly reduce stocks of nuclear material nor slow down the further development of nuclear weapons.

I recall that Senator Mason made the point in an AM interview that the majority of countries which now want to install nuclear capacity are doing so to produce material for nuclear weapons. Perhaps wittingly or unwittingly, that statement is illustrative of the fear tactics which the anti-uranium lobby is using to denigrate the uranium mining industry. Like all such arguments it is demonstrably false. Senator Mason referred to four countries seeking to build nuclear power stations-Argentina, Pakistan, possibly South Africa, and Israel. He went on to say that the motive of their doing so was not to produce electricity but to produce plutonium for small nuclear weapons. He does not know that. But he would well understand, as most people would, that such an argument is likely to create unnecessary fear in the Australian community. It is more likely to create that fear than it would be if he offered the most likely reasons for those countries' decisions to build nuclear power stations. They are , in fact, countries largely devoid of petroleum resources. The international position, which at least two of them find themselves in-I refer here of course to South Africa and Israel-is such that their future energy supplies are uncertain. Of course they are turning to other energy sources. In fact, according to the International Atomic Energy Agency, in 10 developing countries- Argentina, Brazil, India, Pakistan, Korea, Taiwan, the Philippines, Mexico, Cuba and Yugoslavia-nuclear power stations are under construction or in operation at the present time. Egypt, Israel, Iraq, Thailand and Turkey are also planning some nuclear power generating capacity. Already 25 countries produce electricity from nuclear sources and 21 of these are planning or constructing further nuclear generating capacity. There are 294 operating nuclear power plants in the world today and a further 215 are under construction.

Senator Mason and Senator Chipp and the rest of the Australian Democrats-and perhaps the Government for that matter in some respects-may rest assured that a building program of that magnitude is not going ahead on the assumption that Australia will develop its uranium resources. Even if we do not proceed, about 84 per cent of the Western world's low cost reasonably assured reserves will be available to fuel these stations. Our decisions not to develop will be by and large thoroughly irrelevant. Even the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) understands the absurdity of suggesting otherwise. I remind honourable senators of his comments at the conference of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in September 1979, when he attacked the anti-uranium lobby in no uncertain terms, telling that conference:

They insult your intelligence by saying there are problems about proliferation; there are problems about nuclear waste disposal; there are problems about terrorism. They have told you all the problems but they have denied themselves the final responsibility of saying to you, having listed the problems, we now tell you how you can contribute to the solution of these problems by leaving the uranium in the ground. They didn't go to that. Not one speaker went to that because they knew that if every bit of Australian uranium was kept in the ground , it would be supplied from other sources.

That is the present Prime Minister speaking in 1979 at the ACTU congress. The arguments being put forward against uranium mining in Australia on the grounds that Australia has some sort of moral responsibility in this matter cannot be sustained unless it can be demonstrated that we can make a meaningful contribution to addressing the problem, if indeed there is a problem, simply by not mining our own uranium resources. Yet that is the assumption underlying the Democrats' Bill today and frankly, to me, that assumption is quite absurd. Australia has been developing a uranium mining industry which is closely monitored and controlled to ensure that operations are carried out with the utmost safety. The Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry quite plainly stated that:
The hazards of mining and milling uranium, if those activities are properly regulated and controlled, are not such as to justify a decision not to develop Australian uranium mines.

Subsequent inquiries have made it clear that those regulations are being properly applied. The Ranger inquiry commissioners, in their first report, released in October 1976, made a very important observation which must be borne in mind. They said:
In considering the evidence we have found that many wildly exaggerated statements are made about the risks and dangers of nuclear energy production by those opposed to it.

Honourable senators will recall that those were the comments of a commission appointed by the Whitlam Government to investigate the Ranger uranium proposal. More recently, in the 1981-82 annual report, the Uranium Advisory Council advocated the dissemination of more information so that the Australian public can make its own judgments based on fact rather than on ignorance and misunderstanding. Several organisations are seeking to achieve that. The Council itself notes:

The activities of both the A(ustralian) A(tomic) E(nergy) C(ommission) and the U(ranium) I(nformation) C(entre) are likely to be denigrated by those opposed to the use of uranium, but in the Council's opinion both are performing an important role in disseminating factual information.

Unfortunately it is true that the level of debate on this issue is generally very poor and misinformed. The very good work which these organisations try to do has been attacked, in my view, most unfairly, Those attacks are coming from a number of sources. The ACTU, as the peak union council in Australia should in my view be acting with a great deal more responsibility, especially since some of its affiliated unions support the further development of Australia's uranium resources. The facts are that the uranium mining industry is one of the most regulated and closely monitored areas of economic activity in Australia today. A vast array of Commonwealth and State legislation controls all aspects of the industry, from the actual mining procedures to environmental aspects and the impact of the industry on Aboriginal communities. According to a 1981 report on uranium mining laws in the Northern Territory, eight different pieces of legislation impinge on the single matter of waste disposal alone. A similar situation exists in respect of the protection of the environment, employees' safety and the contact of the mining community with Aboriginal communities in the vicinity of uranium mines. These controls clearly bear out the conclusion of the inquiry into the Northern Territory legislation that:

We have formed the view from our consideration of the laws applicable to uranium mining operations in the Northern Territory that those operations are ' properly regulated and controlled' in great detail in respect of all aspects.
The inquiry went on further to comment:
Although we have no way of accurately assessing the statement, we believe that it is likely that such operations are the most regulated and controlled mining operations within the country.

From my observations I would concur with that view. With that in mind, the Bill before us today, if we were even to implement it, would only deny Australia the opportunity to develop new export markets and destroy employment opportunities in several States which currently exist in this industry and would cause the loss of many millions of dollars in investment capital which would otherwise flow through to the Australian community. In a State such as South Australia, which had the highest unemployment rate in Australia in July 1983, standing at 10.9 per cent, it is nonsense to prevent the completion of a project such as Roxby Downs which will involve $1,400m in investment and which will employ 2,400 people directly and up to 8,000 people indirectly during the initial construction phase and many more during the later parts of the construction phase, simply to appease a jaundiced view of Australia's supposed international moral responsibility. Even if such a responsibility existed-I do not believe it does-it is plainly understood on our side of the chamber, and even by the present Prime Minister, that it would be a responsibility which we could simply not discharge. Delaying the development of our resources is achieving nothing except to deny this country the benefits which uranium mining has to offer.

There are several examples of where Australia has already lost opportunities. I will refer to one that seems particularly significant. It was reported in the Weekend Australian of 14 and 15 May last-some time ago-that a Korean utility, described as one of the most important potential customers for locally produced yellowcake, had joined a major Canadian company, a subsidiary of a west German company, in a major exploration venture into Canada's North-west Territory. The significant words here are 'exploration venture'. Because of concerns that the political situation in Australia could affect the reliability of supply, a major utility-a potential major user of our uranium-is looking for uranium in Canada while there are several proven deposits in Australia, potential mines, including Yeelirrie in Western Australia which the Australian Labor Party has already jeopardised. That project could have gone ahead and supplied all the uranium this utility needs. We have lost that opportunity because of the uncertainty which Bills such as this and others that the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party propose to introduce produce in the minds of potential customers. The repercussions of the decision not to grant licences to the Honeymoon partners and the standing threat, which has now manifested itself into reality, to withhold licences from such projects as Yeelirrie, Jabiluka and Koongarra are already being felt through decisions such as that taken by the Korean utility. A ban on mining will not prevent it from obtaining uranium. It will only determine the origin of the uranium and deny Australia substantial economic benefits in the process.

At present, about 10 per cent of the world's electricity is nuclear generated. By 1985 it is anticipated it will be 17 per cent and by the beginning of the next century, 23 per cent. These projections are not contingent in any way upon Australia developing its uranium resources. Except in terms of the economic benefits which our own people can derive from a positive attitude to mining, decisions which we make are all but irrelevant. The sooner the Government, the Australian Democrats and the anti-uranium sections of the trade union movement understand that, the quicker Australia will once again be able to participate in this developing industry.

It ought to be understood that the decision that the Australian Labor Party made recently in respect of Roxby Downs and the continuation of contracts already in place for two other mines in no way should properly be described as a pro-uranium decision. It is anything but that. In my view it is a slight variation from the ambiguity of the Australian Labor Party policy which has been set down. The ALP is simply saying that for expedient reasons which as yet have not been thoroughly disclosed by the Government, it has chosen Roxby Downs as some unique and special mine, allegedly because it has other minerals. The relevance of other minerals to the general arguments and the general philosophic thrust put forward by the ALP that there should not be uranium mining in Australia escapes me. A great cloud still hangs over what will ultimately be the decision of this Government on the future exploration of Australia's magnificent resource which can provide us with a great deal of wealth and employment.

I conclude by saying that in a recent visit to Japan I raised the very question of what would be Japan's attitude if Australia reneged on its current uranium contracts and chose not to go ahead with Roxby Downs or any other source of Australian uranium. The Japanese Government in a very refreshing and, I thought, unique and frank way, said that if that were the case it would consider it in the gravest light. It said that a decision to abrogate international contracts to which Australia was morally and legally committed would make Australia a potentially unreliable supplier, not only of uranium but also of other commodities. As the Japanese Government said, it could proceed to get uranium from South Africa, Canada and the United States. Such a decision by Australia would not affect Japan immediately in terms of its capacity to acquire uranium but it would cast us in the light of being unreliable suppliers not only of uranium but also potentially of beef-we are having great difficulty at the present time maintaining our share of the beef market-iron ore, bauxite and many other of our exports which I think run in our favour at about five or six to one . Of course, at a time when the Japanese trade surplus with the United States is such that there is enormous pressure from the United States on Japan to increase its imports from the United States it would be very easy, not only for commercial reasons but also for political pragmatic reasons, to acquire some of those products which we now sell to Japan from the United States of America. While the Bill may be well-intentioned, I believe it is ill-informed. I do not believe it has any virtue. I will certainly be voting against it. I am sure that every responsible, wise thinking member of the Senate will do likewise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It needs to be said from the outset that the Customs (Nuclear Materials and Hardware Prohibition) Bill 1983 does not raise for debate in the Senate today the general merits of the decision recently announced by the parliamentary Labor Party except in so far as that announcement permits existing mines at Nabarlek and Ranger to continue to export uranium contracted for and which is destined to move to export ports. This Bill would halt that movement overnight. The Bill-I will confine my remarks to it as much as possible-very starkly, very fairly and squarely, takes an absolute stance and calls for immediate cessation of import and export of nuclear-related materials here and now, as soon as it is passed into law, if it were to pass into law. Immediate barriers would be erected at the waterfront in law-
—That has been our policy for seven years.

—There would be immediate abrogation of contracts. I acknowledge the interjection that the absolute immediate cessation of imports and exports is the policy of the Australian Democrats. I think it has to be understood by those who may question what is going on in this debate that that is indeed the central proposition, indeed, the only proposition in the Bill. The substance of the Bill is contained in two short sentences. Clause 6 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The exportation of any nuclear materials from Australia is prohibited absolutely.
Clause 7 reads:
The importation of any nuclear hardware into Australia is prohibited absolutely .

I believe that the narrowest reading of ALP policy cannot support those clauses. The answer from this side of the chamber to the Bill is that it elevates a very legitimate concern into such an absolute principle with such an immediate effect that we cannot support it. We cannot support it today. We could not have supported it last Thursday had it come on for debate because of the devasting effect it would have on existing operations at Nabarlek and Ranger and the crippling effect it would have on the operations of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission at Lucas Heights which is concerned with research and with the production of various materials, including medical isotopes. We believe that certainly ought not to be jeopardised.

We do not take the simplistic approach which, I believe, this Bill takes. We do not, thereby, accept the unfettered development subject only to market forces which underlies the Liberal and National parties' approach to these questions. The national platform of the Liberal Party does not even mention uranium. It does speak of market forces governing resource development. Our platform is both more complex and realistic than either alternative represented on the other side of the chamber.

It is more complex because we have a very real concern with the risks of nuclear proliferation and, therefore, are strong advocates of adherence to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. But within that Treaty itself the tension which is apparent in our policy is recognised. Article I of the Treaty reads:

Each nuclear-weapon State Party to the Treaty undertakes not to trasnfer to any recipient whatsoever nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices or control over such weapons or explosive devices directly, or indirectly, and not in any way to assist, encourage, or induce any non-nuclear-weapon State to manufacture or otherwise acquire nucelar weapons or other nuclear explosive devices, or control over such weapons or explosive devices.
Article IV reads:

Nothing in this Treaty shall be interpreted as affecting the inalienable right of all the Parties to the Treaty to develop research, production and use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes without discrimination and in conformity with Articles I and II of this Treaty.

So there within the Treaty, which I believe holds out the only hope to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons and thereby the increase in the possibility of a nuclear holocaust overwhelming the whole of mankind's history, the tension is present. It seems to me that the only rational way to resolve the tension in fulfilling Article IV is to have such stringent safeguards and conditions attached to the fulfillment of that Article that Article I is not put in jeopardy. The two are linked, but I believe that the Australian Democrats, in this Bill, forge such an absolute link between the export of Australian uranium, from the existing mines at Ranger and Nabarlek, and the threat of nuclear holocaust that they do a disservice to the peace movement, of which I count myself a member and in which I intend to continue. I know that in this matter Senator Chipp thinks that I am naive, perhaps, or even hypocritical.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I withdraw that totally. I regret saying that.

—Thank you. I certainly acknowledge that those who have brought this Bill into the chamber do so in good will, and I acknowledge the conscientious reservations of those on this side of the chamber, but I honestly believe that all those on this side of the chamber can in good faith repudiate this Bill. To explain why that can be done in good faith, I assert that there are two very down to earth, realistic reasons why support for the Bill cannot be given.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, we came into office in March 1983, after seven years in the political wilderness, during which time, and certainly in the face of our policy, mines were established at Ranger and Nabarlek. To pass this Bill into law would be to immediately suspend or even destroy the livelihood of hundreds of Australian workers on the sites and in associated transport operations and would also place in jeopardy the Aboriginal communities which have negotiated certain settlements in relation to the use of their land. We will not be party to such an immediate crippling impact. To invite us to do so is to invite us to emulate the very worst practices of some of those in the private sector, and that is something which this Government will not do.

The second reason-I plead with Senator Chipp; I really require an answer on this one-the second realistic, compassionate and utterly humane reason for rejecting the simplistic approach of this Bill lies in its proposal to raise an absolute barrier to the import of nuclear hardware, as it is defined. That cannot be supported by any Australian, because it could well disable the only nuclear reactor operating in Australia, at Lucas Heights in Sydney. It is a publicly funded facility, largely devoted to research, operated by a commission which reports annually to the Parliament. It is not a private organisation or firm or a profit-seeking enterprise being conducted simply for commercial gain in a manner outside the scope of parliamentary scrutiny. If one refers to the thirtieth annual report of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, which covers the year 1981-82, one finds there that the Commission, in supporting the continued operation of the HIFAR reactor, states:

HIFAR is a unique national facility which provides a focus for an Australian nuclear research program. It is used by the Commission in its research programs, by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) for such services as neutron activation analysis and for irradiation studies. Neutron beams from HIFAR are used by some 70 scientists each year from the 17 Australian universities for advanced studies of the structure of matter. These latter studies are arranged through the Australian Institute of Nuclear Science and Engineering (AINSE).

I do not place so much weight on that, though I should have thought that the desire, often stated by Senator Macklin, to see Australia intellectual resources devoted full to understanding the whole range of matter, would have found something to which to respond in that paragraph. I quoted it only for completeness. The second paragraph is more important. It states:

HIFAR is indispensable for the domestic production of most of the radioisotopes used in Australia in industry and medicine. Radiopharmaceuticals to an annual value of about $2 million are distributed to hospitals throughout Australia for use in nuclear medicine departments for the benefit of more than 150,000 patients annually. While many of these radioisotopes could be imported, a domestic production capability is considered highly desirable to ensure reliability of supply competitive prices and local research and development capability.
The third paragraph states:
HIFAR operations provide the means for maintaining practical experience in nuclear reactor technology and its regulation.

I have spent some time on this because it more than adequately permits members of the Senate, in utter good faith and conscientiously, to reject the Bill. On page 52 of the annual report, the Commission goes on to say:

The most intense neutron field in the HIFAR fuel core is located in the region of a number of hollow fuel element rigs. These rigs were used during the year mainly for the production of medical radioisotopes and the irradiation of SYNROC , a synthetic material under study for the long-term storage of radioactive waste products.

There we have it, where the Commission explains that it supports the continuation of the HIFAR reactor because of the range of programs to which it is committed, including those to which we ought to give the gravest concern and devote much of our research resources and scarce dollars raised by the taxpayer- namely, in relation to devising a means to dispose of waste. Those experiments in relation to synroc hold out some hope for the future and the solving of that admittedly difficult problem in relation to the operation of the nuclear fuel cycle. Of course, in relation to the provision of radioisotopes, pharmaceutical medical isotopes, I believe that the 150,000 patients annually in Australia who make use of that provision ought to be considered. They certainly ought not to be put in jeopardy, because it is clear from the report that rather than buying a new reactor, the Government has decided to initiate a HIFAR refurbishing program at an estimated cost of $4.7m over five years. It is said in the report, for example:

The present emergency core cooling system which is manual in operation will be converted to automatic and its layout, piping and testing will be upgraded. This will be supported by considerable analytical effort verifying that the required level of reliability has been met and that its performance will be adequate under accident conditions.

That will certainly require the importation of some types of the nuclear hardware which this Bill would not permit to be imported and, therefore, the Bill would lead to a more dangerous situation in the operation of that facility needed within the Australian community.

For those reasons, which should commend themselves to all honourable senators, I certainly cannot support the Bill. Looking at the Bill in relation to the actual impact, what it seeks to do by law, I believe that certainly my attitude is consonant with the very core of Australian Labor Party policy and certainly is able to be supported by any honourable senator in good faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the great thinkers of our time, the late Arthur Koestler, wrote these words: 'The self-induced extinction of all life on this planet is now approaching a statistical certainty'. I do not know that that statement can be sensibly challenged by any thinking or caring person. The reason for his statement was uranium. It is the basic reason why Koestler wrote those words. He did not write them because of the biological and chemical weapons that the human race now has at its disposal, terrible, shocking, terrifying though they are; he did not say it because of the nerve gases that both sides have created in our insanity to destroy. He said it because of uranium. That is what this debate is about-the banning, the mining, and the milling and exporting of uranium from Australia, and the banning of devices to assist the nuclear industry in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As I stand here today, 50,000 nuclear devices are in existence. Thirty thousand of them are owned by the United States and 20,000 are owned by the Soviet Union. Of that 50,000 devices, 20,000 are pointed at human beings. Twelve thousand devices owned by the United States are pointed at targets in Russia and Europe and about 8,000 owned by the Soviet Union and the Eastern Bloc are pointed at Europe and the United States and, according to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), one or two are, perchance, pointed at Australia. The magnitude of some of those devices passes beyond my comprehension. I humbly admit that my finite mind cannot comprehend the destructive power of the 50 megatonne weapon. As I understand it, it is much greater in its destructive power than the sum total of all the bombs and shells exploded during the Second World War over a six-year period. I cannot comprehend that, but is a fact. Even more chillingly, such a weapon would fit under the desk in front of me as I speak. The way in which some speakers today have spoken, particularly those on the Opposition side of the House, seemed to ignore the fact that every one of those 50,000 nuclear devices would not be there today and the world would not be on the brink of self -induced extinction if it were not for the element, uranium. I think that is a fair statement. I do not think it can be challenged in any logic.

Without uranium there would not be this unspeakable, unthinkable danger to the human race. There would be no threat to children or, as Senator Georges said, there would be no threat to the unborn. Therefore, by contributing in any way to the construction of nuclear devices which threaten life on this planet, we are not committing an offence against logic; we are committing an offence against morality, as Senator Georges so passionately, eloquently and sincerely said. I agree with what he said, namely, that one of the most immoral things that you, Mr Deputy President, and I can do during our lifetimes on this planet is to commit an act of omission or commission that endangers the lives, the happiness and the health of the unborn. There is no more unspeakable sin-I use that word advisedly-against morality, against God, and against our whole existence than to do something or to allow something to be done that will endanger the unborn, or, for that matter, the children who can do nothing against the actions we undertake. I will come to the issue of disarmament in a moment.

I wanted to put on the record at the beginning of this speech what uranium is. Uranium is not just another element. It does not provide just another means of warfare. It introduces a whole new concept into the contemplation of existence and survival because, as I understand it, for the first time in our history, we now have the capacity-one does not want to get too maudlin about it-almost to wipe out the human race. In a global nuclear war almost all of the human race would be demobilised within about six minutes. All of us would then take about five days to die. With the deployment of the Cruise missile which, again as I understand it, in some cases reaches its destination within five five or six minutes of its being launched, the day of consultation over the hotline is over. There is now an absurdity in the concept that once the Cruise missile with its atomic warhead or the SS20 is launched, Andropov and Reagan could pick up a telephone and try to talk to each other. The time is no longer there for consultation. We have now reached a stage which, to use the horrific jargon, is one of launch on warning.

If the computer systems of the Soviet Union or the United States register a pre -emptive strike, there is no time for consultation. If the computer says that a country is having a pre-emptive strike, that country launches on that warning. The launching entails the letting-go of every nuclear device a country has towards every major city that the enemy has. How many times, Mr Deputy President , has the world been on red alert because of a computer error? As I understand it, a recent occurrence was in the late 1970s. In 1979 the world was on a three minutes red alert and counting. Computer errors have been caused by some idiot in Washington leaving a war game in a computer; then a series of freak circumstances occurred, circumstances as absurd as the registering of a flock of geese on a scanner in Alaska. That, compounded with other phenomena, put the computer on red alert and the world was counting. This is the sort of new situation in which we find ourselves.

The point I am making today is that this Government in its decision to expand massively the uranium industry has been blind to many alternatives and blind to its own policies. I listened carefully to what Senator Tate had to say. I admired almost all speeches from the Labor side today. I remind Senator Tate of Labor Party policy. I confess that I will quote only a small section of Labor Party policy and I acknowledge that there are many qualifications to this particular section I will put into the record, particularly the qualifications known as the Hogg amendments. What I do read into the record from the ALP policy is:
Our minimum position would be a total unequivocal commitment to phase out Australia's involvement in the uranium industry.

There is nothing equivocal about that; there is nothing doubtful about its meaning in English. Even if we were to add the Hogg amendment which provides that certain projects might be continued where the mining of uranium is incidental to the mining of other metals, there are still many superlatives in that policy statement: 'Our minimum position'-superlative No. 1-'would be a total'-another superlative-'unequivocal'-another superlative-'commitment to phase out'-another superlative-'Australia's involvement in the uranium industry' . When one puts that next to the decision of last week to mine uranium from Roxby Downs-the largest single uranium mine in the world-one must ask the question: 'Is that decision not a betrayal of an election promise to phase out uranium mining in Australia?' I concede in passing the point raised by Senator Georges and Senator Tate that there is a defect in the simple Bill which I brought forward, namely, the provision for a total prohibition on the importation of nuclear gear. But that should not concern those honourable senators who want to vote to phase out uranium mining. A simple amendment in the Committee stage would take care of that. The reason for its insertion should be clear to Senator Tate, of all people, who happens to have some extraordinary people in his State, like Premier Robin Gray, who constantly talk about the erection of nuclear reactors in Tasmania. They are supported by Senator Peter Rae who, if I do not misrepresent him, wants to put one on some obscure island in Bass Strait. That sort of policy statement was so chilling, at least to me, that I believed that the insertion of that kind of total prohibition of nuclear gear was necessary.

Let me mention the facts that the Government has ignored. Nuclear power, even if it supplied all of the world's electricity, would still provide no more than between 4 per cent and 8 per cent of the world's energy needs. From what Senator Sir John Carrick said, one would think that the world runs almost entirely on electicity. There is confustion about electricity and energy. I state now that electricity, to take the top figure, provides only 8 per cent of the world's total energy needs and, of all that electricity, nuclear power provides only about 10 per cent. Therefore, nuclear power today provides only 10 per cent of 8 per cent of the world's total energy needs. I never was a scholar in mathematics but I think that means that about 0.8 per cent of the world's total energy needs is provided by the processing of uranium. So we are not talking about a situation where, if we were to stop supplying the world with our uranium, the world would cese. That is an absurdity. Senator Crichton-Browne, who has just graced Japan with his presence, came back with a story that suggests that Japanese industry will grind to a halt if we do not supply it with uranium. Uranium supplies 0.8 per cent of the world's total energy needs.

We wonder to what extent the underdeveloped countries of, say, Indonesia, the Philippines, Bangladesh, India and Pakistan would benefit from nuclear power even if it were developed in those countries. The Minister alleges-he constantly talks about this-that our withdrawal from the market would not affect the world consumption of uranium. I dispute that. Senator Walsh concedes that if we withheld our uranium the world price would rise. Of course it would. He concedes that but says it would rise a minimal amount.

TALK.START.PARA: —Marginal.

—I am sorry; marginal. That is a concession for which we Democrats are grateful. We dispute his adjective; we believe it would rise to a significant extent because, if we did withdraw something like 25 per cent of the Western world's known supplies, surely the law of supply and demand would mean that the world's price would rise.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, and as Senator Macklin said in a magnificent contribution to this debate last week, producing electricity from uranium is now becoming non -viable. He gave the example of the United States, where no new reactor has been ordered since the late 1970s and the orders for several reactors have been cancelled. It is now becoming not economically viable to produce electricity from uranium. An increase in the world price of uranium puts additional pressure on those nations contemplating the substitution of a form of energy with electricity from uranium.

Mr Deputy President, at this time the world quivers on the point of self- induced extinction because of the proliferation of nuclear weapons. I remind those speakers who said there is no connection between uranium and weapons that every nuclear weapon comes from uranium. President Ronald Reagan has stated that , in the next three or four years, he will create 11,000 more nuclear warheads. This is happening at a time when millions of ordinary human beings around the world are concerned about their future. What a magnificent example to the world it would be if, out of all the greed and commercial lust that abounds in our society, one country, Australia, stood up at this time and said: 'We are prepared to make a sacrifice for the sake of the safety of the human race; we are prepared even to allow our hip pocket nerve to be hurt by not getting cheap dollars from uranium mining, to make a sacrifice and accept perhaps a lower standard of living'. What a significant message would be sent around the world if one of the world's largest suppliers of uranium were, on a matter of principle, prepared to make a sacrifice. What sort of encouragement and inspiration would that be to the 70 per cent of West Germans who feel under seige because of the deployment of cruise missiles. One of the things I believe this world desperately needs is a sign from some entity that it is prepared to make the sacrifice. Australia, among all nations, small in population though we are, has this unique opportunity to give that example.

The Government has not given enough consideration to alternative energy sources . It has ignored the fact that there are cheap, viable and renewable energy resources which are ready to be employed now. A wind energy project in San Francisco will provide electricity for 450,000 people at a real cost of 3.5c a kilowatt hour. One wonders why successive Ministers in this country, both Labor and Liberal, have not grasped the challenge of being able to create electricity through wind energy at what I believe to be a cheaper cost than even Mr Gray's precious hydro-electric schemes could provide it.

Brazil's program to produce alcohol from sugar cane is saving $14m a year in oil imports. It provides domestic employment, saves oil and eases the country's balance of payments problems. The Sanyo corporation is about to manufacture photovoltaic cells as roof tiles. Covering one quarter of a house with the tiles provides enough electricity for day time needs. Each tile is now down to a cost of $10 each. These are the sorts of things that are happening in other parts of the world. Why do Australians and Australia's Ministers who are in charge of these matters not have a go at them also? Certainly we have the know how, we have the resources.

This Government has wrongly concluded that the world must have our uranium. We challenge that. The Government has accepted the fait accompli of the world's 50, 000 nuclear warheads as a reason for continuing to sell uranium and runs the risk of fuelling the arms race. Of course, ending the nuclear industry will not make those 50,000 nuclear warheads disappear but, as Mr Justice Fox said, to continue the nuclear industry will produce more nuclear weapons. Closing down the nuclear industry tomorrow will help control and avert nuclear proliferation. I make that point very strongly. The Australian Democrats seem to be the only party in this Senate putting that point of view. Closing down the nuclear industry will control and avert nuclear proliferation. The nuclear industry currently provides a benign cover for developing bombs. Ending the civil nuclear industry would leave any remaining nuclear activity with an unmistakable military intent. Such blatant moves would then be very easily identified, be more politically repugnant and thus more easily opposed. As long as the nuclear industry continues it will provide a smokescreen for mushroom clouds.

I ask the Senate to contemplate one thing that does send nervous shivers right through me. At present nuclear safeguards are acknowledged to be virtually useless. If one says that they are not useless, I ask: How in the name of God did India and Israel explode devices? They obtained plutonium and weapons grade fuel from uranium that was being mined for peaceful purposes. If that is not enough to worry honourable senators, let me list a few nations, headed by crazies, which are on the verge of getting the bomb: Argentina, the Philippines, Pakistan, India, Lybia, Syria, Korea, Iraq and Iran. What does it do for the peace of mind of honourable senators to think that some of those nations may soon have the bomb and that they will get the bomb only if they can get their hands on the products of uranium.

For this reason the Australian Democrats are very proud to have been associated with introducing this Bill. We believe it is time to say to the world: Stop being crazy. Remember Koestler's words that our self-induced extinction of all life on this planet is now approaching a statistical certainty. We believe the first step to stop that-before we can even begin to be regarded as fair dinkum in our contribution to nuclear proliferation-is to stop exporting our uranium. What short of a reaction will our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or our public servants in the foreign diplomatic corps receive overseas when they talk about nuclear proliferation, when the people to whom they talk know that we are exporting uranium as fast as any ship can leave Australia fully loaded with it for a quick lousy buck? I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented, Mr Deputy President. I take it that the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, misunderstood or misheard what I said. I did not suggest that in the event of there being an immediate cessation of the exportation of uranium from Australia to Japan, Japan would no longer be able to fulfil its own requirements. What I said was that three weeks ago the Japanese Government make it quite clear that in the event of there being an abrogation of the contractual relationship, which is presently in place between Australia and Japan in respect of the sale of uranium, Japan would have to reconsider its position in respect of our integrity, our capacity as responsible suppliers and our future likelihood as a responsible trading partner.

SPEECH.PARA: The Japanese were referring not only to uranium. They made the point that they can acquire their uranium needs from other countries. On the statistics, I think that in 1981 they were acquiring 3,000 tonnes; in 1990 the figure will be 5,000 and by the year 2000 it will be 11,000. That was not the problem. The problem was that Australia is a reliable supplier, not only of uranium but also of coal, beef and many other products which we presently sell. As I said, because of the enormous trade surplus in our favour, a surplus which is in favour of Japan as against the United States, Japan would look elsewhere for contracts in respect of many products that we presently supply and we could no longer be considered a reliable and responsible trading partner. I did not for a moment suggest that Japan's capacity to acquire uranium for its plants would diminish.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
