SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this matter was being considered before luncheon I was in the course of replying briskly and succinctly to Senator Durack's untoward suggestions that we have been something less than energetic and effective as a law reform administration in the first seven months. May I just complete at least the partial litany of achievement by mentioning some other matters before I sit down. Defamation law, an exercise which again under the previous Administration's stewardship had been prolonged over some three years without visible signs of achievement, was brought to fruition through the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General this year and a draft Bill is in the process of final discussion with the view to exposure either in the next few weeks or, at the latest, very early next year.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to audio visual copyright, a major review exercise has been drawn rapidly to conclusion. I will be making some announcements to morrow as to what the Government's likely position will be on some of those vexed and difficult matters. A major review of Part IV of the Trade Practices Act has been completed as promised and it is expected that before we rise again this year a major piece of legislation will be exposed to the community for comment, outlining what is proposed not only in relation to Part IV but also the Part V consumer protection provisions.

Other matters have occupied the attention of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General with active leadership from the Commonwealth. I refer in particular to artificial insemination and in vitro fertilisation procedures and the status of children born as a result thereof; the position of transsexuals, which is the subject of a major project in which the Commonwealth has been taking a leading role and in respect of which a discussion paper was recently circulated.

At a Federal-State level we have been actively pursuing, as I indicated we would, the whole question of accident compensation and discussions are at an advanced stage, both within the Commonwealth and as between the Commonwealth and New South Wales, with a view to moving towards the first stage of a co-operative national accident compensation scheme. In the area of legal administration, we have brought to fruition something again on which the Government previously was dragging its feet for a long period, and that is the establishment of a national computerised legal information retrieval system with appropriate agreements being entered into by the Commonwealth and the States to ensure that legal data can be made available by this new technology.

Within the Attorney-General's Department, a very major management review has been set in train, resulting in a draft report which has been submitted to me by a steering committee just a few weeks ago and which is now being finally shaped up for major organisational implementation next year, as has already been publicly announced. One of the key elements in that, as has been announced, will be the replacement of the Crown Solicitor's Division as traditionally constructed with an Australian Government Solicitor in corporate form. That will be the subject of implementing legislation and administrative action early next year. Another key aspect of it is the concept of establishing an Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions in order to co-ordinate Commonwealth prosecutions right across the whole spectrum but including in particular taxation, fraud and other white collar crime in respect of which the previous Government was lax to the point of criminal negligence. In relation to that, of course today has also been the day, and Senator Durack is rather unlucky in his choice of occasion in this respect, when the Director of Public Prosecutions Bill has been introduced into the Parliament. It is a clear demonstration of where the Government is going in that respect.

There are other matters to which I can refer, in particular legal aid, which has been the subject of very substantial increases in money terms this financial year, and in real terms, as well as being the subject of a very major review which was promised at the time we came into Government as to the best methods of delivery. Senator Durack himself, as I acknowledge has not been churlish in his acknowledgment of some of the steps forward that we have been able to make, particularly so far as getting a uniform fee scale for family law is concerned and moving towards the curtailing of what has been a quite undesirable explosion in the amount of money that has been spent in legal aid in recent years- undesirable given the proportion of return that has been achieved for that expenditure. We have doubled the expenditure on community legal centres by up to $1m and generally are advancing on a broad front towards the rationalisation of legal aid. I hope to have achieved, by the middle of next year, a final rationalisation of the national legal aid delivery system through the establishment, on the same basis as elsewhere, of a legal aid commission in New South Wales, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. There are other matters in various degrees of progress at the moment in respect of which it is not appropriate to make any public announcement. I mention in that respect the review of the off-shore legislation which roused Senator Durack's particular indignation but in respect of which major activity has been going on behind the scenes.

I simply summarise by saying that far from the Government having anything to be ashamed of so far as the content and rate of implementation of its pre-election promises in the law reform area is concerned, we have a great deal on the record and a great deal to be proud of. Of all the possible areas of public interest which Senator Durack might have chosen to launch his attack on today, I find it quite extraordinary and a measure of the degree to which the present Opposition is out of touch with reality, that he should have chosen to focus on alleged failings in the implementation of law reform promises. It has been a record of great energy and great achievement. I do not blame Senator Durack for being jealous of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been treated simply to a repetition of claims by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) for law reform initiatives which simply prove the point that I made, that those initiatives which he has achieved by and large are ones on which a vast amount of work had been done and which were virtually ready for implementation at the time he came into office. I readily acknowledged, of course, that one particular achievement he had was to establish the legislation under the external affairs power for South West Tasmania. I simply commented there that that so-called achievement from his own point of view was one which had created and will continue to create more problems for him, for the Government and for Australia than it has solved. I raised a number of matters from the point of view of his own priorities and I was interested to know what had happened to a number of them on which there did not appear to have been the same degree of success which he and his constant rhetoric claims for himself and for his law reform program. In the course of his reply, he has mentioned several matters which I think only prove my point, namely, the claim that somehow or other he has been responsible for the implementation of the legal information retrieval system. Of course, that claim is utter nonsense. The whole matter had been developed to the point where New South Wales and Victoria were about to enter into arrangements with an entrepreneur for these purposes and on that issue there was simply a difference of view between the previous Government and the present Government as to whether the Commonwealth would give those bodies an exclusive night licence or not. As to defamation, again the announcement that has been made-we have not yet seen the Bill-draws substantially on the work that had been done in the past and decisions which had been made at various meetings of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.
—The problems have been with some of the stupid decisions you made.

—The other interesting aspect is that since Senator Evans announced this particular decision, for which he claims such credit, he has got himself into a mine-field of controversy which he will have to face. When the legislation is introduced there will be a great deal of controversy about it. It will not be the simple plain-sailing exercise which he seems to think it will be .

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney has been very coy in responding to several matters about which I was seeking information, namely, what is happening about this alleged review of the re-established Commonwealth sovereignty on off-shore areas. He is not really prepared, apparently, to tell us what the Government is planning in that area and yet that is of enormous significance. He has completely ignored my request to know what has happened about the implementation of the Premiers Conference agreement of 18 months ago relating to the removal of residual constitutional links. I also asked him what was the significance of and what is the Commonwealth's intention in relation to the item about the companies and securities legislation. If Senator Evans wants to be so coy about matters that he cannot list or even claim to have achieved at this stage, there are a number of other matters which I did not bother to mention or ask questions about because I did not have the time when I was speaking before in this debate. For instance, under the area of justice, I notice that priority 1A was given to review and reintroduce the criminal investigation Bill. On Senator Evans's own priorities that should have been reintroduced back in May, but it has not been.

What is the Government doing or planning in respect of the review of the terms of Australia's ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights with a view to withdrawing reservations? Another item under the same heading refers to the establishment of a Federal sentencing council. That has been given priority 1B. As I understand it, that was to be achieved by the Budget session. What has happened about that? The Law Reform Commission's recommendations relating to sentencing and parole and uniformity of treatment of Federal offenders was to be implemented by the end of the year. I am interested to know what has happened about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —But this is not the right place.
—It is entirely the right place to discuss it.
—We are on the Estimates.

—Under the Estimates we can talk about what is happening in the department for which we are voting money. What a nonsense comment from Senator Tate. Nobody has ever suggested that we cannot, in an Estimates debate, ask questions about what is happening in aspects of departmental administration. If the Minister wants to ignore the questions that is his business. But that will be flying in the face of his responsibility to this Parliament. If that is the way he wants to behave and if that is the way Senator Tates wants to encourage him to behave, let them stand on that attitude to this Parliament and answer to the people in due course for their autocratic and arrogant behaviour. Of course, we see plenty of arrogant behaviour all the time from the Attorney-General. I am sorry to see him being aided and abetted in that by Senator Tate of whom I thought better.

SPEECH.PARA: There are several other matters about which we have heard a lot of rhetoric from Senator Evans as to what he intends to do. I read a speech that he gave a few months ago about establishing a national law reform advisory council. Perhaps he might tell us what has happened with that. He was very keen on developing automatic parliamentary consideration of Law Reform Commission reports. That was another thing about which he spoke a great deal. I have not noticed that that has been achieved as yet. I do not think it can ever be achieved because it is such a nonsensical proposal that these things can be rubber stamped either by the Government or the Parliament.

I do not propose to speak at great length on this program. I simply raise the matter because Senator Evans has raised it to the height that he has by his claims and rhetoric about his dedication and success as a law reformer. I have simply pointed out that most of the matters on which he can claim achievement are ones which were really in the pipeline when he became Attorney-General. I am interested to know what progress he has made in areas about which he has established his own priorities. Senator Evans was a great critic of the former Administration. He said things were not done when, of course, it was a question of whether the former Administration was implementing his policies and priorities. I do not expect Senator Evans to implement the Opposition's policies . I am interested to know how far the Government is going and what it has achieved in implementing Senator Evans's policies. That is why I raised some questions. I believe that a number of questions are justified and that Senator Evans should explain what position he has reached, particularly in view, as I said, of the priorities which he laid down for himself and for the Government. I think it is fair enough for the Parliament to find out whether Senator Evans is coming within cooee of meeting the deadlines on so many items that he has laid down. The answer that he has already given falls far short of answering the questions which were raised as a result of this document to which I am referring . When all is said and done, he has now been in office for eight months, not seven months, as he told us. He usually is inclined to exaggeration, but not in that direction. We are approaching the end of the parliamentary session and the end of the year. Obviously there is a good deal of slippage on the priorities which Senator Evans laid down. He has already said that the human rights legislation would be introduced by the end of the year. That was one of his priorities, I believe. That was to be introduced for the Budget session. He now says, quite understandably-I am not being critical-that probably that will be introduced next year. There are obviously a number of other areas where there has been some slippage. I and I am sure the Parliament would be interested to know what the revised program is for a number of matters that have been the subject of this timetable that Senator Evans laid down at the beginning of his administration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard a tiresome and sterile initial contribution from Senator Durack I did not think it would be possible to hear something even more tiresome and sterile. But such it was and as such, I suppose, it must be replied to, the conventions of this place being as they are. I make the point, as I made the point last time round, that the document to which Senator Durack refers with so much pleasure-it is not shared by any of his listeners on his own side because they are as bored as we are with it-is not a document that was ever made public nor did it ever represent a public or deliberate commitment by me to targets that I was committing myself or the Government to. It was simply a discussion document that was prepared in order to form the basis for discussions with the Department after we came into government as to what the art of the possible might be. It is thoroughly tendentious against that background, for Senator Durack to use in a thoroughly dishonest and misleading way what was a document prepared for a totally different purpose. The particular items on the list I do not resile from in any way. They do represent the areas of activity to which I wish to devote and still wish to devote priority attention to. But the actual date and order of priority associated with each of them was necessarily a matter of subsequent discussion and refinement. Such has proved to be the case. There is not a single claim that I have made, I think, which has been publicly shown to be false in this respect.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not doubt that Senator Durack should get tetchy on the subject of targets and priorities because that was manifestly something to which he was utterly unable to address himself in his conduct of this portfolio as was evident in the spectacular maladministration that occurred under his stewardship. But he has raised eight particular matters that he wants me to comment further on so let be briefly deal with them. As to the first one, I do not propose to say anything more than I have already about the review of the re-establishment of Commonwealth sovereignty over the off-shore areas. That is a matter in respect of which I set myself the target internally of conducting a review. That has been done. The Government is now considering its position. The implementation of the Premiers Conference agreement concerning residual constitutional links has been the subject of a great deal of further activity and refinement and the development of legislative formulae. It has been the subject of extended discussions between myself, the British Government, Buckingham Palace and other relevant interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —You only learnt what I learnt three years ago.

—Well, we are a damn sight closer to a solution, I can assure Senator Durack. I am not in a position of being able to state exactly where the thing is at the moment. It will be further discussed at a meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in Melbourne on 15 December, and I remain optimistic that legislation will be forthcoming early next year, which was always part of our hoped for timetable.

SPEECH.PARA: As to companies and securities legislation, the only suggestion in the document to which Senator Durack refers, was that there would be an internal review of the constitutional possibilities of unilateral legislation here in the event that we chose to follow that particular course. But I have made it clear on numerous occasions that we will not go down that adventurous and exploratory course as long as the continuing co-operative scheme with all its deficiencies continues to work reasonably satisfactorily; and it has shown itself, with certain limitations, to be operating in this way. Part of the proof of this is the major piece of reforming company legislation which we will be debating in this place next week.

A criminal investigation Bill very much remains a priority target for the Government. Its implementation or introduction has been necessarily delayed by the difficulties that have been occurring with respect to the creation and establishment of the National Crime Authority. That was obviously a higher immediate priority in the area of the administration of criminal justice, but with that now out of the way, as I hope it will be in a few weeks' time, we will be able to devote all resources to bringing that major piece of reforming legislation to fruition next year. The exercise of removing the reservations and declarations that were so indefensibly entered into by this Government in relation to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, has been proceeding through the task force on human rights which has been working over the last two or three months. I have formulated my views on that and they are now being worked up in the form of a submission to go to government within a matter of days.

As to the proposed Federal Sentencing Council, once again I have canvassed, as did the preceding Administration, the views of judges exercising Federal jurisdiction around the country, and have discovered, as did my predecessors, for reasons which continue to escape me I hasten to add, some resistence to the concept of establishing such a council. I believe that resistence is ill-founded and propose to proceed nonetheless with the establishment of something in the new year that will help to improve the sharing of experience in that area and to get some greater degree of uniformity into the sentencing process. I propose to make the vehicle for this purpose the Institute of Criminology, which is to assume a new life and vitality, I hope, with the coming to the office of directory early in the new year of Professor Richard Harding, who is keen to make the sentencing area a major priority.

The law reform advisory council or commission concept has been worked up, formulated and is the subject of a major 80-page document-I do not know whether Senator Durack has any interest in seeing it but if he does and he can contribute constructively to the process of working something out here on a bipartisan basis, I would be only too happy to make it available to him. The recommendations arising out of that exercise were in fact approved by a national law reform agencies conference meeting in Brisbane just a few months ago and discussions are now continuing in the context of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General to see what sort of institutional machinery we can agree on to implement that concept which does have a degree of acceptance in principle around the country.

As to the final point about the implementation of the Australian Law Reform Commission reports, Senator Durack continues to caricature the position that I have constantly reiterated publicly, and that is not one of automatic implementation of everything that should happen to fall from the Commission; rather it is a question of applying to the Commission reports an intellectual process which says the onus is on he who would wish to not implement the terms of a report or recommendation given the amount of effort and energy and consultation that has gone into their formulation. We have adopted a different approach to the implementation of these reports, and that is now bearing very obvious fruit, particularly in the insurance area, where agents and brokers legislation will be introduced, I am told, before Parliament goes into recess. Insurance contracts legislation will be introduced, if not before we get up then very early in the new year. A whole series of other long-gathering dust reports are about to emerge into the light of day. I do not think that by the time we have spent another year in office there will be very much that Senator Durack can cavil at in this particular respect.

Mr Chairman, I find this, as no doubt everyone else does, a rather empty debate . It is too early in the life of any government to be crowing about lists of achievements, and I did not seek to do so when I came into the chamber today, but I have been forced to address these matters and to give the Committee something like 25 minutes' worth of recitation of those achievements because of the churlish, tendentious, intellectually sterile and utterly qualitatively empty diatribe to which we have been subject by the previous Attorney-General, whose record was nothing to be proud of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I know it is a terrible irritation for any Minister, particularly a Minister such as our present Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), whose patience is somewhat short, to have to come into Parliament and answer questions about the administration of his own Department. I apologise to Senator Evans for the irritation that he is being caused by being subjected to a fairly light examination, in fact, of some aspects of his administration. But when he sets certain timetables and priorities, absurd and all as they were and are, which has been quite clearly revealed by his own answers to my questions today, I am sorry, but he will really just have to put up with it.

SPEECH.PARA: Considering the length of time that all Ministers spend in this chamber on matters such as Estimates, I know it is a very irritating thing for a man such as the Attorney-General, with such remote intellectual capacities, to have to face up to this sort of examination. His patience is very short indeed. That was revealed, of course, in the other Estimates committee discussions which we had. The Attorney-General has all these things in which he has high faith and an academic belief that they can be achieved overnight. I know it must be testing his patience very much to realise that the real world does not operate in quite the same way as the construct that he has of it. I am sorry that he takes the view that he does, but we will certainly persist with our examination of his record.

That leads me to a matter which I think is of very much more immediate concern to the Senate and one to which, perhaps, in the light of the attitude the Attorney-General has expressed, it is a pity we did not respond a little more actively than we did at the end of last week. Last week we saw an extraordinary performance in this chamber by the Attorney-General in relation to claims that he made about a certain matter which may in itself have been thrust upon him unwillingly. No doubt he had the same reaction to the task that he was given as he has exhibited here today in having to answer a number of questions about the timetable of certain aspects of his policy. But it happened, as we reminded him last week, that on 12 October this year he answered a question from Senator Chaney about a report from Mr Abbott, the New South Wales Police Commissioner, to Mr Wran concerning very serious allegations about the early release of prisoners and about the transcripts of tapes that has been the product of a warrant under the Telephonic Communications (Interception) Act. In relation to a question about these matters from Senator Chaney Senator Gareth Evans answered in his usual form and manner. He now wants to repudiate what he said about that document earlier. He now says that it was not really meant to be a public document, despite the fact that it had been published in the journal known as Justinian which is well known in legal circles. Now the Attorney wants to repudiate that statement because it is embarrassing to him. We know that. In answer to a question from Senator Chaney about these matters, quite out of the blue-no one asked him whether he had read the particular transcripts-he said:

I have also seen the transcripts of the tapes in question which set the initial hares running. So I am not relying solely on second hand information from police commissioners or anyone else in the answer I now give.
He went on to give his answer. Later he said:
But equally clearly the particular matters of criminal investigation that are involved in this case do not in any way, shape or fashion raise questions of possible breaches of Commonwealth law.
That was a very important conclusion. It was made and reported to the Senate. Senator Evans said:
I have looked very carefully at this aspect to satisfy myself personally that that is so, and I am satisfied.

That was Senator Evans, as Attorney-General of the Commonwealth-the first law officer of the Commonwealth-telling the Senate, in answer to a question, that the Senate could rely entirely on his own personal judgment in this very important matter. He tried to give the Senate the very clear impression that we could rely on his personal judgment. That is a very high responsibility for anybody holding the office of Attorney-General to assume.

It emerged in answers to questions last week-indeed it emerged to some extent, in the statement that Senator Evans made at the end of the previous sitting week when the whole matter blew up very strongly indeed-that Senator Evans had only in fact read what he said was six to 10 pages of the transcripts. He said he had read only those parts which were selected and drawn to his attention by the Commissioner of Police as being the ones which were relevant. Senator Evans relied on the selection made by the Commissioner of Police. He said he was entitled to rely on the selection of the Commissioner of Police. I can understand in these circumstances that that may well have been a reasonable thing for the Attorney-General to do although, in view of the very serious matters which were in question-they were so serious that tapes were being forwarded on the instruction of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Premier of a State because of the implications for one of the Ministers of that State-it may well be that the Attorney-General himself, if he were to become involved, should have given much more attention to them than he did.

As emerged last week he spent about half an hour being briefed. He then spent about 20 minutes in reading the six to 10 pages and scanning-that is the word he used-the remainder of the 700 pages of the transcripts. He paid only cursory attention to the transcripts even though they were so important. That is not the point. Senator Evans never really saw the point, as far as I can understand, last week when answering questions. The point was that Senator Evans, in his answer to Senator Chaney on 12 October, made it clear that he was not relying on secondhand information. He said he was not relying on the police commissioners or anyone else in what he was saying about the content of the tapes or their relevance to breaches of Commonwealth law. He made it quite clear that we could rely on his examination of them and on his personal judgment.

That is what he undertook to do. It is perfectly clear. It was perfectly clear last week in answer to the questions that we asked that he was relying on the selection of relevant material by the Commissioner of Police. We are not impugning the Commissioner of Police in any way. It was simply the view of the Commissioner of Police that certain sections out of all those pages were relevant to this question. As I said earlier, Senator Evans may have been quite justified in doing that. But that is not what he told the Senate. It was not the impression that he wanted the Senate to get. He wanted the Senate to believe that we could rely entirely on his own personal judgment of what he saw as the relevant parts of all this material. Yet, Senator Gareth Evans persisted all last week in maintaining that he did not in any way mislead the Senate or give a false impression.

I want to make it quite clear to Senator Evans that in future he will not be let off the hook as easily as he was last week. If he maintains the sort of attitude that he maintained not only last week but also today in the Senate, in answer to very reasonable questions put to him as Attorney-General on the estimates of his own Department, he will not be given such lenient treatment as we gave him last week when we allowed him, perhaps, the benefit of the doubt as to how far he misled the Senate.

When one looks again at the answer the Attorney-General gave to Senator Chaney, as we have done, it is perfectly clear that he did not give the Senate the true impression of the way in which he approached this problem. I believe that he should have recognised that last week when the matter blew up. He should have come clean then and explained the situation clearly. What he had done previously was perhaps perfectly reasonable. I am not challenging that it may have been perfectly reasonable although one would have expected that on such an important matter he would have had the relevant pages checked by someone in his Department . I am not suggesting that he should have been expected to read the whole of the transcripts. As I said, he made a real point in answer to Senator Chaney of saying that we could rely on his judgment in regard to this matter. Then we found out that we really have to rely virtually entirely on the judgment of the Commissioner of Police. I do not believe that is good enough for a person occupying the office of Attorney-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee at the moment is addressing the appropriations for the Attorney-General's Department, the Department which supports the first law officer of the Commonwealth. That makes the debate on these appropriations of a slightly different character. Of course, in the first law officer of the Commonwealth we have a person filling a role which is, in part, not political. The role is one which is above the ruck. It is meant to be distinguishable from the other portfolios which are doled out by the prime ministers and caucuses. It is meant to involve some independence of judgment and some responsibilities as the guardian of the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: The matters which have been raised by Senator Durack, particularly the matters he has raised in his contribution in the Committee debate, are of a slightly different character from the matters which have been raised in other debate upon the appropriations. I think it would be fair to say that anyone reading the Hansard of the Committee debate so far on these appropriations would say that the Attorney-General has responded with his often assumed arrogance and bad manners. That is a very poor quality in a man who is supposed to be the guardian of the public interest, a man who is supposed to be there to prevent the Government, in its political enthusiasm, from trampling upon the public interest . There have been many people who have taken that responsibility very seriously. I was recently reminded of one of the Attorneys' predecessors, my ex-colleague Ellicott. When he felt that the politics of the situation intruded upon his independence, he resigned.

I do not wish to go over all of the facts which have just been traversed by Senator Durack. But they are the facts which I intended to raise in this debate, because they raise very serious questions about the quality which this Attorney is bringing to his work and about the extent to which he is in fact living up to the responsibilities that he has assumed. The simple summary of the facts which have been outlined by Senator Durack, the simple stark fact that this Attorney has to face up to, is that he has had his attention directed to matters on which the Opposition has asked for his judgment as the guardian of the public interest , and he has refused to go back and read the transcripts. If that is an execution of his duty to protect the public interest in his view, I say that he has a very distorted view of what is the public interest. I have sat here and listened to a lot of sanctimonious sermons from the present Attorney. I have listened to them when he was in opposition and I have listened to them from him as Attorney. I believe that he would have been scathing had any of his predecessors indulged in the same sort of humbug.

The simple fact of the matter is that the Opposition, quite specifically, directed the Attorney's attention to certain transcripts, transcripts which on his evidence he had scanned in a matter of a few minutes, and which he had not read. Those transcripts which he had read left him with significant doubts about whether there had been criminal behaviour by a Minister of the Crown, and he will not go back and check the transcripts. That is the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth, the guardian of the public interest, a man of very great intellectual capacity, we are led to believe. If his intellect is as good as his arrogance, he certainly is a man of great intellectual capacity, but he will not perform that simple task to determine whether or not there is evidence of criminal activity in the hand of the Commonwealth. That is utterly inexcusable.

All of the carry-on in the world, all of the arrogance and rudeness that we have come to accept as the standard behaviour from this Attorney, will not properly answer that charge. To remain in wilful ignorance of the facts is inexcusable. To refuse to go back and read another 10 or 12 pages of transcript is inexcusable. I believe that the Attorney-General, who, we are told, is about to take silk, ought to go away and read some of the theoretical works on his role and his duty as the guardian of the public interest and he ought to start living up to it. I for one will have no respect for an Attorney who will not even look at the facts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to put up with vulgar abuse from the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) or from anyone else in this place.
—You dish it out, but you cannot take it.

—I will perfectly cheerfully take anything that the Opposition cares to throw at me. For the last three and a half weeks, since 12 October, I have answered-I have not added them up-about 25 to 30 questions in this place on the Jackson affair and matters arising out of it. I have been perfectly honest, perfectly candid and perfectly straightforward in the answers that I have given, and I have nothing to add today to any of those answers. Senator Chaney can fulminate and wallow in his own sanctimony, which seems to increase with leaps and bounds with each year of his own embittered failure to meet his own ambitions and aspirations to lead that Party of his. He becomes almost as tiresome in his middle age as Senator Durack is in the twilight of his career as a contributor to this place.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing to be gained by continuing an exchange along these lines. It is not edifying for anyone in this place and it cannot be edifying for anyone listening in. Perhaps I might also suggest to you, Mr Temporary Chairman, that it is quite inappropriate for an exercise in relation to the departmental estimates of a kind that this is supposed to be. So far as I am aware, my own salary and my own worthiness to draw it are not matters that come within the realm of the Attorney-General's Department estimates at all. We are talking about the administration of the Department and the conduct, under my direction, of the officers of that Department. The matters which have attracted the enthusiastic indignation of Senator Durack and Senator Chaney have not involved members or officers of my Department at all. They have involved me in my personal ministerial capacity in ways in which I have quite openly and candidly described in this place.

Without wishing in any way to inhibit such flow of further rhetorical nonsense as may be forthcoming, I suggest, Mr Temporary Chairman, that you might suggest, in turn, to the members of the Opposition that they direct themselves to what I understand this parliamentary exercise to be all about, and that they confine themselves to further sallies and forays in Question Time, or, if they believe I deserve it, a motion of censure or something of that kind. They have ample parliamentary forms at their disposal should they believe, as I doubt they do, that they are appropriate to utilise in this particular instance. Perhaps I might suggest that the time of this Committee not be further wasted with this kind of nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The matter raised by the Attorney-General was quite correct. We should remember that we are considering the votes in Group E for the Attorney-General's Department. I would ask honourable senators who are making a contribution to keep that in mind. I call Senator Chaney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Attorney-General's Department at present there are no doubt people beavering away on one of the propositions that our Attorney has recently put before the Parliament which relates to the establishment of an office related to prosecutions. I would ask the Attorney-General, in conformity with your direction or suggestion to the Committee, Mr Temporary Chairman, the extent to which he will be divorcing himself from the prosecuting role of the Commonwealth . I ask that question because of the reservations which I have about his ability to fill that role, but that is not a matter that we need canvass here. However, in asking him to answer on that matter, I draw his attention to the debate which exists in England on the extent to which it is possible, in the modern age, to have a political Attorney capable of filling these high functions. One of the Attorneys-General in England, Lord Rawlinson, expressed a view that the day of the political law officer should be coming to an end; that the public could not understand how the Attorney-General's essential independence of approach could possibly be reconciled with his character as a 'political animal'. That expression is in quotation marks because it is an expression used by another Attorney-General, the Rt Hon. S. C. Silkin, who used that expression to describe his own role when he appeared before the Court of Appeal. But to go back to that view, many of the public cannot understand how the Attorney-General's essential independence of approach could possibly be reconciled with his character as a political animal and with his role as a member of the Government. I believe that we should follow the example of some Commonwealth countries, such as India, in going over to non-political law officers, totally independent, like the Director of Public Prosecutions of the Government of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: In the light of the refusal of the Attorney-General to examine the material which is available to him, and which it has been suggested in a number of places may contain evidence of criminal conduct, I should like the Attorney-General to advise the Committee on the extent to which, by the measures which he has just introduced into the Parliament, or by other measures which in his fertile mind he may be developing as part of his endless program of reform, he intends to remove from his own hands some of these questions of administration of law and, in particular, matters which might relate to prosecutions, over which there might be some political doubts about his ability to maintain his independence.

I also ask the Attorney what access he has to professional help. I am aware that the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth at the moment has a quite impossible work load. I for one would support some reduction in the work load of the Attorney on grounds quite different from those that I have been canvassing. It seems to me that the Department has become far too much of a grab bag of functions and it has suffered accordingly. Many of those functions could be removed and that would no doubt make the job of the Attorney a more manageable one.

In that context, bearing in mind the fact that the Attorney had only 20 minutes to address himself to 700 pages of transcript, I ask him what professional staff he has in his private office, what number, and whether he thinks that number is adequate. Should we be seeking more funds for that purpose? I ask him what number of professional officers he has access to in the Attorney-General's Department? By professional officers I mean qualified barristers and solicitors who might be entrusted with significant work such as examining transcripts to see whether they contain evidence of criminal behaviour. In a nutshell, I would like the Attorney to tell us the extent to which he has access to competent professional help to enable him to carry out the many tasks that he has to perform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I suggest that some of the matters to which the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, wants me to address myself are better left for debate in the context of the Director of Public Prosecutions Bill which is now before the Parliament. There is a legitimate area for argument as to the extent to which the prosecution function ought to be divested entirely to an independent statutory officer of that description or whether, rather, some residual powers should remain vested with the Attorney-General of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: The particular model that we have opted for-which I do not understand to have attracted any particular indignation from Senator Durack when I discussed it with him-is one which gives the day to day conduct of prosecutions for all practical purposes exclusively to the Director of Public Prosecutions, but retains vested in the Attorney-General the capacity to come in over the top, as it were, issue guidelines and directives either of a general character or relating to the circumstances of a particular case subject to the discipline of those guidelines or directions being publicly gazetted and made the subject of public scrutiny. I believe that is an appropriate balance of functions. Whether Senator Chaney believes it is appropriate for someone with my particular combination of character defects to have that degree of professional residual responsibility is a matter I leave to the recesses of his mind to contemplate further.

As to the circumstances in my private office, the situation is this: I have two electoral staff, as everyone does, one of whom is now a lawyer as of last week, although I do not think the appointment has yet been formalised, based in Melbourne, based in Canberra; all peripatetic. I have three highly qualified lawyers as principal private secretary, private secretary and senior adviser, the last mentioned of whom, Mr Pickering, was the subject of an exchange in the Estimates committee. In addition, I have three non-legally qualified secretaries or stenographers/receptionists, plus a Press officer who operates primarily out of the Department. So far as professional assistance from the Department is concerned, there are some 500 lawyers out of a total departmental complement of 2,500. I would have thought that given the expertise and quality which is vested in those 500 lawyers, I am as well served as any professional could be in the decisions for which I assume responsibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reference that the Attorney has made to his private office indicates fairly clearly that he has some substantial legal help readily at hand, apart from those in the Department, who, spread around Australia might not be so readily available to perform the sort of task that he had in front of him when these transcripts were brought to his attention . Certainly when the matter was raised by the Opposition, one would have thought that quite clearly he would have been able to have checked the question that was asked and on which, as I said earlier, he clearly gave the impression that we could rely on his own personal judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I want to refer to one other matter. The Attorney himself raised it in the answer he has just given. When the matter of Mr Pickering's position was mentioned at the Estimates committee, Senator Evans told the committee that he was under the exchange scheme.

—Yes, it was subsequently corrected, but in the course of correcting it the Attorney indicated that it was similar to the exchange scheme in some way. I must say that I find that the essence of an exchange scheme is that there is a two-way process. Mr Pickering apparently remains the employee of a private firm of solicitors in Melbourne. That firm pays his salary, yet he is on the staff of the Attorney-General. Certainly some expenses are apparently met by the Government. I raise with the Attorney-General two questions: First, is there not a very serious potential conflict of interest and duty in that situation?
—That is right.
—Oh, shut up, Teague.
—What is that? Do you want me to shut up?
—No, not you, your back bencher.
—You want somebody else to shut up. You might do better to observe your own counsel. That is a quite offensive inter- jection.
—The whole thrust of what you are saying is offensive.
—I know that the whole thrust of your being asked anything is offensive to you. Anybody who wants to ask you any questions should shut up. We know that, but you are not helping your own case.
—Get down and crawl on your stomach when you are making these sorts of speeches. Goodness gracious, what are you trying to say?
—What did you say?
—I said you should crawl on you stomach when making those sorts of statements.
—Order! Senator Durack, I--
—The Attorney-General is interjecting. I really would like him to have the opportunity-
—Order! Senator Durack, I suggest that you disregard the interjections and continue with your contribution.
—Why should I? You propose to disregard them, do you, Mr Temporary Chairman? I wish to hear what the Attorney-General is saying.
—You will hear my answer in due course.
—I ask the Attorney-General to temper his remarks.
—Might I suggest that the former incumbent of my office temper his provocation?
—It really is very difficult to have a serious discussion of this subject. You really are making a farce of this whole exercise-
—It has nothing to do with the Estimates. My own private office is not paid for out of departmental estimates. You are out of order for a start.

—It is a serious question in relation to the administration of the Department and the readiness of this Parliament to vote money to a department administered by you with the attitudes that you express in this place . You are provoking-
—Senator Durack, would you direct your comments through the Chair.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I apologise for not having done that, but not only are we being provoked, our questions are being disputed as to their relevance. At the present moment we are engaged in consideration of votes for a department. The role, attitudes and capacity of the head of that department, the Attorney-General, are highly relevant to that consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the question that I asked in relation to the role of Mr Pickering and the position that this gentleman has on the Attorney's staff. I have posed one question to him, but I pose another. He has justified the situation, as I understand it, on the basis that Mr Pickering's employment is analagous to an exchange scheme. I can understand, and I applaud, the exchange scheme between the Department and the private profession whereby an officer of the Department goes to a private solicitor's office for a time and somebody, not necessarily from that office but from some other private legal office in Australia, comes to the Attorney-General's Department and spends some months working in the Attorney 's office. There is a mutual advantage to be obtained by that process. An officer of the Attorney-General's Department is acquiring experience in private legal practice and, as a quid pro quo, the Attorney-General's office is obtaining the services of someone from private legal practice. That is the very nature of an exchange scheme.

I do not wish to impugn Mr Pickering in any way whatsoever, but I am intrigued to know how the seconding to the Attorney-General's office of a member of a private legal firm who continues to be paid by that firm in any way satisfies the basic elements of an exchange scheme. Senator Gareth Evans did not make the matter clear at the Estimates committee; he misled the Estimates committee and quite surprisingly was unable to answer what one would think were questions that he would readily have in mind. Admittedly he did clarify the matter later, making it clear that he was not a part of the exchange scheme. But he persisted in maintaining that somehow or other this employment was analagous to it. I believe that these two questions that I have posed certainly arise from that matter and perhaps he could bring himself, I know with great reluctance and invitation, to answer them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Durack seems to be quite unaware that the Public Service Board does run an exchange scheme which happens not necessarily to involve direct one for one swaps between a particular government office, agency or department and a particular private profession or private sector firm. There is no necessary identity of either location or time in the exchanges that do in fact occur under the auspices of the Board. I had taken some interest in and had some general knowledge of the existence of that scheme not arising in any way out of the conduct of my portfolio but by virtue of my general interest in public administration-an interest which Senator Durack does not seem to share.

SPEECH.PARA: It was with that in mind, when I was approached on behalf of Mr Pickering by a partner of the firm with which he worked as to whether or not it might not be possible for him to spend a period in my office, with that firm paying his salary, in order to give Mr Pickering the benefit of a really intense and robust acquaintance with the way in which the world works, as I was told before, that I first asked the Department or my Senior Private Secretary to explore whether such a secondment, as it were, might not be accommodated within the framework of what I generally knew to be the exchange scheme. So it was against that background that the negotiations then proceeded. Apparently it turned out, for one reason or another, that the ground rules applied to schemes of this kind were not particularly appropriate for a secondment to a Minister's office as distinct from a department as such, or there was some other technical limitation which I confess I have never quite stopped to find out.

In the event, the arrangement was reached quite cheerfully with the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley), whose responsibility it is to fund ministerial staff, that the tab would be picked up, as I think I said in my letter to Senator Durack, for Mr Pickering's travel and accommodation expenses but that his basic salary would continue to be paid by the firm. So it was simply by extension of that that the circumstances came about. What on earth is sinister or raises questions of principle or in some other way puts at risk the effective conduct of the nation's affairs or in any way embarrasses the person involved in such an arrangement or in any way creates a situation of embarrassment for the firm that employs him, I am utterly at odds to see. It is an entirely professional relationship in which the gentleman in question is working on particular projects assigned to him by me and is doing a very effective and useful job.

It has been well and early established with the Special Minister of State that, if this gentleman had not been available on this basis, funds would have been made available to me to appoint another lawyer in my office to do professional work of this kind. Such are the demands upon the office, given the standard workload of the Department and the additional workload that has been placed upon it by the very extensive reform program that we have. Why on earth Senator Durack wants to crawl around, turning over stones in this area in the hope of turning up something which will raise questions about something or other, I just cannot understand. Maybe that demonstrates yet another deficiency on my part. But if any further explanation is necessary or if I have overlooked some basic matter that concerns Senator Durack I would be grateful if he would tell me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gareth Evans has really exhibited in the last week or two quite an incredible incapacity to see any problems. Whether that is due to overwork, over-excitement, or over-tension, I do not know. All last week he exhibited a total incapacity to understand the situation that he had created with the answer that he gave in regard to the tapes that he did not in fact examine. He has an incapacity to understand why any problem was created by telling the Senate that we could rely on him, personally; that we did not have to rely on the police commissioner or anyone else but could just rely on him. SPEECH.PARA: Now he persists in saying that he cannot understand what the problem is when he tells us firstly, that somebody is on his staff as part of an exchange scheme. That was not correct; so he corrected it and said it was all analagous to an exchange scheme. Does the Department of the Special Minister of State make payments for this sort of service?

—To the extent that the National Media Liaison Service is funded out of the appropriation for the Special Minister of State, it is the case that money is under this vote for purposes related to the advertising of Government programs and initiatives.
—That is what I was asking.

—I am not the Minister in charge of the Department. I have been wallowing around looking for bits of paper that will help me answer the honourable senator's question. If the honourable senator requires, I will give her a page reference in a moment. From time to time there have been answers to questions in this place by me and others about what the Media Liaison Service does. —I am waiting for the answer from the officers.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the National Media Liaison Service and its functions I refer first of all to pages 456-457 of the Hansard report of the Senate Estimate Committee E hearings on 16 September. I read into the record a detailed description of what precisely the functions of the NMLS are. I will incorporate that again in Hansard if that is helpful to the honourable senator; I will read it out if she really wants me to. I think the most succinct way of indicating the function of the NMLS and the way in which it differs from the GIU is to read from the brief supplied by the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley). The NMLS assists the Government in communicating its policy through the media, community organisations and interest groups. It also maintains channels of communication between the Federal Government and the media in each State. The difference between this service and the former GIU is that the NMLS is designed to provide a genuine information service and will not take direction from any political party organisation or other non-government body.

The Ministerial Media Group-I guess the honourable senator will want to ask me further questions about this-consists of media specialists who are allocated to service Ministers as required in the role of Press secretaries in Canberra and interstate. Offices of both the NMLS and the Ministerial Media Group operate under the direction of the Special Minister of State. They are engaged under the Public Service Act. They work under the same rules and conditions that apply to ministerial staff. Both services will take care not to duplicate the information activities of government departments and will liaise with relevant departments to ensure that such duplication does not occur. So now the honourable senator knows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a question on that subject. I have an acute sense of recall about the then Labor Opposition 's interest in the Government Information Unit. It found two mortal sins in the GIU. It suggested that it would be a heinous thing if the GIU or any such government body should assist any Minister or member in any political action or distribution of the media as distinct from a Cabinet decision or government policy. It also said, quite clearly, that no assistance should be given to Ministers or members at the time of an election campaign. I seek an unqualified assurance from the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that in fact this new unit will commit none of those heinous things that in fact were claimed-and claimed, incidentally, wrongly in most cases-of the GIU.

—All I can do is repeat the clear terms of the Minister's brief. I do not believe he is in the habit of dissimulation on these matters. It is not the intention of the NMLS to behave in any way as a servant or agent of the party organisation as distinct from the Government in its government functions. I have no doubt whatsoever that those strictures will be observed in the conduct of election campaigns and the general business of this Government.

Has administration been put in place to ensure that Press releases are available at the most distant capital from Canberra at the same time as they are available in Canberra? If they are not, I do not know why not. It would be nice to start treating Perth as part of Australia. Will the material sent by the Government to Perth be available to the public generally or only to the media?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure what arrangements are in place at the moment in Perth. I am aware that as of a month or so ago the director for Western Australia had been appointed but had not taken up his position although an office had been opened and a second member of the proposed outfit was there. I will bring to the attention of the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) the concern expressed by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) about same day availability of Press releases. I am sure that in due course, if not already, Vocadex, telex and other equipment necessary to ensure that that situation prevails will be put in place. I think it answers more specifically some matters that Senator Sir John Carrick raises. The functions of the National Media Liaison Service are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) to provide accurate and timely information on Government policies and programmes to the media throughout Australia.
That is a partial answer to Senator Chaney's question because it is the media which is the primary target of the organisation. It continues:

(b) Representatives in each of the State capitals, Townsville and Darwin are to coordinate the passage of detailed information on Government policies and programmes from the information office of various departments to the local media .
So again there is a focus on media relationships. The third function is:
(c) State representatives are to cooperate with the Ministers' staff, especially in the outer States, to coordinate Press arrangements for visiting Ministers.
this is a quite specific answer to one of the questions raised by Senator Chaney earlier on--
(d) State representatives are to provide local members of all parties with details of government programmes.
this is a further answer to I think both Sentor Chaney and Senator Sir John Carrick--
(e) Representatives will not work with local or State ALP branches and will not be involved in party programmes or campaigning in electorates.
(f) To monitor local media reaction to government initiatives. Monitoring, however, is secondary in importance to dissemination of information.
(g) Representatives will provide information on government policies to interest groups within electorates on request.
I believe that that summary of seven points identifying the responsibilities and functions of the NMLS represents a comprehensive answer to the particular questions that have been put to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) for that answer which does go a good way along the track to answering my particular queries although he has not done so yet, and I quite understand his not being in a position to give me the information about same day services. In one of the last points that he mentioned in reading from the Hansard, he touched on the question of monitoring. I would be interested in getting a little more information before we authorise the expenditure for this particular exercise on that particular aspect of the activities of the NMLS. Will the organisation be in Perth? I suppose it will be the same in other capitals. Will it be monitoring the local electronic media? Will it be preparing transcripts of matters of political interest from that media? If so, will those transcripts be available to the public as well as to the Government?

—Not being armed with the ministerial responsibility in this area, I am unable to give any other answer than to repeat the terms of paragraph (f), that one of the functions of the NMLS is to monitor local media reaction to government initiatives which is a quite specific kind of monitoring function, with a further rider that that monitoring is secondary in importance to the dissemination of information. As to what the availability of the product of that monitoring might be, I will refer that to the Special Minister of State (Mr Beazley) to see what arrangements are presently in train and what is proposed.

—I have one final question. I hope that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) can tell me the difference between the money that is spent on the media information service in the Department of the Special Minister of State and that spent in the Department of Social Security for the Government information services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically, as I have indicated again in trying to describe the functions as they have been identified to me, the purpose is not to duplicate the work that is done by the departmental public relations organisation, but rather to co-ordinate more effectively the discrimination of the work of those departments. That is how paragraph (b) describes it. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Representatives in each of the State capitals . . . --
and so on--
are to coordinate the passage of detailed information on Government policies and programmes from the information offices of various departments to the local media.

There is many a slip twixt the central office publicity organs of the various departments and their actual delivery to local media in particular, which media are those often most avidly absorbed by the electorate to whom it is desirable that information of this kind be communicated. One of the very specific objectives is to make sure that that feeding out process is better co-ordinated than it perhaps has been in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am no clearer. Let us take the abolition of the over 70s pension without a means test. Is that work done by the information service in the Department of Social Security or is it done by the Department of the Special Minister of State? Heaven forbid that there be any politics in it. Is the advertising that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is assuring us is just for the information of pensioners done by the Department or is it done by the Minister? Which advertising is done by the Department and which is done by the Minister? Seeing that there is a great inclination not to have any double banking in this area, why is it not all done by the one group or one department?

—As I understand it, when there is a major program of this kind being implemented, there is a function being performed at both the departmental operational level and by the Special Minister of State, either through the co-ordination or dissemination role of the NMLS or through special budgetary appropriations of the kind we were talking about recently, through the information co-ordination branch, as was the case with the superannuation taxation arrangements. If Senator Walters has a particular series of advertisements or something else of that specific kind in mind that she can ask a specific question about, we will endeavour to give her a specific answer as to how the responsibility has been divided or co-ordinated, as the case may be. But the world is a fairly complex place and often there are multiple functions to be performed by many different people.

—Could the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) give me a clear reason why it is being done by both departments when he is so very keen not to have the taxpayers' money wasted with any double banking? Can he give me any reason why one department, either the Department of the Special Minister of State or the Department of Social Security, does not do that work so that at least the Parliament will know how much money is being spent on it? When this work is being done by several departments it is, as one can well imagine, rather difficult for the Opposition to catch up with what the Government is spending in certain areas and it is much more difficult for the public to be aware of how much of their tax money is going on this so-called information service.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all a division of labour. I mean Adam Smith and all that stuff. The honourable senator's Party ought to be familiar with that-

—He may be better equipped to answer these sorts of questions. He is used to handling fatuous questions on matters relating to economics and finance whereas I have to answer fatuous questions in other areas.

—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman, for that proper dispatch . An example, I guess, would be where the functional department actually prepares the basic advertising copy because it may involve substantial matters of technical detail that have to be explained but the actual dissemination of that information and the working of it up into a form which is presentable and able to be assimilated by the community at large may well be done by a specialist agency. There is, I am told, under the auspices of the Department of the Special Minister of State now an Australian Government Advertising Service which was previously in the Department of Administrative Services. Bringing it back into SMOS has been a further step towards the rationalisation which Senator Walters is quite properly concerned with. It is exactly the sort of division of labour which one associates with a business wanting to advertise in the market place but handing out the actual running of its advertising contracts and the placing of the material in question to another agency. As I understand it, that is essentially the role SMOS has played in this respect, co-ordinating and disseminating. But short of wallowing around in this particular portfolio myself for some period, I really cannot give the honourable senator any better answer than that.
