SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a couple of factors which have had a marked effect on the morale of the Defence Force Reserve. I note the decision that was announced yesterday to tax only half the pay of these officers. The two matters to which I refer are, firstly, the reduction in training time and, secondly, the taxing of part of the pay. I am concerned also about the delay in recommending pay changes associated with the decision to tax part of the pay of the Defence Force Reserve. In an answer given about the decline in training time we were told that last year the recruiting was so successful that a lower number of new recruits were required this year and therefore less training time was required. We were told further that some units were already overtrained. This unusual explanation prompted me to evaluate this reply by seeking information from some of the members of the Defence Force Reserve and also from some permanent officers from a number of units including some of the men serving in Butterworth in Malaysia. I visited that unit recently. To be quite frank, in all cases there was an air of complete disbelief about what they called an inaccurate and absurd situation that the answer along the lines given to me could have been given to a Senate Estimates committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to tax part of the income derived from the Defence Force Reserve's activities from 1 December 1984 ignores a number of factors. Firstly, the reservists get paid very three months. Therefore, effectively, they will be taxed from 1 September and not 1 December because of the time lag. Secondly, it fails to recognise that these people get no superanuation and no holiday pay. Thirdly, it fails to recognise that they receive substantially less pay than their full time equivalent. The argument that the Defence Force Reserve personnel should be taxed as regular members or at least pay tax on half of their salary ignores a remaining inconsistency. I think one of the arguments put forward was that the Government had to be consistent in dealing with the reservists and their regular members. This ignores the fact that even the regulars, when they sign up for another term, receive a tax free sum. In other words, they receive a monetary benefit. Is it the Government's intention also, if it is to be consistent, to try to tax this portion of their emoluments?

I think the commitment of these people is very high indeed. In fact, the other day, in my State of Tasmania, I met a number of them on duty. I was told that a significant number of them would attend a camp the following week but would receive absolutely no pay at all. They were doing it gratis, for the love of it. What a situation we find ourselves in. Their commitment was that they believed this training was necessary and they were prepared to attend camp for which they would receive no pay at all. I think we have to recognise that this decision, in the long term, must have some widespread reaction. It must lower the morale, certainly of some of the forces. In fact, on the mainland, a recent survey taken among these people showed that 40 per cent of the reservists would not continue. What a situation.

These people are needed in an emergency. I believe that the Government's attitude towards these people is a national disgrace. It shows that the Australian Labor Party is not really interested in the reserve force. In fact, I think the view can be extended to the defence forces generally. I think it is astounding that, at a time when the Labor Party, particularly through its eloquent Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) is pushing the merits of high technology, within the Department of Defence-I am referring to the science and techology area-insufficient funds are being provided. This has meant the shedding of 80 staff. The reason given was astounding. These staff were being shed to increase the efficiency of the section and those involved in that work were doing work of a low priority. In other words, the Minister for Science and Technology is talking about sunrise industries. He believes that people involved in this type of work can provide the hope for tomorrow. Yet the Government sheds staff in these so-called high technology areas. I believe that is a disgraceful situation.

I think the state of our defence preparedness has been lessened by the fact that while there is an increase in the civilian cost of the defence forces, there is a decreased cost to the uniform branches. Part of this was explained away by the decommissioning of HMAS Melbourne. But I do not think that is the whole answer. What is the significance of it? It means that there is inherently much more red tape and, unfortunately, less preparedness for the uniform branch to service Australia in an emergency.

Further, I hope that the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) will also take steps to rectify an iniquitous position. A corporal with two children serving at Butterworth received a promotion to Flight Sergeant and receives a lesser take home pay after his promotion to Flight Sergeant than he did before. These sorts of anomalies are not good for morale with the defence forces. Another matter of great concern is the lack of depth within certain specialised units within the defence forces and their ability to provide support services. I give an illustration. Again, when I was in Butterworth, I discovered that reservemen in the communications area have to take leave from civvy street and go up to Malaysia to provide a communications coverage for just a single squadron operating there. In other words, the Defence Force relies on the reserve forces to provide some essential communications back-up because of inadequate depth within the defence forces. This is an absolute disgrace. Communications are vitally important. What if an emergency occurred? The lack of personnel is already manifesting itself in this way. I think it is a disgrace. I think Australians need to be informed of what I call the over-concentration of officialdom in Canberra at the expense or neglect of what is required of a modern defence force in a continental sphere.

I think there is widespread acknowledgment now of the problems in relation to fixed wing aircraft, certainly until the arrival of the FA18 Hornet fighter. Most of the Mirages are now operating in excess of the manufacturer's safety limit hours in relation to the problems of air frame fatigue. What does this mean? This means that pilots' lives are at risk by following such a deliberate policy. I believe there is negligence here. This leads one to ask: Does the Government subscribe to the view that we are going to accept inevitable losses? Does this mean that pilots' lives will be lost? While the Government continues to pay civilian operators to keep watch over our northern coastline-these civilian operators fly and report at stipulated times-I believe the tracker aircraft which are now regarded as redundant could usefully be used for detection purposes and for surveillance of the coastline. In addition they provide valuable training for Royal Australian Air Force pilots. Training is vital and search and detection is part of their work. How much more effective could our Air Force surveillance be by the use of tracker or other sorts of aircraft rather than using a civilian service?

The future role of the Skyhawk aircraft is still undecided. Again, this is a matter of great concern within the defence forces. In a force that is trained to make quick decisions such procrastination-and the procrastinations were evident in the Minister's report to the Parliament the other day-is not good and must be viewed against an environment where these fellows, particularly the ones in uniform, are trained to make quick decisions. But the people to whom they are responsible do just the opposite. They procrastinate and play around. Finally, I would like to ask a question in relation to the cost of the FA18 aircraft. When these aircraft were ordered in 1981 the Australian dollar was worth more than the United States dollar, but that situation is now changed. What therefore does the reduction in the value of the Australian dollar in relation to the American dollar mean to the purchase price of the aircraft, since we assume that the purchase price was expressed in United States dollars?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a number of questions, some of which relate to what Senator Watson has asked. First of all, what do reductions in the Budget in relation to steaming time for the Navy, flying time for the Air Force and training time for the Army mean? What in each of the specific services will have been affected as a result of this Budget? Secondly, what will be the reduction in the number of uniformed Service personnel at the end of this financial year compared with the beginning of this financial year? What will be the change in the number of civil personnel in the Defence Force?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson covered rather a large canvas in his remarks and I can respond only briefly to some aspects of them. The reduction in training days for reservists was a matter that was really fully canvassed in the Estimates Committee E hearing, in particular by Brigadier Wade on 15 September. I draw attention to his evidence, recorded at page 297 of the Hansard report of the Senate Estimates Committe hearing on that date, which were in fact answers to questions by Senator Watson, to his renewed attention, in the hope that he might be persuaded this time that what was really involved was just maintenance of the capability which did not in fact demand more than the training days that were actually involved. As to the larger questions of morale of reservists, which he based his speech around, it is not on the information available to me, the case that there are any fundamental problems perceived by the Defence hierarchy. Whether that is a function of their over-establishment or over-concentration in Canberra, as Senator Watson might suggest, I do not know, but certainly I will ensure that his remarks are drawn to the attention of the Minister. To the extent that there are particular problems revealed by what he said, and some of the instances in relation to Butterworth I think do need a definite answer-one which would be assisted incidentally were the honourable senator to provide us with some more specific information about the particular cases to which he referred-I will bring this to the attention of the Minister in the hope that he might be able to give a further reply.

SPEECH.PARA: The taxation question has been the subject I think of Government announcements- whether as to all the detail yet I am not quite sure. But it is the Government's belief that really quite a generous taxation package has been granted to reservists in relation to the additional income they earn as a result of their Reserve activity. If there are any questions that require the specific answer of either the Minister for Defence or the Treasurer (Mr Keating) as a result of what Senator Watson has said, I will ensure that he gets it.

I am advised that the cost of the FA18 can really be determined only at the time payments are made-that is in the sense of the exchange rates that are applicable at that time. So, on what precisely the implications are of the present condition of the exchange rate, it does not follow from that that we can predict with any certainty what the overall costs are. But again I will ask the Minister to give in correspondence a further and better reply if one is possible at this stage.

I am not sure that Senator Watson paid sufficient regard to the effectiveness of the refurbishment program that is now proceeding in respect of the fixed wing aircraft and the condition of the Mirages, quite apart of course from the impact on our strike capability that the FA18s will represent. Again I can only say, not having the ministerial responsibility for this portfolio, that I will draw Senator Watson's speech to the attention of the Minister and get replies for anything that can appropriately be provided.

Similarly, with Senator Carrick's queries as to the civil manpower question, I can give this answer: Service manpower is planned to be reduced by 732 below the actual strength at 30 June 1983, reflecting largely the higher than planned strengths at 30 June 1983 and the planned savings flowing from decisions in relation to the aircraft carrier and fixed wing aviation. While there are increases totalling 648 in the authorised strengths of the Reserve forces, there is an overall reduction of 972 in actual strengths reflecting the Army Reserve being over recruiting target at 30 June 1983. Civilian manpower is planned to be reduced by 399 below the actual strength at 30 June 1983. This includes 147 staff transferred to the Department of Defence Support.

As to the flying and steaming time and the implications of that, the Air Force flying hours program has been maintained at the same level as 1982-83, this financial year. The Navy's fleet fuel allowance will be reduced from the high levels applied in the last few years; by what amount I am unable to tell the honourable senator. I will endeavour to find what further information I can from the Minister. I am told that Army track running will increase slightly. What that means in precise quantitative terms I am again not in a position to advise, but will ask the Minister whether he cares to add anything further. There was a third question which the honourable senator raised which we do not have the answer to at the moment, but I will ensure that a written reply is provided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am curious to have an explanation of the Minister's answer where he said that he felt the Government had given a generous taxation concession to the reservists. —I call the Attorney-General and remind him that we have one minute left.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to give all the details because I do not carry the stuff out of my portfolio around in my head. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address myself briefly to a matter which has been canvassed in the Queensland Press this week. Queensland Australian Democrat, Senator Macklin, has demonstrated this week what an unreliable authority he is on the Liberal Party of Australia. He is reported in Tuesday's Courier-Mail as claiming:

SPEECH.PARA: Liberal International . . . had refused the Liberal Party of Australia membership on three separate occasions.

For the record, the Liberal Party has never applied to join Liberal International. As for Senator Macklin's claim that the Democrats' membership of Liberal International is some sort of evidence of purity by association I think anyone tempted to take him seriously should know that his so-called genuine liberal parties from around the world include a number of quasi-socialist parties. To use the words of Mr Stan Stanley, who has also commented, the Queensland Director of the Australian Democrats, Senator Macklin, shows 'dismal ignorance' of liberalism in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to talk about the hardships imposed on the family of two young Victorian lads whom I happen to know. Those boys are James and Andrew Gallacher aged 10 and 12 years. I have not seen them for some five or six years. When I last saw them I assure the Senate that they were fine young little devils in all the best traditions of young little devils. These two boys unfortunately have what I believe is a terminal illness. I see that the Minister for Health (Senator Grimes) is in the chamber, so perhaps he is able to confirm or deny that. I do not know whether it is true but I understand that the illness is terminal. It is a genetic disease called cystic fibrosis. These young boys take 16 pills with each meal. In addition, they inhale other drugs two or three times a day. At present they are on nine different types of drugs. That apparently is not excessive. Their physician predicts that they could get up to 11 or 12 different types of drug each day.

SPEECH.PARA: These young lads have become part of a scheme to extract money from taxpayers in some way or other. There is no need for me to elaborate to the Senate about the sacrifices made by their parents or about the future of these young lads. It does seem to me that some sacrifies imposed by man on other men are beyond my comprehension. The Cain Labor Government in Victoria has directed the Royal Children's Hospital to reduce its expenditure by 1.5 per cent. It has directed all public hospitals to reduce their expenditure by 1.5 per cent. That hospital, Mr President, is faced, as I see it, with a number of alternatives. It could cut administration costs, its works programs, its staff or its medical services. But in the true tradition of politicians from all over the world what it has decided on is the 'close the fire station' policy. It has decided to cut off the free supply of drugs to all chronically sick children. I understand that some 340 children are being treated with this illness at the Royal Children's Hospital. The supply of free drugs to these children will be cut off from 1 November this year. I understand why the hospital has done this. It is not because it is a quick way of saving about $400,000. It has done it because it puts pressure on the State Government. A strong emotional feeling is aroused in people towards these children. I have no doubt the Royal Children's Hospital could have effected savings in other ways but what it has done, as I said, is to close the fire station and so send up a flame throughout the State because of the hardships imposed on these children. As I said before, why man imposes hardships on other men is beyond my comprehension.

The hospital in my book deserves no praise at all for its actions but, I must say, neither does the Cain Labor Government. Victoria is now in a state of severe financial strife absolutely as a result of mismanagement by the Cain Labor Government. This Government has increased the number employed in the Public Service by over 8,000. One figure put to me was 9,600 but I cannot be sure of that. I am sure that it is in excess of 8,000 people at a time when governments have been trying to cut back expenditure. The Federal Government, of Liberal-National parties, was trying to cut back and the Federal Government, of the Australian Labor Party, is certainly not trying to expand its Public Service any more than it has to to cover unemployment problems. Yet, the Cain Labor Government in Victoria has decided to increase its permanent staff by at least 8 ,000 people.

It is not only those decisions which are involved. For example, in the health field alone the Cain Government has introduced the 38-hour week operative from July this year. It must have been possible to defer that decision. That cost is estimated by the Cain Labor Government at $17m per annum. It is estimated by the Liberal Opposition in Victoria at about $30m per annum. In order to overcome that problem, of course, the Government has had to introduce what are called offsets to meet the cost. For example, it has increased cafe charges in hospitals and things of that nature. Five strikes have occurred in recent weeks about these offsets. Where is the benefit of cutting back to a 38-hour week? What purpose does it achieve?

Even worse than that-this is what really gets me-is that these young kids are not in a union, their parents are not in a union so they cannot stand over their State Government to get what they are entitled to. That is not the situation with the Builders Labourers Federation and other building unions. Victoria is building the new Queen Victoria Hospital at Clayton. The Government of Victoria has agreed with the Builders Labourers Federation, and other labourer organisations working on that site to pay a site allowance of 75c an hour to every worker in the entire project. It will last three or four years perhaps. The unions are not satisfied with the 75c an hour site allowance at this stage. It is indexed to the consumer price index to make sure that the value remains in it and it is backdated to October 1982. The Victorian Government is paying unionist builders labourers working on the site of that hospital paying ultimately, because of the actions of the Royal Children's Hospital, at the expense of the families of 340 kids who have this illness.

I think it is a disgrace. I think it is something that the Federal Government ought to treat as a disgrace. I understand that these boys' physician, Professor Phelan, who is in charge of the chest section of the Royal Children's Hospital is coming to Canberra on Monday to see the Minister for health, Dr Blewett. What the Cain Labor Government is doing in Victoria is what all State governments do. It is trying to blame the Federal Government and trying to push the Federal Government into providing it with the funds to make up its deficit so that it can pay the builders labourers working on the site at Clayton 75c per hour, indexed to the consumer price index and backdated to October 1982. It is a national disgrace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I wished to ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, that is, Senator Ryan representing Mr Cohen. I should like to read it now and to make some comment. The question is:

SPEECH.PARA: Has the Government taken any decision to declare the second stage of the Kakadu National Park? If no decision has yet been taken, what stage has the Government' s consideration of this matter reached? Is the Minister aware of the concern of the Northern Territory Government that any move to declare the second stage without provision for the excision of the Koongarra and Jabiluka uranium deposits will deprive the nation of billions of dollars in export income, Aboriginal communities of millions of dollars in royalties and equity returns and thousands of new jobs which would flow from the development of these reserves.
Such is the concern of the Territory that a Press release was put out today by the Chief Minister. I should like to make some comment on it. The Press release read:

Hasty action to prevent a future decision to develop Jabiluka and Koongarra uranium deposits would harm employment, the Aboriginal community and national development, the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Paul Everingham, said today.

'Federal Cabinet should have pause before it takes any action calculated to obstruct these uranium ventures', he said. 'Furthermore it would pre-empt any decisions arising from the Federal Government's announced inquiry and make it a mere sham.
Jabiluka contains $16 billion worth of recoverable uranium and $500 million worth of recoverable gold.
I am not too sure about whether that figure for gold is correct. The Press release continues:
It has an expected life of 30 years, employing 880 mill operators and miners over this period and providing $8.5 million annually to Aborigines.

Koongarra has $1 billion worth of recoverable uranium. It would employ 150 people over a life of 12 years with Aboriginal traditional owners having a 25 per cent equity in the project. Both mines are ready to go ahead now on the basis of potential contracts which have been blocked by the decision of the Federal Government.
In addition there are more than 2,000 jobs during the construction phases of the mines.

These projects are of immense value to the Territory, to Aboriginal communities and to the nation. The Federal Government and the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service should have pause before taking action to stop Jabiluka and Koongarra going ahead by proclaiming the second stage of the Kakadu Park without making provision for these mines, as was done with Ranger and Nabarlek within Stage 1.
The Coalition parties have committed themselves to ensuring that Jabiluka and Koongarra will proceed in the national interest after a change of Government.

The Government of the Northern Territory has asked the Federal Government to excise Jabiluka from the Kakadu Park, to declare only 50 per cent of the second stage of the Park initially, and to declare a conservation zone over the highly mineralised remainder for an interim period of 12 months.
There is considerable evidence of other minerals such as gold and copper existing in the area as well as high grade uranium ore.'

I think that that states the case for the excision of Koongarra from Kakadu II and to bring about this conservation area, which is a matter of some national importance. I am not too sure as to whether it is right or wrong but there is, perhaps, a rumour in the House now, that while it was mentioned in the Senate today that Cabinet would be looking at this matter in the next few days, or perhaps today, I understand now that perhaps the decision has been made and that Kakadu II has been or will be proclaimed. If it is to be proclaimed without all these requests having been met, I can only suggest for the development of the north and for the people of the north that it is a calamity. If the decision has been made so hastily, one can only wonder why this action should be taken so quickly, because more thought should be given to the matter.

If this action has been taken or is to be taken, it will have a very detrimental effect on the minerals of this particular region and, of course, on Jabiluka, too. If this decision has been taken or is to be taken, it could mean the end of Jabiluka after the tremendous efforts that have been made to bring it into operation. These efforts have been in being for perhaps 12 years. They are efforts which have brought about the environmental laboratory, costing over $1m, so that the whole escarpment and the area of Jabiluka can be properly investigated on an environmental basis.

One would wonder why it is so necessary to hit Jabiluka, as has been done. If the action has not yet been taken, once again I and many people of the Territory would plead with the Government that this action not be taken until a proper review has been carried out, as instanced by the fact that the Federal Government is now carrying out an inquiry into the future of uranium. If the decision has been made that the action is to be taken, that Kakadu II is to be proclaimed, all I can say in regard to that is that it is a national calamity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some little time ago I drew the Senate's attention to the appalling industrial relations situation in the Pilbara iron ore industry in Western Australia and the very damaging effect that the irresponsible action of union leaders was having on Australia's share of Japan's iron ore trade. I use this evening to again refer to the Senate yet another example of irresponsible action by unions in the Pilbara, and perhaps more particularly to highlight the intimidating and intolerable position into which a responsible union member has been cast by the standover tactics of irresponsible and bullying union leaders.

SPEECH.PARA: Last month the operations of Mount Newman Mining's activities at Port Hedland were closed down by the actions of 200 members of the Amalgamated Metals, Foundry and Shipwrights Union, who downed tools for two weeks, threatening the jobs of a further 2,000 workers. Honourable senators might ask what the issue was. During the recent long-running strike at Mount Newman a while back over an irresponsible dispute, the AMFSU members working for Mount Newman Mining at the Port Hedland site were ordered by the local union at Port Hedland to contribute $20 a fortnight from their own pay packets to provide financial support for the striking members at Mount Whaleback. One employee of Mount Newman Mining's operation at Port Hedland, a Mr Niarros, objected to being forced to support financially workers who were on strike over an issue with which he did not agree . He had already, due to the strike, been stood down for two weeks and had lost $800 in wages. Mr Niarros has been a member of the union for 27 years and had conscientiously paid his union dues during that period.

Because of Mr Niarros's stand, one I would have thought he was entirely free to take, the union demanded that he be sacked. That is blackmail and extortion by any standards. Mr Niarros made clear his disillusionment with continual strikes, but when subsequently it became abundantly apparent to him that his actions in refusing to pay the levy might be used as an excuse for yet another dispute, he immediately offered to pay it. That offer was turned down. A meeting was held of AMFSU members who decided to stop work. The members refused to work on the same site as Mr Niarros and demanded his resignation notwithstanding the fact that he had subsequently offered to pay the levy for the sake of industrial peace. Two days later Mount Newman Mining applied to the Western Australian Industrial Arbitration Commission for a conference on the issue.

The State Industrial Commissioner, Mr Johnston, directed Mr Niarros to write to the AMFSU, declaring that he would pay his levy, agree to pay future levies and apologise to the convenor with whom he had had some modest altercation on the issue, as can be imagined. Subsequently-surprise, surprise!-a meeting of the 200 strikers was held at which Mr Niarros read out a letter complying with the directives of the Industrial Commissioner. The union meeting decided that it would accept nothing short of a dismissal. However, at the same time, the company, Mount Newman Mining, was advised that it had no grounds for taking any action, particularly by way of dismissal, against Mr Niarros in the face of union demands that he should be sacked.

Mr Johnston, the commissioner, then recommended that Mr Niarros should resign on the understanding that the men would return to work. He could be reinstated after eight weeks with the company in a different area. During those eight weeks the company would use his long service payment to pay his salary. This proposal was rejected by the strikers. They wanted nothing short of blood; they were going to show this man that nobody steps out of line with their union. Nobody would have the courage to stand up and disagree with their intimidating blackmail and extortion tactics.

Last week a further conference with the Arbitration Commission was held and Commissioner Halliwell suggested two further options. One was that Mr Niarros accept a transfer to the town of Mount Newman where the Mount Whaleback operations take place, a modest eight hour trip by train from his home in South Hedland where he also ran a small ice-cream parlour. His other option was to be suspended without pay until the case was heard by the Arbitration Commission. Reluctantly, Mr Niarros felt that he had no choice but to accept the suspension, although I am sure that he entertains no real hope of subsequent reinstatement.

It was interesting to note that during the period of this disputation, these brave unionists picketed his ice-cream parlour to discourage children from going along and buying their daily ice creams. I am glad to report that his sales went up dramatically as a vote of protest against the intimidation by the union. Mr Niarros is one of those few people who bravely, and perhaps in the modern jungle of industrial relations unwisely, stand up for a principle they believe in. Now he would appear to have lost his job. In his own words:
The thing I don't like about the decision is that the unions will be able to do the same thing to any other worker. Nobody's job is safe.

That might all be the reality of the industrial jungle, the way the warfare is run. However, I am sure that if those circumstances, that deprivation of civil liberties, were transposed into another environment, shock, horror and indignation would be expressed by all those in this Parliament and in this community who profess to have any real concern about civil liberties. If an employer were to conduct himself with the same brutal disregard for the individual rights of an employee or of an individual's rights in any way, I am sure the sky would fall in on him. I find it absolutely abhorrent and I notice that what I have had to say was in part questioned by Senator Bjelke-Petersen yesterday. There did not seem to be any real concern by the Australian Labor Party over the matter. I hope that those on the other side who profess daily to have concern for civil liberties will take up the concern of this man who was brave enough to step out and stand up for what he represents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not my intention tonight to speak in the adjournment debate, but the first speaker, Senator Martin, referred to some Press reports in the Queensland Press in relation to myself and some discussion about Liberal International. I would be quite happy at some future stage, if Senator Martin is interested, to have a general discussion about the philosophies of socialism, liberalism and conservatism. But during this adjournment debate tonight I would simply like to read the letter that was alluded to by Senator Martin. She referred to Stan Stanley, the State Director of the Australian Democrats and to a letter that he wrote. If I can read that letter and make a few comments on it, I think that will suffice for tonight. Mr Stanley said:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it any wonder that the Liberal Party is in such trouble, when their State Director, Mr Gary Neat, is prepared to state publicly that he has 'never heard of Liberal International'.
Such a dismal ignorance of world groupings of political parties, and their respective philosophies, is no doubt the reason why the Liberal Party in Queensland has no idea what they stand for.

Mr Neat's further statement that the Liberal Party of Australia was associated with two major 'liberal' bodies, the European Democratic Union and the Pacific Democratic Union, is either a deliberate deception, or again ignorance of the conservative nature of these bodies.
Perhaps Mr Neat should get hold of a copy of his federal leader's speech to the European Democratic Union earlier this year.
In this speech, Mr Peacock made it abundantly clear that the Australian Liberal Party was proud to belong to an international body of conservative parties-. . .

The proposition also contained in Senator Martin's speech during the adjournment debate was that some members of Liberal International were, as she put it, quasi -socialist bodies. The members of Liberal International can join Liberal International upon invitation and upon acceptance of the charter of liberalism which was set down in the Hague Convention, as it is called in Liberal International. The major political party that Australians would be aware of which took part in drawing up that particular document was the British Liberal Party. Amongst its various other members are some well known throughout Europe as well as the Canadian Liberal Party. It has as one of its official observers the Democratic Party from the United States.

Liberal International is a group of political parties. In fact, it is the oldest grouping of political parties on an international scale anywhere in the world, and that includes Socialist International. I think that if Senator Martin , who did not tell me that she was speaking tonight on this, feels at some stage that it would be useful to have a discussion, I believe it would be useful also. I think any furtherance of the debate about political philosophies might lead to a clarification in Australia of where various parties stand in their ultimate ambitions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my concern, albeit briefly , about the parliamentary process and Executive accountability. My concern was heightened today during the two extremely important parts of the parliamentary process, particularly so far as the Senate is concerned; that is, Question Time and the consideration of the Appropriation Bills in Committee. That is the opportunity we have after Estimates committee hearings to ensure the accountability of the Executive. They are both of absolutely fundamental importance to the parliamentary process. What have we been treated to, although I might say not by either the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) or the Minister for Veteran's Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), who are present at the moment, but by others? We have been treated to insult as a substitute for information, a display of arrogance, a display of absolutism which I find totally objectionable, a substitution of abuse for argument and an apparent belief in the unquestionable authoritarianism which was so different from the rhetoric which came from some of the same people when they were in opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Why, one asks, is this happening? The only conclusion to which one can be led is that it is an attempt to paper over the deficiencies and disunity which exists within the Government. It is a particularly unimpressive exercise but it is an abuse and a destruction of the processes of parliamentary democracy. I believe that it is time, before it goes too far, to require some acknowledgment of the accountability of the Executive. It is fundamental to parliamentary democracy that the Executive be accountable and however irrelevant, however peurile, the executive may regard the questioning which comes from an opposition , it ought to be treated seriously. It ought to be given appropriate respect even though it may be regarded by the government of the day, whoever it may be, as being either irrelevant or even obnoxious or misguided. I claimed this when I was a member of the parties which were in government and, equally, I claim it now when I am a member of the Opposition. I believe that, if the sort of arrogant display of insult as a substitute for information continues in this place, we might as well just disband the Parliament. I say this, Mr President, as a cry from the heart for the parliamentary process that we do not have a continuation of the sort of display that regrettably we had today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, before I reply to some of the matters raised tonight, I table a series of papers on the assessment of year 12 students in the Australian Capital Territory which was requested by Senator Teague in the consideration of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) this afternoon. It was to have been tabled earlier but Senator Ryan's office delayed it in the hope that a better copy could be obtained. The copy I now table is not very good but I assure the Senate that it probably provides sufficient information for the weekend, and next week I will get a decent copy for Senator Teague.

SPEECH.PARA: The first matter raised tonight, by Senator Martin and later by Senator Macklin , concerned the relative merits of the Australian Democrats being a member of Liberal International. Although I did not hear all the remarks properly, I understand that the Liberal Party of Australia is now a member, or an affiliate, of what was to be called Conservative International. I am not sure what it is called.

TALK.START.PARA: —The European Democratic Union.

—It was to be an organisation amalgamated out of the European Democratic Union and the Pacific Democratic Union. Certainly I think Conservative International would be an appropriate place for the Liberal Party of Australia to be. I am amazed at Senator Macklin's complacency about the Democrats being a member of Liberal International. Certainly when Liberal International was formed the Liberal Party of Great Britain, a noble party, was a member. But over the years Liberal International has had a chequered career. I remember one of its prominent European members was the Socialist Party of Portugal, which happened to be the party which supported Salazar during the time of his dictatorship in that country. I remember the Liberal Party in Canada at one stage withdrawing from Liberal International because of some of the strange bedfellows that it had. As Senator Peter Rae said as an aside to me during Senator Macklin's speech, Liberal parties in the European Parliament sit on the right of the conservatives, which is as about as far right as you can get.
—It is as far right as you can get in the European Parliament.

—Yes, or probably as you can get anywhere. So I would have thought that the complacency and the pleasure that Senator Macklin gets out of his party being a member of Liberal International warrants more looking at by the Democrats than by any other political party in this country. Of course the Australian Labor Party is a member of Socialist International, so apparently we have members of all the internationals here now.
—We will have to look at you more closely.

—Socialist International, Senator Kilgariff, is a long-standing organisation; its President is Willy Brandt who, I do not think anyone would question, is a great democrat. It consists of all the great social democratic and democratic socialist parties in the world.
—Delors, who is implementing the most John Stone-type monetary policy in France, is a member also, is he not?
—The French Socialist Party is certainly a member of Socialist International, as is the recently successful radical party in Argentina.

SPEECH.PARA: I move to more serious business. Senator Lewis brought up a matter concerning the Gallacher family and two boys who have fibro-cystic disease. Senator Lewis said he thought it was a 'terminal disease'. That is an unfortunate term to use for this condition because these days, with modern treatment, people with fibro- cystic disease frequently get into adulthood, and it may be as the years go by that they will live much longer than they used to. It is certainly true, as Senator Lewis said, that these unfortunate people need considerable amounts of medication. He talked about these young boys of 10 years needing 16 tablets a day. I have an acquaintance with cystic fibrosis who has to take something like 12 capsules before she eats, every day, and she is younger than 10.

I had better divide his description of what has happened in Victoria into two parts. First of all, the Victorian Government decided to cut back on hospital expenditure and asked hospitals to cut back their budgets. Hospitals did what so many organisations do in these circumstances-they deliberately cut back on their budgets where it would cause the most public fuss and the most political fuss, in this case I would have thought in an appalling way, by depriving children with cystic fibrosis and similar diseases of free medication. I would certainly join with Senator Lewis in condemning such behaviour and I know similar behaviour has been carried out by other hospitals in Victoria under the instruction to cut their staff and their expenses. They pick on areas which will affect the public, which will affect the most unfortunate people in the community and use these people as tools in their battles with government.

We see another example of this with the Federal Government where some of the drug companies, in particular Bristol-Myers, deliberately raised excessively and unilaterally the prices of food substitutes needed by children who are intolerant of milk, and of a drug, cyclophosphamide, which is needed to treat a very rare disease but also to treat people with cancer. That company deliberately picked these two drugs because it thought that this would put the greatest pressure on the Government to cave in. But the Government did not-it could not-cave in and eventually the company had to cave in.

Senator Lewis then drew a long bow when he attributed the actions of the Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne to the paying of site allowances to builders' labourers on the construction site of another hospital in Melbourne. I do not think he did his case any good by trying to draw that long bow and by trying to connect the Cain Labor Government, a very successful government and still a very popular one, with these actions. I think we as a government and-I certainly agree with Senator Lewis-we as a parliament and as a community, have to think about the costs to the relatively small number of people in this community like the families of cystic fibrosis sufferers, like the families of those with other uncommon genetic diseases particularly, who need constant and continuous medication. We really should consider what is the best way to supply the medication to these people. It is specific medication. It is not useful for anyone else. It cannot be diverted for any other uses. I would have thought that the community rating principle, whereby the whole community assisted these people in their unfortunate situation of drugs, would be the best one.

It has been traditional that the States, through their public hospitals, have provided, as the Royal Children's Hospital has up until now, the medication in these situations. If State governments are attempting, as Senator Lewis suggested, to bribe or bully Federal governments we may have to consider whether some sort of a national constribution to a program to support these children is warranted. Frequently children in Tasmania who have cystic fibrosis go to the Royal Children's Hospital or the Prince Henry's Hospital in Melbourne for treatment, so there is an interstate element to this.

However, I think it is most unfortunate that any hospital, particularly a hospital with the record and history of the Royal Children's Hospital would deliberately pick on a group of patients such as this in order to try to stand over the State Government. I will certainly be interested to see what Professor Phelan has to say when he sees the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, next week. I will certainly obtain from Dr Blewett a more detailed reply to Senator Lewis.

Senator Kilgariff was concerned about the possible proclaiming of the second stage of Kakadu National Park. I am a member of the Cabinet and the Cabinet certainly has not yet made a decision on that matter. It may do so next week, I do not know, I have not seen the agenda for next week's Cabinet meeting. The matter may have been discussed by a committee of Cabinet or others this week, but I am not involved in this area and I do not know about it. I cannot comment, nor should I comment, on such a decision. I think that Senator Kilgariff was stretching things a bit when he said that if such a decision has been made it will have been made in haste. We have all heard about Stage I and Stage II of Kakadu National Park for many years in this place. There has been considerable discussion in the Northern Territory, in this Parliament and throughout the community about this matter. I would not have thought that any decision made at this stage would have been made in haste by this Government or any other government.

Senator Crichton-Browne mentioned the case of an industrial dispute in the Pilbarra. I am afraid I do not know anything about that dispute. I do know that at the moment there are discussions between the Commonwealth Government, the Western Australian Government, the Western Australian unions and industry to see whether we cannot improve, on a continuous basis, the industrial relations record in that area. Not knowing the details of the case, I am not willing to comment on it. I do know that Senator Crichton-Browne spent all of his time canning the unions in the Pilbarra area. I would have thought that, in an area that has the sort of industrial relations record that that area has, one might have to look also at the managerial side, as we have to so often in this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not a dispute involving the union.

—I know that. I am talking about the industrial relations record up there. Senator Crichton-Browne also stretched the case a bit when he said-I think this is an accurate quote-that any employer who conducted himself with the same brutal disregard for employees, as he thinks the Amalgamated Metals Foundry and Shipwrights Union has done in this case, would not be tolerated in our society. I wonder what Senator Crichton-Browne thinks of the behaviour of certain large organisations in this community, particularly car manufacturers, when a manager walks into the factory on a Friday night and sacks 600 people without any notice or warning and without any consultation with the unions or the Government having taken place. That sort of behaviour by management would certainly not be tolerated in any of the social democracies of Western Europe. I have said many times that I do not think it should be tolerated in this country. I would have thought it was wrong to condemn that union. I understood from what Senator Crichton-Browne said, that the union came to its decision after a vote of some 200 members. I wonder what would have caused 200 members of the union to take that action after meeting and after consultation. Maybe there is more to it than we have heard from Senator Crichton-Browne, but I am certainly not willing to comment on that. The disregard which he sees for individuals involved in this case cannot just be sheeted home to unions. If it does exist in this country, I believe there are plenty of examples of management doing the same.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Peter Rae was brief. He complained about the lack of responsibility of members of the Executive to the Parliament, particularly in Question Time and during the consideration of the Appropriation Bills. Fortunately, he excluded the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt and I from that. We must have had a good day. I know that at one time in Question Time today things were so quiet that I went to sleep. I must have missed something during that episode.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were probably answering a question.

—I may have been. I cannot really make any detailed comment on what Senator Rae had to say because he did not mention just what upset him in Question Time or what upset him in the consideration of the Appropriation Bills.
—Vulgar abuse as a substitute is the best way of summarising it.

—If it is vulgar abuse as a substitute for answering questions, I would have thought that was a pretty fair pot and kettle exercise. I well remember sitting next to where Senator Rae sits and copping the abuse which we used to cop from Senator Sir John Carrick when he was standing where I am standing now, as well as from other honourable senators in this place at Question Time. I suppose that occasionally people on this side of the chamber who have subconscious memories of those days indulge in the same sorts of tactics. I have no argument with Senator Rae's general principle that the Executive should be responsible to members of the Parliament and the Parliament as a whole. I will look with interest at the Hansard of Question Time and the consideration of the Appropriation Bills today to see just what he was talking about and to see whether he was not being too sensitive. Mr President, I would have thought that you would have pulled up anyone who indulged in that sort of behaviour, as you usually do when I step out of line in this place.
—To save you time I will be delighted to send you a copy of Hansard with some of the objectionable parts identified by underlining.

—I accept that Senator Rae has always had an interest in the responsibility of the Executive to the Parliament. I think that the interest which he has shown has kept him out of the Executive in the past, because of his capacity to irritate executives and those who lead them. If I have not answered anything I will try to answer other matters raised by honourable senators during the next week. I think I have covered all the matters about which honourable senators spoke. I think it is about time the Senate adjourned and we were allowed to finish our evening meal.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Aboriginal Land Rights applications have been received by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.
(2) What claims are currently being heard.
(3) What claims are still outstanding.
(4) What claims are in the hands of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs or awaiting ministerial action.
(5) When is it anticipated a decision will be made on these claims.
(6) How many Aboriginal Land claims have not yet been made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, in substitution for the answer appearing in Hansard of Tuesday, 8 November 1983:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The net number of Aboriginal land claims lodged since the Aboriginal Land Rights Act (Northern Territory) 1976 came into effect is 60. This total takes account of claims which were later replaced, withdrawn, or amalgamated with others. A listing of all applications, with their current status, is contained in the following schedule.

(2) The Jawoyn (Katherine area), Murranju, Warumungu, Kenbi (Cox Peninsula), Beetaloo and Upper Daly River claims have been partly heard. A High Court decision is awaited before the Warumungu and Beetaloo hearings may proceed.

(3) Thirty-one claims, which are listed in the schedule have yet to be heard. The hearings of nine of these are scheduled to commence in 1984. The Cox River, Mt Allen, Nicholson River, Mt Barkly and Ngadi Warlpiri claims have been heard, and the Minister is waiting for the Aboriginal Land Commissioner's reports.
(4) The Finniss River and Daly River (Malak Malak) claims are awaiting Ministerial decisions.

(5) The Finniss River and Daly River claims involve complex issues of potential detriment to other parties, and it will be some months before decisions can be made. A working party of Northern Territory and Australian Government officers, and the Northern Land Council, is currently studying detriment issues involved in the Finniss River land claim.

(6) The number of future claims cannot be forecast. The rate at which applications have been lodged has slowed; only two new applications were received by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner in the year ended 30 June 1983.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 5 October, 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it part of the duty of the Director of the Canberra School of Music to participate in public performances in Canberra and in the school's concert activities.

(2) Has the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs' attention been drawn to an article in the Canberra Times of 21 September 1983 in which the Director of the Canberra School of Music was reported to have said that he would no longer perform in Canberra because criticism of his performances adversely reflected on the school.
(3) Has there been adverse criticism of the Director's performances; if so, have these reflected on the Director or the school.
(4) Did the Director also indicate his reasons for no longer performing in Canberra in a letter to the Friends of the School of Music Society; if so, what were the contents of that letter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The situation of the Director in this regard is different to that of other members of the teaching staff. It is, however, quite appropriate in my view for the person who occupies the position of Director of the School of Music to choose to participate in public performances.

(3) I understand from the Press report referred to in (2) that there have been some comments concerning the present Director's performances, or a particular performance, which he regards as adverse criticism. I cannot of course say as a question of fact whether any such criticism has reflected on either the Director or the school but I do not believe that it has.
(4) I would regard the contents of any correspondence of this kind as being a private matter between the individual and the organisation.
